3.409: out of our view; we skirted the bold shores
3.410: of proud Epirus, in Chaonian land,
3.411: and made Buthrotum's port and towering town.
3.412: Here wondrous tidings met us, that the son
3.413: of Priam, Helenus, held kingly sway
3.414: o'er many Argive cities, having wed
3.415: the Queen of Pyrrhus, great Achilles' son,
3.416: and gained his throne; and that Andromache
3.417: once more was wife unto a kindred lord.
3.418: Amazement held me; all my bosom burned
3.419: to see the hero's face and hear this tale
3.420: of strange vicissitude. So up I climbed,
3.421: leaving the haven, fleet, and friendly shore.
3.422: That self-same hour outside the city walls,
3.423: within a grove where flowed the mimic stream
3.425: with offerings to the dead, and gifts of woe,
3.426: poured forth libation, and invoked the shade
3.427: of Hector, at a tomb which her fond grief
3.429: though void; a mound of fair green turf it stood,
3.430: and near it rose twin altars to his name.
3.431: She saw me drawing near; our Trojan helms
3.432: met her bewildered eyes, and, terror-struck
3.433: at the portentous sight, she swooning fell
3.434: and lay cold, rigid, lifeless, till at last,
3.435: scarce finding voice, her lips addressed me thus :
3.436: “Have I true vision? Bringest thou the word
3.437: Of truth, O goddess-born? Art still in flesh?
3.438: Or if sweet light be fled, my Hector, where?”
3.439: With flood of tears she spoke, and all the grove
3.440: reechoed to her cry. Scarce could I frame
3.441: brief answer to her passion, but replied
3.442: with broken voice and accents faltering:
3.443: “I live, 't is true. I lengthen out my days
3.444: through many a desperate strait. But O, believe
3.445: that what thine eyes behold is vision true.
3.446: Alas! what lot is thine, that wert unthroned
3.447: from such a husband's side? What after-fate
3.448: could give thee honor due? Andromache,
3.449: once Hector's wife, is Pyrrhus still thy lord?”
3.450: With drooping brows and lowly voice she cried :
3.451: “O, happy only was that virgin blest,
3.452: daughter of Priam, summoned forth to die
3.453: in sight of Ilium, on a foeman's tomb!
3.454: No casting of the lot her doom decreed,
3.455: nor came she to her conqueror's couch a slave.
3.456: Myself from burning Ilium carried far
3.457: o'er seas and seas, endured the swollen pride
3.458: of that young scion of Achilles' race,
3.459: and bore him as his slave a son. When he
3.460: sued for Hermione, of Leda's line,
3.462: I, the slave-wife, to Helenus was given,
3.463: and slave was wed with slave. But afterward
3.464: Orestes, crazed by loss of her he loved,
3.465: and ever fury-driven from crime to crime,
3.466: crept upon Pyrrhus in a careless hour
3.467: and murdered him upon his own hearth-stone.
3.468: Part of the realm of Neoptolemus
3.469: fell thus to Helenus, who called his lands
3.470: Chaonian, and in Trojan Chaon's name
3.471: his kingdom is Chaonia. Yonder height
3.473: What power divine did waft thee to our shore,
3.474: not knowing whither? Tell me of the boy
3.475: Ascanius! Still breathes he earthly air?
3.476: In Troy she bore him—is he mourning still
3.477: that mother ravished from his childhood's eyes?
3.478: what ancient valor stirs the manly soul
3.479: of thine own son, of Hector's sister's child?”
3.480: Thus poured she forth full many a doleful word
3.481: with unavailing tears. But as she ceased,
3.482: out of the city gates appeared the son
3.483: of Priam, Helenus, with princely train.
3.484: He welcomed us as kin, and glad at heart
3.485: gave guidance to his house, though oft his words
3.486: fell faltering and few, with many a tear.
3.487: Soon to a humbler Troy I lift my eyes,
3.488: and of a mightier Pergamus discern
3.489: the towering semblance; there a scanty stream
3.490: runs on in Xanthus' name, and my glad arms
3.491: the pillars of a Scaean gate embrace.
3.492: My Teucrian mariners with welcome free
3.493: enjoyed the friendly town; his ample halls
3.494: our royal host threw wide; full wine-cups flowed
3.495: within the palace; golden feast was spread,
3.496: and many a goblet quaffed. Day followed day,
3.497: while favoring breezes beckoned us to sea,
3.498: and swelled the waiting canvas as they blew.
3.499: Then to the prophet-priest I made this prayer:
3.501: Who knowest Phoebus' power, and readest well
3.502: the tripod, stars, and vocal laurel leaves
3.503: to Phoebus dear, who know'st of every bird
3.504: the ominous swift wing or boding song,
3.505: o, speak! For all my course good omens showed,
3.506: and every god admonished me to sail
3.507: in quest of Italy's far-distant shores;
3.508: but lone Celaeno, heralding strange woe,
3.510: and vile, unnatural hunger. How elude
3.511: such perils? Or by what hard duty done
3.512: may such huge host of evils vanquished be?”
3.513: Then Helenus, with sacrifice of kine
3.514: in order due, implored the grace of Heaven,
3.515: unloosed the fillets from his sacred brow,
3.516: and led me, Phoebus, to thy temple's door,
3.517: awed by th' o'er-brooding godhead, whose true priest,
3.518: with lips inspired, made this prophetic song:
3.520: the blessing of great gods upon thy path
3.521: across the sea; the heavenly King supreme
3.522: thy destiny ordains; 't is he unfolds
3.523: the grand vicissitude, which now pursues
3.524: a course immutable. I will declare
3.525: of thy large fate a certain bounded part;
3.526: that fearless thou may'st view the friendly sea,
3.527: and in Ausonia's haven at the last
3.528: find thee a fixed abode. Than this no more
3.529: the Sister Fates to Helenus unveil,
3.530: and Juno, Saturn's daughter, grants no more.
3.531: First, that Italia (which nigh at hand
3.532: thou deemest, and wouldst fondly enter in
3.533: by yonder neighboring bays) lies distant far
3.534: o'er trackless course and long, with interval
3.535: of far-extended lands. Thine oars must ply
3.536: the waves of Sicily; thy fleet must cleave
3.537: the large expanse of that Ausonian brine;
3.538: the waters of Avernus thou shalt see,
3.539: and that enchanted island where abides
3.540: Aeaean Circe, ere on tranquil shore
3.541: thou mayest plant thy nation. Lo! a sign
3.542: I tell thee; hide this wonder in thy heart:
3.543: Beside a certain stream's sequestered wave,
3.544: thy troubled eyes, in shadowy flex grove
3.545: that fringes on the river, shall descry
3.546: a milk-white, monstrous sow, with teeming brood
3.547: of thirty young, new littered, white like her,
3.548: all clustering at her teats, as prone she lies.
3.549: There is thy city's safe, predestined ground,
3.550: and there thy labors' end. Vex not thy heart
3.551: about those ‘tables bitten’, for kind fate
3.552: thy path will show, and Phoebus bless thy prayer.
3.553: But from these lands and yon Italian shore,
3.554: where from this sea of ours the tide sweeps in,
3.555: escape and flee, for all its cities hold
3.556: pernicious Greeks, thy foes: the Locri there
3.557: have builded walls; the wide Sallentine fields
3.558: are filled with soldiers of Idomeneus;
3.560: petilia, towers above its little wall.
3.561: Yea, even when thy fleet has crossed the main,
3.562: and from new altars built along the shore
3.563: thy vows to Heaven are paid, throw o'er thy head
3.564: a purple mantle, veiling well thy brows,
3.565: lest, while the sacrificial fire ascends
3.566: in offering to the gods, thine eye behold
3.567: some face of foe, and every omen fail.
3.568: Let all thy people keep this custom due,
3.569: and thou thyself be faithful; let thy seed
3.570: forever thus th' immaculate rite maintain.
3.571: After departing hence, thou shalt be blown
3.572: toward Sicily, and strait Pelorus' bounds
3.573: will open wide. Then take the leftward way:
3.574: those leftward waters in long circuit sweep,
3.575: far from that billowy coast, the opposing side.
3.576: These regions, so they tell, in ages gone
3.577: by huge and violent convulsion riven
3.579: sprang wide asunder; where the doubled strand
3.580: sole and continuous lay, the sea's vast power
3.581: burst in between, and bade its waves divide
3.583: while with a straitened firth it interflowed
3.584: their fields and cities sundered shore from shore.
3.585: The right side Scylla keeps; the left is given
3.586: to pitiless Charybdis, who draws down
3.587: to the wild whirling of her steep abyss
3.588: the monster waves, and ever and anon
3.589: flings them at heaven, to lash the tranquil stars.
3.590: But Scylla, prisoned in her eyeless cave,
3.591: thrusts forth her face, and pulls upon the rocks
3.592: ship after ship; the parts that first be seen
3.593: are human; a fair-breasted virgin she,
3.594: down to the womb; but all that lurks below
3.595: is a huge-membered fish, where strangely join
3.596: the flukes of dolphins and the paunch of wolves.
3.597: Better by far to round the distant goal
3.598: of the Trinacrian headlands, veering wide
3.599: from thy true course, than ever thou shouldst see
3.600: that shapeless Scylla in her vaulted cave,
3.601: where grim rocks echo her dark sea-dogs' roar.
3.602: Yea, more, if aught of prescience be bestowed
3.603: on Helenus, if trusted prophet he,
3.604: and Phoebus to his heart true voice have given,
3.605: o goddess-born, one counsel chief of all
3.606: I tell thee oft, and urge it o'er and o'er.
3.607: To Juno's godhead lift thy Ioudest prayer;
3.608: to Juno chant a fervent votive song,
3.610: that potent Queen. So shalt thou, triumphing,

3.615: There shalt thou see a frenzied prophetess,
3.616: who from beneath the hollow scarped crag

3.619: on leaves inscribing the portentous song,
3.620: she sets in order, and conceals them well
3.621: in her deep cave, where they abide unchanged
3.622: in due array. Yet not a care has she,
3.623: if with some swinging hinge a breeze sweeps in,
3.624: to catch them as they whirl: if open door
3.625: disperse them flutterlig through the hollow rock,
3.626: she will not link their shifted sense anew,
3.629: scorning the Sibyl's shrine. But deem not thou

3.631: Though thy companions chide, though winds of power

3.634: Pray that her own lips may sing forth for thee
3.635: the oracles, uplifting her dread voice
3.636: in willing prophecy. Her rede shall tell
3.637: of Italy, its wars and tribes to be,
3.638: and of what way each burden and each woe
3.639: may be escaped, or borne. Her favoring aid
3.640: will grant swift, happy voyages to thy prayer.
3.641: Such counsels Heaven to my lips allows.
3.642: arise, begone! and by thy glorious deeds

3.658: Anchises bade us speedily set sail,
3.659: nor lose a wind so fair; and answering him,
3.662: of Venus, self and twice in safety borne

3.687: Thus I made answer, turning to depart
3.688: with rising tears: “Live on, and be ye blessed,
3.689: whose greatness is accomplished! As for me,
3.690: from change to change Fate summons, and I go;
3.691: but ye have won repose. No leagues of sea
3.692: await your cleaving keel. Not yours the quest
3.694: Here a new Xanthus and a second Troy
3.695: your labor fashioned and your eyes may see—
3.696: more blest, I trust, less tempting to our foes!
3.697: If e'er on Tiber and its bordering vales
3.698: I safely enter, and these eyes behold
3.699: our destined walls, then in fraternal bond
3.700: let our two nations live, whose mutual boast
3.701: is one Dardanian blood, one common story.
3.703: one Troy in heart and soul. But this remains
3.704: for our sons' sons the happy task and care.”

3.706: nigh the Ceraunian headland, where begins
3.708: Soon sank the sun, while down the shadowed hills
3.709: stole deeper gloom; then making shore, we flung
3.710: our bodies on a dry, sea-bordering sand,
3.711: couched on earth's welcome breast; the oars were ranged
3.712: in order due; the tides of slumber dark
3.713: o'erflowed our lives. But scarce the chariot
3.714: of Night, on wings of swift, obedient Hours,
3.715: had touched the middle sky, when wakeful sprang
3.716: good Palinurus from his pillowed stone:
3.717: with hand at ear he caught each airy gust
3.718: and questioned of the winds; the gliding stars
3.719: he called by name, as onward they advanced
3.720: through the still heaven; Arcturus he beheld,
3.721: the Hyades, rain-bringers, the twin Bears,
3.722: and vast Orion girt in golden arms.
3.723: He blew a trumpet from his ship; our camp
3.724: stirred to the signal for embarking; soon
3.725: we rode the seas once more with swelling sail.
3.726: Scarce had Aurora's purple from the sky
3.727: warned off the stars, when Iying very low
3.728: along th' horizon, the dimmed hills we saw
3.729: of Italy; Achates first gave cry
3.732: Anchises, then, wreathed a great bowl with flowers
3.733: and filled with wine, invoking Heaven to bless,
3.734: and thus he prayed from our ship's lofty stern:
3.735: “O Iords of land and sea and every storm!
3.736: Breathe favoring breezes for our onward way!”
3.737: Fresh blew the prayed-for winds. A haven fair
3.738: soon widened near us; and its heights were crowned
3.739: by a Greek fane to Pallas. Yet my men
3.740: furled sail and shoreward veered the pointing prow.
3.741: the port receding from the orient wave
3.742: is curved into a bow; on either side
3.743: the jutting headlands toss the salt sea-foam
3.744: and hide the bay itself. Like double wall
3.745: the towered crags send down protecting arms,
3.746: while distant from the shore the temple stands.
3.747: Here on a green sward, the first omen given,
3.748: I saw four horses grazing through the field,
3.749: each white as snow. Father Anchises cried:
3.750: “Is war thy gift, O new and alien land?
3.751: Horses make war; of war these creatures bode.
3.752: Yet oft before the chariot of peace
3.753: their swift hoofs go, and on their necks they bear
3.754: th' obedient yoke and rein. Therefore a hope
3.755: of peace is also ours.” Then we implored
3.756: Minerva's mercy, at her sacred shrine,
3.757: the mail-clad goddess who gave welcome there;
3.758: and at an altar, mantling well our brows
3.759: the Phrygian way, as Helenus ordained,
3.760: we paid the honors his chief counsel urged,
3.761: with blameless rite, to Juno, Argive Queen.
3.762: No tarrying now, but after sacrifice
3.763: we twirled the sailyards and shook out all sail,
3.764: leaving the cities of the sons of Greece
3.765: and that distrusted land. Tarentum's bay
3.766: soon smiled before us, town of Hercules,
3.767: if fame be true; opposing it uptowers
3.769: the heights of Caulon, and that sailors' bane,
3.771: trinacrian Aetna cleaves th' horizon line;
3.772: we hear from far the crash of shouting seas,
3.773: where lifted billows leap the tide-swept sand.
3.774: Father Anchises cried: “'T is none but she—
3.776: and rocks of dreadful name. O, fly, my men!
3.777: Rise like one man with long, strong sweep of oars!”
3.779: veered to the leftward wave the willing keel,
3.780: and sails and oars together leftward strove.
3.781: We shot to skyward on the arching surge,
3.782: then, as she sank, dropped deeper than the grave;
3.783: thrice bellowed the vast cliffs from vaulted wall;
3.784: thrice saw we spouted foam and showers of stars.
3.785: After these things both wind and sun did fail;
3.786: and weary, worn, not witting of our way,
3.787: we drifted shoreward to the Cyclops' land.
3.788: A spreading bay is there, impregnable
3.789: to all invading storms; and Aetna's throat
3.790: with roar of frightful ruin thunders nigh.
3.791: Now to the realm of light it lifts a cloud
3.792: of pitch-black, whirling smoke, and fiery dust,
3.793: shooting out globes of flame, with monster tongues
3.794: that lick the stars; now huge crags of itself,
3.795: out of the bowels of the mountain torn,
3.796: its maw disgorges, while the molten rock
3.797: rolls screaming skyward; from the nether deep
3.798: the fathomless abyss makes ebb and flow.
3.800: lies prisoned under all, so runs the tale:
3.801: o'er him gigantic Aetna breathes in fire
3.802: from crack and seam; and if he haply turn
3.803: to change his wearied side, Trinacria's isle
3.804: trembles and moans, and thick fumes mantle heaven.
3.805: That night in screen and covert of a grove
3.806: we bore the dire convulsion, unaware
3.807: whence the loud horror came. For not a star
3.808: its lamp allowed, nor burned in upper sky
3.809: the constellated fires, but all was gloom,
3.810: and frowning night confined the moon in cloud.
3.811: When from the eastern waves the light of morn
3.812: began to peer, and from the upper sky
3.813: Aurora flamed away the dark and dew,
3.814: out of the forest sprang a startling shape
3.816: in wretched guise, who shoreward came with hands
3.817: outstretched in supplication. We turned back
3.818: and scanned him well. All grime and foulness he,
3.819: with long and tangled beard, his savage garb
3.820: fastened with thorns; but in all else he seemed
3.821: a Greek, and in his country's league of arms
3.822: sent to the seige of Troy. Then he beheld
3.823: the Dardan habit, and our Trojan steel,
3.824: he somewhat paused, as if in dread dismay
3.825: such sight to see, and falteringly moved;
3.826: but soon with headlong steps he sought the shore,
3.828: “By stars above! By gods on high! O, hear!
3.829: By this bright heavenly air we mortals breathe,
3.830: save me, sweet Trojans! Carry me away
3.831: unto what land ye will! I ask no more.
3.832: I came, I know it, in the ships of Greece;
3.833: and I did war, 't is true, with Ilium's gods.
3.834: O, if the crime deserve it, fling my corse
3.835: on yonder waves, and in the boundless brine
3.836: sink me forever! Give me in my death
3.837: the comfort that by human hands I die.”
3.838: He clasped our knees, and writhing on his own
3.839: clung fast. We bid him tell his race and name,
3.840: and by what fate pursued. Anchises gave
3.841: his own right hand in swift and generous aid,
3.842: and by prompt token cheered the exile's heart,
3.843: who, banishing his fears, poured forth this tale :—
3.844: “My home was Ithaca, and I partook
3.846: My name is Achemenides, my sire
3.847: was Adamastus, and I sailed for Troy,
3.848: being so poor,—O, that I ne'er had change
3.849: the lot I bore! In yon vast Cyclops' cave
3.850: my comrades, flying from its gruesome door,
3.851: left me behind, forgotten. 'T is a house
3.852: of gory feasts of flesh, 't is deep and dark,
3.853: and vaulted high. He looms as high as heaven;
3.854: I pray the blessed gods to rid the earth
3.855: of the vile monster! None can look on him,
3.856: none speak with him. He feeds on clotted gore
3.857: of disembowelled men. These very eyes
3.858: saw him seize two of our own company,
3.859: and, as he lolled back in the cave, he clutched
3.860: and dashed them on the stones, fouling the floor
3.861: with torrent of their blood; myself I saw him
3.862: crunch with his teeth the dripping, bloody limbs
3.863: still hot and pulsing on his hungry jaw.
3.864: But not without reward! For such a sight
3.865: Ulysses would not brook, and Ithaca
3.866: forgot not in such strait the name he bore.
3.867: For soon as, gorged with feasting and o'ercome
3.868: with drunken slumber, the foul giant lay
3.869: sprawled through the cave, his head dropped helpless down,
3.870: disgorging as he slept thick drool of gore
3.871: and gobbets drenched with bloody wine; then we,
3.872: calling on Heaven and taking place by lot,
3.873: drew round him like one man, and with a beam
3.874: sharpened at end bored out that monster eye,
3.875: which, huge and sole, lay under the grim brow,
3.876: round as an Argive shield or Phoebus' star.
3.877: Thus took we joyful vengeance for the shades
3.878: of our lost mates. But, O ill-fated men!
3.879: Fly, I implore, and cut the cables free
3.880: along the beach! For in the land abide,
3.881: like Polyphemus, who in hollow cave
3.882: kept fleecy sheep, and milked his fruitful ewes,
3.883: a hundred other, huge as he, who rove
3.884: wide o'er this winding shore and mountains fair:
3.885: Cyclops accursed, bestial! Thrice the moon
3.886: has filled her horns with light, while here I dwell
3.887: in lonely woods and lairs of creatures wild;
3.888: or from tall cliffs out-peering I discern
3.889: the Cyclops, and shrink shuddering from the sound
3.890: of their vast step and cry. My sorry fare
3.891: is berries and hard corners dropped from trees,
3.892: or herb-roots torn out from the niggard ground.
3.893: Though watching the whole sea, only today
3.894: Have I had sight of ships. To you I fled.
3.895: Whate'er ye be, it was my only prayer
3.896: to 'scape that monster brood. I ask no more.
3.897: O, set me free by any death ye will!”
3.898: He scarce had said, when moving o'er the crest
3.899: of a high hill a giant shape we saw:
3.900: that shepherd Polyphemus, with his flocks
3.902: huge, shapeless, horrible, with blinded eye,
3.903: bearing a lopped pine for a staff, he made
3.904: his footing sure, while the white, fleecy sheep,
3.905: sole pleasure now, and solace of his woes,
3.907: Soon to the vast flood of the level brine
3.908: he came, and washed the flowing gore away
3.909: from that out-hollowed eye; he gnashed his teeth,
3.910: groaning, and deep into the watery way
3.911: stalked on, his tall bulk wet by scarce a wave.
3.912: We fled in haste, though far, and with us bore
3.914: the anchor-ropes, and, bending to the oar,
3.915: swept on with eager strokes clean out to sea.
3.916: Aware he was, and toward our loud halloo
3.917: whirled sudden round; but when no power had he
3.918: to seize or harm, nor could his fierce pursuit
3.919: o'ertake the Ionian surges as they rolled,
3.920: he raised a cry incredible; the sea
3.921: with all its billows trembled; the wide shore
3.922: of Italy from glens and gorges moaned,
3.923: and Aetna roared from every vaulted cave.
3.924: Then rallied from the grove-clad, Iofty isle
3.925: the Cyclops' clan, and lined the beach and bay.
3.926: We saw each lonely eyeball glare in vain,
3.927: as side by side those brothers Aetna-born
3.928: stood towering high, a conclave dark and dire:
3.929: as when, far up some mountain's famous crest,
3.931: have made assembling in the solemn hills,
3.932: Jove's giant wood or Dian's sacred grove.
3.933: We, terror-struck, would fly we knew not where,
3.934: with loosened sheet and canvas swelling strong
3.935: before a welcome wind; but Helenus
3.936: bade us both Scylla and Charybdis fear,
3.937: where 'twixt the twain death straitly hems the way;
3.938: and so the counsel was to veer our bark
3.939: the course it came. But lo! a northern gale
3.940: burst o'er us from Pelorus' narrowed side,
3.941: and on we rode far past Pantagia's bay
3.942: of unhewn rock, and past the haven strong
3.943: of Megara, and Thapsus Iying low.
3.944: Such were the names retold, and such the shores
3.945: shown us by Achemenides, whose fate
3.946: made him familiar there, for he had sailed
3.947: with evil-starred Ulysses o'er that sea.
3.948: Off the Sicilian shore an island lies,
3.949: wave-washed Plemmyrium, called in olden days
3.951: from Elis flowed by secret sluice, they say,
3.952: beneath the sea, and mingles at thy mouth,
3.954: Our voices hailed the great gods of the land
3.955: with reverent prayer; then skirted we the shore,
3.956: where smooth Helorus floods the fruitful plain.
3.958: we kept our course; then Camarina rose
3.960: by Fate's decree; and that far-spreading vale
3.961: of Gela, with the name of power it takes
3.962: from its wide river; and, uptowering far,
3.963: the ramparts of proud Acragas appeared,
3.964: where fiery steeds were bred in days of old.
3.965: Borne by the winds, along thy coast I fled,
3.966: Selinus, green with palm! and past the shore
3.967: of Lilybaeum with its treacherous reef;
3.968: till at the last the port of Drepanum
3.969: received me to its melancholy strand.
3.970: Here, woe is me I outworn by stormful seas,
3.971: my sire, sole comfort of my grievous doom,
3.972: Anchises ceased to be. O best of sires!
3.973: Here didst thou leave me in the weary way;
3.974: through all our perils—O the bitter loss! —
3.975: borne safely, but in vain. King Helenus,
3.976: whose prophet-tongue of dark events foretold,
3.977: spoke not this woe; nor did Celeno's curse
3.978: of this forebode. Such my last loss and pain;
3.979: such, of my weary way, the destined goal.
3.980: From thence departing, the divine behest
3.981: impelled me to thy shores, O listening queen!
3.982: Such was, while all gave ear, the tale sublime
3.983: father Aeneas, none but he, set forth
3.984: of wanderings and of dark decrees divine:
3.985: silent at last, he ceased, and took repose.

4.1: Now felt the Queen the sharp, slow-gathering pangs
4.2: of love; and out of every pulsing vein
4.3: nourished the wound and fed its viewless fire.
4.4: Her hero's virtues and his lordly line
4.5: keep calling to her soul; his words, his glance,
4.6: cling to her heart like lingering, barbed steel,
4.7: and rest and peace from her vexed body fly.
4.8: A new day's dawn with Phoebus' lamp divine
4.9: lit up all lands, and from the vaulted heaven
4.10: Aurora had dispelled the dark and dew;
4.11: when thus unto the ever-answering heart
4.12: of her dear sister spoke the stricken Queen:
4.14: perplex me and alarm? What guest is this
4.15: new-welcomed to our house? How proud his mien!
4.16: What dauntless courage and exploits of war!
4.17: Sooth, I receive it for no idle tale
4.18: that of the gods he sprang. 'T is cowardice
4.19: betrays the base-born soul. Ah me! How fate
4.20: has smitten him with storms! What dire extremes
4.21: of war and horror in his tale he told!
4.22: O, were it not immutably resolved
4.23: in my fixed heart, that to no shape of man
4.24: I would be wed again (since my first love
4.25: left me by death abandoned and betrayed);
4.26: loathed I not so the marriage torch and train,
4.27: I could—who knows?—to this one weakness yield.
4.28: Anna, I hide it not! But since the doom
4.29: of my ill-starred Sichaeus, when our shrines
4.30: were by a brother's murder dabbled o'er,
4.31: this man alone has moved me; he alone
4.32: has shaken my weak will. I seem to feel
4.33: the motions of love's lost, familiar fire.
4.34: But may the earth gape open where I tread,
4.35: and may almighty Jove with thunder-scourge
4.36: hurl me to Erebus' abysmal shade,
4.37: to pallid ghosts and midnight fathomless,
4.38: before, O Chastity! I shall offend
4.39: thy holy power, or cast thy bonds away!
4.40: He who first mingled his dear life with mine
4.41: took with him all my heart. 'T is his alone —
4.42: o, let it rest beside him in the grave!”
4.43: She spoke: the bursting tears her breast o'erflowed.
4.44: “O dearer to thy sister than her life,”
4.45: Anna replied, “wouldst thou in sorrow's weed
4.46: waste thy long youth alone, nor ever know
4.47: sweet babes at thine own breast, nor gifts of love?
4.48: Will dust and ashes, or a buried ghost
4.49: reck what we do? 'T is true thy grieving heart
4.50: was cold to earlier wooers, Libya's now,
4.51: and long ago in Tyre. Iarbas knew
4.52: thy scorn, and many a prince and captain bred
4.53: in Afric's land of glory. Why resist
4.54: a love that makes thee glad? Hast thou no care
4.55: what alien lands are these where thou dost reign?
4.56: Here are Gaetulia's cities and her tribes
4.57: unconquered ever; on thy borders rove
4.59: lies Syrtis' cruel shore, and regions wide
4.61: by the wild hordes of Barca. Shall I tell
4.62: of Tyre's hostilities, the threats and rage
4.63: of our own brother? Friendly gods, I bow,
4.64: wafted the Teucrian ships, with Juno's aid,
4.65: to these our shores. O sister, what a throne,
4.66: and what imperial city shall be thine,
4.67: if thus espoused! With Trojan arms allied
4.68: how far may not our Punic fame extend
4.69: in deeds of power? Call therefore on the gods
4.70: to favor thee; and, after omens fair,
4.71: give queenly welcome, and contrive excuse
4.72: to make him tarry, while yon wintry seas
4.73: are loud beneath Orion's stormful star,
4.74: and on his battered ships the season frowns.”
4.75: So saying, she stirred a passion-burning breast
4.76: to Iove more madly still; her words infused
4.77: a doubting mind with hope, and bade the blush
4.78: of shame begone. First to the shrines they went
4.79: and sued for grace; performing sacrifice,
4.80: choosing an offering of unblemished ewes,
4.81: to law-bestowing Ceres, to the god
4.82: of light, to sire Lyeus, Iord of wine;
4.84: of nuptial vows. There Dido, beauteous Queen
4.85: held forth in her right hand the sacred bowl
4.86: and poured it full between the lifted horns
4.87: of the white heifer; or on temple floors
4.88: she strode among the richly laden shrines,
4.89: the eyes of gods upon her, worshipping
4.90: with many a votive gift; or, peering deep
4.91: into the victims' cloven sides, she read
4.93: How blind the hearts of prophets be! Alas!
4.94: Of what avail be temples and fond prayers
4.95: to change a frenzied mind? Devouring ever,
4.96: love's fire burns inward to her bones; she feels
4.97: quick in her breast the viewless, voiceless wound.
4.98: Ill-fated Dido ranges up and down
4.99: the spaces of her city, desperate
4.100: her life one flame—like arrow-stricken doe
4.102: pierced by a far-off shepherd, who pursues
4.103: with shafts, and leaves behind his light-winged steed,
4.104: not knowing; while she scours the dark ravines
4.105: of Dicte and its woodlands; at her heart
4.107: around her city's battlements she guides
4.108: aeneas, to make show of Sidon's gold,
4.109: and what her realm can boast; full oft her voice
4.110: essays to speak and frembling dies away:
4.111: or, when the daylight fades, she spreads anew
4.112: a royal banquet, and once more will plead
4.113: mad that she is, to hear the Trojan sorrow;
4.114: and with oblivious ravishment once more
4.115: hangs on his lips who tells; or when her guests
4.116: are scattered, and the wan moon's fading horn
4.117: bedims its ray, while many a sinking star
4.118: invites to slumber, there she weeps alone
4.119: in the deserted hall, and casts her down
4.120: on the cold couch he pressed. Her love from far
4.121: beholds her vanished hero and receives
4.122: his voice upon her ears; or to her breast,
4.123: moved by a father's image in his child,
4.124: she clasps Ascanius, seeking to deceive
4.125: her unblest passion so. Her enterprise
4.126: of tower and rampart stops: her martial host
4.127: no Ionger she reviews, nor fashions now
4.129: but idly all her half-built bastions frown,
4.130: and enginery of sieges, high as heaven.
4.131: But soon the chosen spouse of Jove perceived
4.132: the Queen's infection; and because the voice
4.133: of honor to such frenzy spoke not, she,
4.134: daughter of Saturn, unto Venus turned
4.135: and counselled thus: “How noble is the praise,
4.136: how glorious the spoils of victory,
4.137: for thee and for thy boy! Your names should be
4.138: in lasting, vast renown—that by the snare
4.139: of two great gods in league one woman fell!
4.140: it 'scapes me not that my protected realms
4.141: have ever been thy fear, and the proud halls
4.142: of Carthage thy vexation and annoy.
4.143: Why further go? Prithee, what useful end
4.144: has our long war? Why not from this day forth
4.146: Hast thou not worked thy will? Behold and see
4.147: how Iove-sick Dido burns, and all her flesh
4.148: 'The madness feels! So let our common grace
4.149: smile on a mingled people! Let her serve
4.150: a Phrygian husband, while thy hands receive
4.151: her Tyrian subjects for the bridal dower!”
4.153: which unto Libyan shores were fain to shift
4.154: italia's future throne) thus Venus spoke:
4.155: “'T were mad to spurn such favor, or by choice
4.156: be numbered with thy foes. But can it be
4.157: that fortune on thy noble counsel smiles?
4.158: To me Fate shows but dimly whether Jove
4.160: a common city with the sons of Tyre,
4.161: with mingling blood and sworn, perpetual peace.
4.162: His wife thou art; it is thy rightful due
4.163: to plead to know his mind. Go, ask him, then!
4.164: For humbly I obey!” With instant word
4.165: Juno the Queen replied: “Leave that to me!
4.166: But in what wise our urgent task and grave
4.167: may soon be sped, I will in brief unfold
4.168: to thine attending ear. A royal hunt
4.169: in sylvan shades unhappy Dido gives
4.170: for her Aeneas, when to-morrow's dawn
4.171: uplifts its earliest ray and Titan's beam
4.172: shall first unveil the world. But I will pour
4.173: black storm-clouds with a burst of heavy hail
4.174: along their way; and as the huntsmen speed
4.175: to hem the wood with snares, I will arouse
4.176: all heaven with thunder. The attending train
4.177: shall scatter and be veiled in blinding dark,
4.178: while Dido and her hero out of Troy
4.179: to the same cavern fly. My auspices
4.180: I will declare—if thou alike wilt bless;
4.181: and yield her in true wedlock for his bride.
4.182: Such shall their spousal be!” To Juno's will
4.184: and laughed such guile to see. Aurora rose,
4.185: and left the ocean's rim. The city's gates
4.186: pour forth to greet the morn a gallant train
4.187: of huntsmen, bearing many a woven snare
4.188: and steel-tipped javelin; while to and fro
4.189: run the keen-scented dogs and Libyan squires.
4.190: The Queen still keeps her chamber; at her doors
4.191: the Punic lords await; her palfrey, brave
4.192: in gold and purple housing, paws the ground
4.193: and fiercely champs the foam-flecked bridle-rein.
4.194: At last, with numerous escort, forth she shines:
4.195: her Tyrian pall is bordered in bright hues,
4.196: her quiver, gold; her tresses are confined
4.197: only with gold; her robes of purple rare
4.198: meet in a golden clasp. To greet her come
4.199: the noble Phrygian guests; among them smiles
4.200: the boy Iulus; and in fair array
4.201: Aeneas, goodliest of all his train.
4.202: In such a guise Apollo (when he leaves
4.203: cold Lycian hills and Xanthus' frosty stream
4.204: to visit Delos to Latona dear)
4.205: ordains the song, while round his altars cry
4.206: the choirs of many islands, with the pied,
4.208: moves o'er the Cynthian steep; his flowing hair
4.209: he binds with laurel garland and bright gold;
4.210: upon his shining shoulder as he goes
4.211: the arrows ring:—not less uplifted mien
4.212: aeneas wore; from his illustrious brow
4.213: such beauty shone. Soon to the mountains tall
4.214: the cavalcade comes nigh, to pathless haunts
4.215: of woodland creatures; the wild goats are seen,
4.216: from pointed crag descending leap by leap
4.217: down the steep ridges; in the vales below
4.218: are routed deer, that scour the spreading plain,
4.219: and mass their dust-blown squadrons in wild flight,
4.220: far from the mountain's bound. Ascanius
4.221: flushed with the sport, spurs on a mettled steed
4.222: from vale to vale, and many a flying herd
4.223: his chase outspeeds; but in his heart he prays
4.224: among these tame things suddenly to see
4.225: a tusky boar, or, leaping from the hills,
4.227: Meanwhile low thunders in the distant sky
4.228: mutter confusedly; soon bursts in full
4.229: the storm-cloud and the hail. The Tyrian troop
4.230: is scattered wide; the chivalry of Troy,
4.231: with the young heir of Dardan's kingly line,
4.232: of Venus sprung, seek shelter where they may,
4.233: with sudden terror; down the deep ravines
4.234: the swollen torrents roar. In that same hour
4.235: Queen Dido and her hero out of Troy
4.236: to the same cavern fly. Old Mother-Earth
4.237: and wedlock-keeping Juno gave the sign;
4.238: the flash of lightnings on the conscious air
4.239: were torches to the bridal; from the hills
4.240: the wailing wood-nymphs sobbed a wedding song.
4.241: Such was that day of death, the source and spring
4.242: of many a woe. For Dido took no heed
4.243: of honor and good-name; nor did she mean
4.244: her loves to hide; but called the lawlessness
4.245: a marriage, and with phrases veiled her shame.
4.246: Swift through the Libyan cities Rumor sped.
4.247: Rumor! What evil can surpass her speed?
4.248: In movement she grows mighty, and achieves
4.249: strength and dominion as she swifter flies.
4.250: small first, because afraid, she soon exalts
4.251: her stature skyward, stalking through the lands
4.252: and mantling in the clouds her baleful brow.
4.253: The womb of Earth, in anger at high Heaven,
4.254: bore her, they say, last of the Titan spawn,
4.256: Feet swift to run and pinions like the wind
4.257: the dreadful monster wears; her carcase huge
4.258: is feathered, and at root of every plume
4.259: a peering eye abides; and, strange to tell,
4.260: an equal number of vociferous tongues,
4.261: foul, whispering lips, and ears, that catch at all.
4.262: At night she spreads midway 'twixt earth and heaven
4.263: her pinions in the darkness, hissing loud,
4.264: nor e'er to happy slumber gives her eyes:
4.265: but with the morn she takes her watchful throne
4.266: high on the housetops or on lofty towers,
4.267: to terrify the nations. She can cling
4.268: to vile invention and malignant wrong,
4.269: or mingle with her word some tidings true.
4.270: She now with changeful story filled men's ears,
4.271: exultant, whether false or true she sung:
4.273: Dido, the lovely widow, Iooked his way,
4.274: deigning to wed; how all the winter long
4.275: they passed in revel and voluptuous ease,
4.276: to dalliance given o'er; naught heeding now
4.278: Such tidings broadcast on the lips of men
4.279: the filthy goddess spread; and soon she hied
4.280: to King Iarbas, where her hateful song
4.281: to newly-swollen wrath his heart inflamed.
4.282: Him the god Ammon got by forced embrace
4.283: upon a Libyan nymph; his kingdoms wide
4.284: possessed a hundred ample shrines to Jove,
4.285: a hundred altars whence ascended ever
4.286: the fires of sacrifice, perpetual seats
4.287: for a great god's abode, where flowing blood
4.288: enriched the ground, and on the portals hung
4.289: garlands of every flower. The angered King,
4.291: unto his favored altars came, and there,
4.293: upraised in prayer to Jove his suppliant hands.
4.295: at banquet on the painted couch reclined,
4.296: Numidia pours libation! Do thine eyes
4.297: behold us? Or when out of yonder heaven,
4.298: o sire, thou launchest the swift thunderbolt,
4.299: is it for naught we fear thee? Do the clouds
4.300: shoot forth blind fire to terrify the soul
4.301: with wild, unmeaning roar? O, Iook upon
4.302: that woman, who was homeless in our realm,
4.303: and bargained where to build her paltry town,
4.304: receiving fertile coastland for her farms,
4.305: by hospitable grant! She dares disdain
4.306: our proffered nuptial vow. She has proclaimed
4.307: Aeneas partner of her bed and throne.
4.308: And now that Paris, with his eunuch crew,
4.309: beneath his chin and fragrant, oozy hair
4.310: ties the soft Lydian bonnet, boasting well
4.311: his stolen prize. But we to all these fanes,
4.312: though they be thine, a fruitless offering bring,
4.313: and feed on empty tales our trust in thee.”
4.314: As thus he prayed and to the altars clung,
4.315: th' Omnipotent gave ear, and turned his gaze
4.316: upon the royal dwelling, where for love
4.317: the amorous pair forgot their place and name.
4.318: Then thus to Mercury he gave command:
4.319: “Haste thee, my son, upon the Zephyrs call,
4.320: and take thy winged way! My mandate bear
4.321: unto that prince of Troy who tarries now
4.323: of empire Heaven-bestowed. On winged winds
4.324: hasten with my decrees. Not such the man
4.325: his beauteous mother promised; not for this
4.326: twice did she shield him from the Greeks in arms:
4.327: but that he might rule Italy, a land
4.328: pregnant with thrones and echoing with war;
4.329: that he of Teucer's seed a race should sire,
4.330: and bring beneath its law the whole wide world.
4.331: If such a glory and event supreme
4.332: enkindle not his bosom; if such task
4.333: to his own honor speak not; can the sire
4.335: of the proud name of Rome? What plans he now?
4.336: What mad hope bids him linger in the lap
4.338: the land Lavinian and Ausonia's sons.
4.339: Let him to sea! Be this our final word:
4.340: this message let our herald faithful bear.”
4.341: He spoke. The god a prompt obedience gave
4.342: to his great sire's command. He fastened first
4.343: those sandals of bright gold, which carry him
4.344: aloft o'er land or sea, with airy wings
4.345: that race the fleeting wind; then lifted he
4.346: his wand, wherewith he summons from the grave
4.347: pale-featured ghosts, or, if he will, consigns
4.348: to doleful Tartarus; or by its power
4.349: gives slumber or dispels; or quite unseals
4.350: the eyelids of the dead: on this relying,
4.351: he routs the winds or cleaves th' obscurity
4.352: of stormful clouds. Soon from his flight he spied
4.353: the summit and the sides precipitous
4.354: of stubborn Atlas, whose star-pointing peak
4.355: props heaven; of Atlas, whose pine-wreathed brow
4.356: is girdled evermore with misty gloom
4.357: and lashed of wind and rain; a cloak of snow
4.358: melts on his shoulder; from his aged chin
4.359: drop rivers, and ensheathed in stiffening ice
4.360: glitters his great grim beard. Here first was stayed
4.361: the speed of Mercury's well-poising wing;
4.362: here making pause, from hence he headlong flung
4.363: his body to the sea; in motion like
4.364: some sea-bird's, which along the levelled shore
4.365: or round tall crags where rove the swarming fish,
4.366: flies Iow along the waves: o'er-hovering so
4.367: between the earth and skies, Cyllene's god
4.368: flew downward from his mother's mountain-sire,
4.369: parted the winds and skimmed the sandy merge
4.370: of Libya. When first his winged feet
4.371: came nigh the clay-built Punic huts, he saw
4.373: and founding walls and towers; at his side
4.374: was girt a blade with yellow jaspers starred,
4.375: his mantle with the stain of Tyrian shell
4.376: flowed purple from his shoulder, broidered fair
4.377: by opulent Dido with fine threads of gold,
4.378: her gift of love; straightway the god began:
4.379: “Dost thou for lofty Carthage toil, to build
4.380: foundations strong? Dost thou, a wife's weak thrall,
4.381: build her proud city? Hast thou, shameful loss!
4.382: Forgot thy kingdom and thy task sublime?
4.383: From bright Olympus, I. He who commands
4.384: all gods, and by his sovran deity
4.385: moves earth and heaven—he it was who bade
4.386: me bear on winged winds his high decree.
4.387: What plan is thine? By what mad hope dost thou
4.388: linger so Iong in lap of Libyan land?
4.389: If the proud reward of thy destined way
4.390: move not thy heart, if all the arduous toil
4.391: to thine own honor speak not, Iook upon
4.392: Iulus in his bloom, thy hope and heir
4.393: Ascanius. It is his rightful due
4.394: in Italy o'er Roman lands to reign.”
4.395: After such word Cyllene's winged god
4.396: vanished, and e'er his accents died away,
4.397: dissolved in air before the mortal's eyes.
4.398: Aeneas at the sight stood terror-dumb
4.399: with choking voice and horror-rising hair.
4.400: He fain would fly at once and get him gone
4.401: from that voluptuous land, much wondering
4.402: at Heaven's wrathful word. Alas! how stir?
4.403: What cunning argument can plead his cause
4.404: before th' infuriate Queen? How break such news?
4.405: Flashing this way and that, his startled mind
4.406: makes many a project and surveys them all.
4.407: But, pondering well, his final counsel stopped
4.408: at this resolve: he summoned to his side
4.410: and bade them fit the fleet, all silently
4.411: gathering the sailors and collecting gear,
4.413: such novel stir intends: himself the while
4.414: (Since high-born Dido dreamed not love so fond
4.415: could have an end) would seek an audience,
4.416: at some indulgent time, and try what shift
4.417: such matters may require. With joy they heard,
4.418: and wrought, assiduous, at their prince's plan.
4.419: But what can cheat true love? The Queen foreknew
4.420: his stratagem, and all the coming change
4.421: perceived ere it began. Her jealous fear
4.422: counted no hour secure. That unclean tongue
4.423: of Rumor told her fevered heart the fleet
4.424: was fitting forth, and hastening to be gone.
4.426: roamed through her city, like a Maenad roused
4.427: by the wild rout of Bacchus, when are heard
4.428: the third year's orgies, and the midnight scream
4.429: to cold Cithaeron calls the frenzied crew.
4.430: Finding Aeneas, thus her plaint she poured:
4.431: “Didst hope to hide it, false one, that such crime
4.432: was in thy heart,—to steal without farewell
4.433: out of my kingdom? Did our mutual joy
4.434: not move thee; nor thine own true promise given
4.435: once on a time? Nor Dido, who will die
4.436: a death of sorrow? Why compel thy ships
4.437: to brave the winter stars? Why off to sea
4.438: so fast through stormy skies? O, cruelty!
4.439: If Troy still stood, and if thou wert not bound
4.440: for alien shore unknown, wouldst steer for Troy
4.441: through yonder waste of waves? Is it from me
4.442: thou takest flight? O, by these flowing tears,
4.443: by thine own plighted word (for nothing more
4.444: my weakness left to miserable me),
4.445: by our poor marriage of imperfect vow,
4.446: if aught to me thou owest, if aught in me
4.447: ever have pleased thee—O, be merciful
4.448: to my low-fallen fortunes! I implore,
4.449: if place be left for prayer, thy purpose change!
4.450: Because of thee yon Libyan savages
4.451: and nomad chiefs are grown implacable,
4.452: and my own Tyrians hate me. Yes, for thee
4.453: my chastity was slain and honor fair,
4.454: by which alone to glory I aspired,
4.455: in former days. To whom dost thou in death
4.456: abandon me? my guest!—since but this name
4.457: is left me of a husband! Shall I wait
4.458: till fell Pygmalion, my brother, raze
4.459: my city walls? Or the Gaetulian king,
4.460: Iarbas, chain me captive to his car? .
4.461: O, if, ere thou hadst fled, I might but bear
4.462: some pledge of love to thee, and in these halls
4.463: watch some sweet babe Aeneas at his play,
4.464: whose face should be the memory of thine own —
4.465: I were not so forsaken, Iost, undone!”
4.466: She said. But he, obeying Jove's decree,
4.467: gazed steadfastly away; and in his heart
4.468: with strong repression crushed his cruel pain;
4.469: then thus the silence broke: “O Queen, not one
4.470: of my unnumbered debts so strongly urged
4.472: will be my treasure Iong as memory holds,
4.473: or breath of life is mine. Hear my brief plea!
4.474: 'T was not my hope to hide this flight I take,
4.475: as thou hast dreamed. Nay, I did never light
4.476: a bridegroom's torch, nor gave I thee the vow
4.477: of marriage. Had my destiny decreed,
4.478: that I should shape life to my heart's desire,
4.479: and at my own will put away the weight
4.480: of foil and pain, my place would now be found
4.481: in Troy, among the cherished sepulchres
4.482: of my own kin, and Priam's mansion proud
4.483: were standing still; or these my loyal hands
4.484: had rebuilt Ilium for her vanquished sons.
4.485: But now to Italy Apollo's power
4.486: commands me forth; his Lycian oracles
4.487: are loud for Italy. My heart is there,
4.488: and there my fatherland. If now the towers
4.489: of Carthage and thy Libyan colony
4.490: delight thy Tyrian eyes; wilt thou refuse
4.491: to Trojan exiles their Ausonian shore?
4.492: I too by Fate was driven, not less than thou,
4.493: to wander far a foreign throne to find.
4.494: Oft when in dewy dark night hides the world,
4.495: and flaming stars arise, Anchises' shade
4.496: looks on me in my dreams with angered brow.
4.497: I think of my Ascanius, and the wrong
4.498: to that dear heart, from whom I steal away
4.499: Hesperia, his destined home and throne.
4.500: But now the winged messenger of Heaven,
4.501: sent down by Jove (I swear by thee and me!),
4.502: has brought on winged winds his sire's command.
4.503: My own eyes with unclouded vision saw
4.504: the god within these walls; I have received
4.505: with my own ears his word. No more inflame
4.506: with lamentation fond thy heart and mine.
4.507: 'T is not my own free act seeks Italy.”
4.508: She with averted eyes and glance that rolled
4.509: speechless this way and that, had listened long
4.510: to his reply, till thus her rage broke forth:
4.511: “No goddess gave thee birth. No Dardanus
4.512: begot thy sires. But on its breast of stone
4.513: Caucasus bore thee, and the tigresses
4.514: of fell Hyrcania to thy baby lip
4.515: their udders gave. Why should I longer show
4.516: a lying smile? What worse can I endure?
4.517: Did my tears draw one sigh? Did he once drop
4.518: his stony stare? or did he yield a tear
4.519: to my lament, or pity this fond heart?
4.520: Why set my wrongs in order? Juno, now,
4.521: and Jove, the son of Saturn, heed no more
4.522: where justice lies. No trusting heart is safe
4.523: in all this world. That waif and castaway
4.524: I found in beggary and gave him share—
4.525: fool that I was!—in my own royal glory.
4.526: His Iost fleet and his sorry crews I steered
4.527: from death away. O, how my fevered soul
4.529: His Lycian oracles! and sent by Jove
4.530: the messenger of Heaven on fleeting air
4.531: the ruthless bidding brings! Proud business
4.532: for gods, I trow, that such a task disturbs
4.533: their still abodes! I hold thee back no more,
4.534: nor to thy cunning speeches give the lie.
4.535: Begone! Sail on to Italy, thy throne,
4.536: through wind and wave! I pray that, if there be
4.537: any just gods of power, thou mayest drink down
4.538: death on the mid-sea rocks, and often call
4.539: with dying gasps on Dido's name—while I
4.540: pursue with vengeful fire. When cold death rends
4.541: the body from the breath, my ghost shall sit
4.542: forever in thy path. Full penalties
4.543: thy stubborn heart shall pay. They'll bring me never
4.544: in yon deep gulf of death of all thy woe.”
4.545: Abrupt her utterance ceased; and sick at heart
4.546: she fled the light of day, as if to shrink
4.547: from human eyes, and left Aeneas there
4.548: irresolute with horror, while his soul
4.549: framed many a vain reply. Her swooning shape
4.550: her maidens to a marble chamber bore
4.551: and on her couch the helpless limbs reposed.
4.552: Aeneas, faithful to a task divine,
4.553: though yearning sore to remedy and soothe
4.554: such misery, and with the timely word
4.555: her grief assuage, and though his burdened heart
4.556: was weak because of love, while many a groan
4.557: rose from his bosom, yet no whit did fail
4.558: to do the will of Heaven, but of his fleet
4.559: resumed command. The Trojans on the shore
4.560: ply well their task and push into the sea
4.561: the lofty ships. Now floats the shining keel,
4.562: and oars they bring all leafy from the grove,
4.563: with oak half-hewn, so hurried was the flight.
4.564: Behold them how they haste—from every gate
4.565: forth-streaming!—just as when a heap of corn
4.566: is thronged with ants, who, knowing winter nigh,
4.567: refill their granaries; the long black line
4.568: runs o'er the levels, and conveys the spoil
4.569: in narrow pathway through the grass; a part
4.570: with straining and assiduous shoulder push
4.571: the kernels huge; a part array the file,
4.572: and whip the laggards on; their busy track
4.573: swarms quick and eager with unceasing toil.
4.574: O Dido, how thy suffering heart was wrung,
4.575: that spectacle to see! What sore lament
4.576: was thine, when from the towering citadel
4.577: the whole shore seemed alive, the sea itself
4.578: in turmoil with loud cries! Relentless Love,
4.579: to what mad courses may not mortal hearts
4.580: by thee be driven? Again her sorrow flies
4.581: to doleful plaint and supplication vain;
4.582: again her pride to tyrant Love bows down
4.583: lest, though resolved to die, she fail to prove
4.584: each hope of living: “O Anna, dost thou see
4.585: yon busy shore? From every side they come.
4.586: their canvas wooes the winds, and o'er each prow
4.587: the merry seamen hang their votive flowers.
4.588: Dear sister, since I did forebode this grief,
4.589: I shall be strong to bear it. One sole boon
4.590: my sorrow asks thee, Anna! Since of thee,
4.591: thee only, did that traitor make a friend,
4.592: and trusted thee with what he hid so deep —
4.593: the feelings of his heart; since thou alone
4.594: hast known what way, what hour the man would yield
4.596: and humbly thus implore our haughty foe:
4.597: ‘I was not with the Greeks what time they swore
4.598: at Aulis to cut off the seed of Troy;
4.599: I sent no ships to Ilium. Pray, have I
4.600: profaned Anchises' tomb, or vexed his shade?’
4.601: Why should his ear be deaf and obdurate
4.602: to all I say? What haste? May he not make
4.603: one last poor offering to her whose love
4.604: is only pain? O, bid him but delay
4.605: till flight be easy and the winds blow fair.
4.606: I plead no more that bygone marriage-vow
4.607: by him forsworn, nor ask that he should lose
4.608: his beauteous Latium and his realm to be.
4.609: Nothing but time I crave! to give repose
4.610: and more room to this fever, till my fate
4.611: teach a crushed heart to sorrow. I implore
4.612: this last grace. (To thy sister's grief be kind!)
4.613: I will requite with increase, till I die.”
4.614: Such plaints, such prayers, again and yet again,
4.615: betwixt the twain the sorrowing sister bore.
4.616: But no words move, no lamentations bring
4.617: persuasion to his soul; decrees of Fate
4.618: oppose, and some wise god obstructs the way
4.619: that finds the hero's ear. Oft-times around
4.620: the aged strength of some stupendous oak
4.621: the rival blasts of wintry Alpine winds
4.622: smite with alternate wrath: Ioud is the roar,
4.623: and from its rocking top the broken boughs
4.624: are strewn along the ground; but to the crag
4.625: steadfast it ever clings; far as toward heaven
4.626: its giant crest uprears, so deep below
4.627: its roots reach down to Tartarus:—not less
4.628: the hero by unceasing wail and cry
4.629: is smitten sore, and in his mighty heart
4.630: has many a pang, while his serene intent
4.631: abides unmoved, and tears gush forth in vain.
4.632: Then wretched Dido, by her doom appalled,
4.633: asks only death. It wearies her to see
4.634: the sun in heaven. Yet that she might hold fast
4.635: her dread resolve to quit the light of day,
4.636: behold, when on an incense-breathing shrine
4.637: her offering was laid—O fearful tale!—
4.638: the pure libation blackened, and the wine
4.639: flowed like polluting gore. She told the sight
4.640: to none, not even to her sister's ear.
4.641: A second sign was given: for in her house
4.642: a marble altar to her husband's shade,
4.643: with garlands bright and snowy fleeces dressed,
4.644: had fervent worship; here strange cries were heard
4.645: as if her dead spouse called while midnight reigned,
4.646: and round her towers its inhuman song
4.647: the lone owl sang, complaining o'er and o'er
4.648: with lamentation and long shriek of woe.
4.650: whisper old omens dire. In dreams she feels
4.651: cruel Aeneas goad her madness on,
4.652: and ever seems she, friendless and alone,
4.653: some lengthening path to travel, or to seek
4.654: her Tyrians through wide wastes of barren lands.
4.655: Thus frantic Pentheus flees the stern array
4.656: of the Eumenides, and thinks to see
4.657: two noonday lights blaze oer his doubled Thebes;
4.659: Orestes, flees his mother's phantom scourge
4.660: of flames and serpents foul, while at his door
4.662: and by her grief undone, resolved on death,
4.663: the manner and the time her secret soul
4.664: prepares, and, speaking to her sister sad,
4.665: she masks in cheerful calm her fatal will:
4.666: “I know a way—O, wish thy sister joy!—
4.667: to bring him back to Iove, or set me free.
4.668: On Ocean's bound and next the setting sun
4.669: lies the last Aethiop land, where Atlas tall
4.670: lifts on his shoulder the wide wheel of heaven,
4.671: studded with burning stars. From thence is come
4.672: a witch, a priestess, a Numidian crone,
4.673: who guards the shrine of the Hesperides
4.674: and feeds the dragon; she protects the fruit
4.675: of that enchanting tree, and scatters there
4.676: her slumb'rous poppies mixed with honey-dew.
4.677: Her spells and magic promise to set free
4.678: what hearts she will, or visit cruel woes
4.679: on men afar. She stops the downward flow
4.680: of rivers, and turns back the rolling stars;
4.681: on midnight ghosts she calls: her vot'ries hear
4.682: earth bellowing loud below, while from the hills
4.683: the ash-trees travel down. But, sister mine,
4.684: thou knowest, and the gods their witness give,
4.685: how little mind have I to don the garb
4.686: of sorcery. Depart in secret, thou,
4.687: and bid them build a lofty funeral pyre
4.688: inside our palalce-wall, and heap thereon
4.689: the hero's arms, which that blasphemer hung
4.690: within my chamber; every relic bring,
4.691: and chiefly that ill-omened nuptial bed,
4.692: my death and ruin! For I must blot out
4.693: all sight and token of this husband vile.
4.694: 'T is what the witch commands.” She spoke no more,
4.695: and pallid was her brow. Yet Anna's mind
4.696: knew not what web of death her sister wove
4.697: by these strange rites, nor what such frenzy dares;
4.698: nor feared she worse than when Sichaeus died,
4.699: but tried her forth the errand to fulfil.
4.700: Soon as the funeral pyre was builded high
4.701: in a sequestered garden, Iooming huge
4.702: with boughs of pine and faggots of cleft oak,
4.703: the queen herself enwreathed it with sad flowers
4.704: and boughs of mournful shade; and crowning all
4.705: she laid on nuptial bed the robes and sword
4.706: by him abandoned; and stretched out thereon
4.707: a mock Aeneas;—but her doom she knew.
4.708: Altars were there; and with loose locks unbound
4.709: the priestess with a voice of thunder called
4.710: three hundred gods, Hell, Chaos, the three shapes
4.711: of triple Hecate, the faces three
4.712: of virgin Dian. She aspersed a stream
4.713: from dark Avernus drawn, she said; soft herbs
4.714: were cut by moonlight with a blade of bronze,
4.715: oozing black poison-sap; and she had plucked
4.716: that philter from the forehead of new foal
4.717: before its dam devours. Dido herself,
4.718: sprinkling the salt meal, at the altar stands;
4.719: one foot unsandalled, and with cincture free,
4.720: on all the gods and fate-instructed stars,
4.721: foreseeing death, she calls. But if there be
4.722: some just and not oblivious power on high,
4.723: who heeds when lovers plight unequal vow,
4.724: to that god first her supplications rise.
4.725: Soon fell the night, and peaceful slumbers breathed
4.726: on all earth's weary creatures; the loud seas
4.727: and babbling forests entered on repose;
4.728: now midway in their heavenly course the stars
4.729: wheeled silent on; the outspread lands below
4.730: lay voiceless; all the birds of tinted wing,
4.731: and flocks that haunt the merge of waters wide
4.732: or keep the thorny wold, oblivious lay
4.733: beneath the night so still; the stings of care
4.734: ceased troubling, and no heart its burden knew.
4.735: Not so the Tyrian Queen's deep-grieving soul!
4.736: To sleep she could not yield; her eyes and heart
4.737: refused the gift of night; her suffering
4.738: redoubled, and in full returning tide
4.739: her love rebelled, while on wild waves of rage
4.740: she drifted to and fro. So, ceasing not
4.741: from sorrow, thus she brooded on her wrongs:
4.742: “What refuge now? Shall I invite the scorn
4.743: of my rejected wooers, or entreat
4.745: to take me to his bed—though many a time
4.746: such husbands I made mock of? Shall I sail
4.747: on Ilian ships away, and sink to be
4.748: the Trojans' humble thrall? Do they rejoice
4.749: that once I gave them bread? Lives gratitude
4.750: in hearts like theirs for bygone kindnesses?
4.751: O, who, if so I stooped, would deign to bear
4.752: on yon proud ships the scorned and fallen Queen?
4.753: Lost creature! Woe betide thee! Knowest thou not
4.755: What way is left? Should I take flight alone
4.756: and join the revelling sailors? Or depart
4.757: with Tyrians, the whole attending train
4.758: of my own people? Hard the task to force
4.759: their hearts from Sidon's towers; how once more
4.760: compel to sea, and bid them spread the sail?
4.761: Nay, perish! Thou hast earned it. Let the sword
4.762: from sorrow save thee! Sister of my blood—
4.763: who else but thee,—my own tears borne down,
4.764: didst heap disaster on my frantic soul,
4.765: and fling me to this foe? Why could I not
4.766: pass wedlock by, and live a blameless life
4.767: as wild things do, nor taste of passion's pain?
4.768: But I broke faith! I cast the vows away
4.769: made at Sichaeus' grave.” Such loud lament
4.770: burst from her breaking heart with doleful sound.
4.771: Meanwhile Aeneas on his lofty ship,
4.772: having made ready all, and fixed his mind
4.773: to launch away upon brief slumher fell.
4.774: But the god came; and in the self-same guise
4.775: once more in monitory vision spoke,
4.776: all guised as Mercury,—his voice, his hue,
4.777: his golden locks, and young limbs strong and fair.
4.778: “Hail, goddess-born! Wouldst linger on in sleep
4.779: at such an hour? Nor seest thou the snares
4.780: that hem thee round? Nor hearest thou the voice
4.781: of friendly zephyrs calling? Senseless man!
4.782: That woman's breast contrives some treachery
4.783: and horrid stroke; for, resolute to die,
4.784: she drifts on swollen floods of wrath and scorn.
4.785: Wilt thou not fly before the hastening hour
4.786: of flight is gone? To-morrow thou wilt see
4.787: yon waters thronged with ships, the cruel glare
4.788: of fire-brands, and yonder shore all flame,
4.789: if but the light of morn again surprise
4.790: thee loitering in this land. Away! Away!
4.791: Stay not! A mutable and shifting thing
4.792: is woman ever.” Such command he spoke,
4.793: then melted in the midnight dark away.
4.794: Aeneas, by that fleeting vision struck
4.795: with an exceeding awe, straightway leaped forth
4.796: from slumber's power, and to his followers cried :
4.797: “Awake, my men! Away! Each to his place
4.798: upon the thwarts! Unfurl at once the sails!
4.799: A god from heaven a second time sent down
4.800: urges our instant flight and bids us cut
4.801: the twisted cords. Whatever be thy name,
4.802: behold, we come, O venerated Power!
4.803: Again with joy we follow! Let thy grace
4.804: assist us as we go! And may thy power
4.805: bring none but stars benign across our sky.”
4.806: So saying, from its scabbard forth he flashed
4.807: the lightning of his sword, with naked blade
4.808: striking the hawsers free. Like ardor seized
4.809: on all his willing men, who raced and ran;
4.810: and, while their galleys shadowed all the sea,
4.811: clean from the shore they scudded, with strong strokes
4.812: sweeping the purple waves and crested foam.
4.813: Aurora's first young beams to earth were pouring
4.814: as from Tithonus' saffron bed she sprang;
4.815: while from her battlements the wakeful Queen
4.816: watched the sky brighten, saw the mated sails
4.817: push forth to sea, till all her port and strand
4.818: held not an oar or keel. Thrice and four times
4.819: she smote her lovely breast with wrathful hand,
4.820: and tore her golden hair. “Great Jove,” she cries,
4.822: of me, a queen? Will not my men-at-arms
4.823: draw sword, give chase, from all my city thronging?
4.824: Down from the docks, my ships! Out, out! Begone!
4.825: Take fire and sword! Bend to your oars, ye slaves!
4.826: What have I said? Where am I? What mad thoughts
4.827: delude this ruined mind? Woe unto thee,
4.828: thou wretched Dido, now thy impious deeds
4.829: strike back upon thee. Wherefore struck they not,
4.830: as was most fit, when thou didst fling away
4.831: thy sceptre from thy hand? O Iying oaths!
4.832: O faith forsworn! of him who brings, they boast,
4.833: his father's gods along, and bowed his back
4.834: to lift an age-worn sire! Why dared I not
4.835: seize on him, rend his body limb from limb,
4.836: and hurl him piecemeal on the rolling sea?
4.837: Or put his troop of followers to the sword,
4.838: ascanius too, and set his flesh before
4.839: that father for a feast? Such fearful war
4.840: had been of doubtful issue. Be it so!
4.841: What fears a woman dying? Would I had
4.842: attacked their camp with torches, kindled flame
4.843: from ship to ship, until that son and sire,
4.844: with that whole tribe, were unto ashes burned
4.845: in one huge holocaust—myself its crown!
4.846: Great orb of light whose holy beam surveys
4.847: all earthly deeds! Great Juno, patroness
4.848: of conjugal distress, who knowest all!
4.849: Pale Hecate, whose name the witches cry
4.850: at midnight crossways! O avenging furies!
4.851: O gods that guard Queen Dido's dying breath!
4.852: Give ear, and to my guiltless misery
4.853: extend your power. Hear me what I pray!
4.854: If it be fated that yon creature curst
4.855: drift to the shore and happy haven find,
4.857: such goal decree—there may he be assailed
4.858: by peoples fierce and bold. A banished man,
4.859: from his Iulus' kisses sundered far,
4.860: may his own eyes see miserably slain
4.861: his kin and kind, and sue for alien arms.
4.862: nor when he basely bows him to receive
4.863: terms of unequal peace, shall he be blest
4.864: with sceptre or with life; but perish there
4.865: before his time, and lie without a grave
4.866: upon the barren sand. For this I pray.
4.867: This dying word is flowing from my heart
4.868: with my spilt blood. And—O ye Tyrians! I
4.869: sting with your hatred all his seed and tribe
4.871: my ashes ask. Betwixt our nations twain,
4.872: No Iove! No truce or amity! Arise,
4.873: Out of my dust, unknown Avenger, rise!
4.874: To harry and lay waste with sword and flame
4.875: those Dardan settlers, and to vex them sore,
4.876: to-day, to-morrow, and as long as power
4.877: is thine to use! My dying curse arrays
4.878: shore against shore and the opposing seas
4.879: in shock of arms with arms. May living foes
4.880: pass down from sire to son insatiate war!”
4.881: She said. From point to point her purpose flew,
4.882: seeking without delay to quench the flame
4.883: of her loathed life. Brief bidding she addressed
4.884: to Barce then, Sichaeus' nurse (her own
4.885: lay dust and ashes in a lonely grave
4.886: beside the Tyrian shore), “Go, nurse, and call
4.887: my sister Anna! Bid her quickly bathe
4.888: her limbs in living water, and procure
4.889: due victims for our expiating fires.
4.890: bid her make haste. Go, bind on thy own brow
4.891: the sacred fillet. For to Stygian Jove
4.892: it is my purpose now to consummate
4.893: the sacrifice ordained, ending my woe,
4.894: and touch with flame the Trojan's funeral pyre.”
4.895: The aged crone to do her bidding ran
4.897: at her own dread design, unstrung with fear,
4.898: her bloodshot eyes wide-rolling, and her cheek
4.899: twitching and fever-spotted, her cold brow
4.900: blanched with approaching death)—sped past the doors
4.901: into the palace garden; there she leaped,
4.902: a frenzied creature, on the lofty pyre
4.903: and drew the Trojan's sword; a gift not asked
4.904: for use like this! When now she saw the garb
4.905: of Ilian fashion, and the nuptial couch
4.906: she knew too well, she lingered yet awhile
4.907: for memory and tears, and, falling prone
4.908: on that cold bed, outpoured a last farewell:
4.909: “Sweet relics! Ever dear when Fate and Heaven
4.910: upon me smiled, receive my parting breath,
4.911: and from my woe set free! My life is done.
4.912: I have accomplished what my lot allowed;
4.913: and now my spirit to the world of death
4.914: in royal honor goes. The founder I
4.915: of yonder noble city, I have seen
4.916: walls at my bidding rise. I was avenged
4.917: for my slain husband: I chastised the crimes
4.918: of our injurious brother. Woe is me!
4.919: Blest had I been, beyond deserving blest,
4.920: if but the Trojan galleys ne'er had moored
4.921: upon my kingdom's bound!”So saying, she pressed
4.922: one last kiss on the couch. “Though for my death
4.923: no vengeance fall, O, give me death!” she cried.
4.924: “O thus! O thus! it is my will to take
4.925: the journey to the dark. From yonder sea
4.926: may his cold Trojan eyes discern the flames
4.927: that make me ashes! Be this cruel death
4.928: his omen as he sails!” She spoke no more.
4.929: But almost ere she ceased, her maidens all
4.930: thronged to obey her cry, and found their Queen
4.931: prone fallen on the sword, the reeking steel
4.932: still in her bloody hands. Shrill clamor flew
4.933: along the lofty halls; wild rumor spread
4.934: through the whole smitten city: Ioud lament,
4.935: groans and the wail of women echoed on
4.936: from roof to roof, and to the dome of air
4.937: the noise of mourning rose. Such were the cry
4.938: if a besieging host should break the walls
4.939: of Carthage or old Tyre, and wrathful flames
4.940: o'er towers of kings and worshipped altars roll.
4.941: Her sister heard. Half in a swoon, she ran
4.942: with trembling steps, where thickest was the throng,
4.943: beating her breast, while with a desperate hand
4.944: she tore at her own face, and called aloud
4.945: upon the dying Queen. “Was it for this
4.946: my own true sister used me with such guile?
4.947: O, was this horrid deed the dire intent
4.948: of altars, Iofty couch, and funeral fires?
4.949: What shall I tell for chiefest of my woes?
4.950: Lost that I am! Why, though in death, cast off
4.951: thy sister from thy heart? Why not invite
4.952: one mortal stroke for both, a single sword,
4.953: one agony together? But these hands
4.954: built up thy pyre; and my voice implored
4.955: the blessing of our gods, who granted me
4.956: that thou shouldst perish thus—and I not know!
4.957: In thy self-slaughter, sister, thou hast slain
4.958: myself, thy people, the grave counsellors
4.959: of Sidon, and yon city thou didst build
4.960: to be thy throne!—Go, fetch me water, there!
4.961: That I may bathe those gashes! If there be
4.962: one hovering breath that stays, let my fond lips
4.963: discover and receive!” So saying, she sprang up
4.964: from stair to stair, and, clasping to her breast
4.965: her sister's dying form, moaned grievously,
4.966: and staunched the dark blood with her garment's fold.
4.967: Vainly would Dido lift her sinking eyes,
4.968: but backward fell, while at her heart the wound
4.969: opened afresh; three times with straining arm
4.970: she rose; three times dropped helpless, her dimmed eyes
4.971: turned skyward, seeking the sweet light of day, —
4.972: which when she saw, she groaned. Great Juno then
4.973: looked down in mercy on that lingering pain
4.974: and labor to depart: from realms divine
4.975: she sent the goddess of the rainbow wing,
4.976: Iris, to set the struggling spirit free
4.977: and loose its fleshly coil. For since the end
4.978: came not by destiny, nor was the doom
4.979: of guilty deed, but of a hapless wight
4.980: to sudden madness stung, ere ripe to die,
4.981: therefore the Queen of Hades had not shorn
4.982: the fair tress from her forehead, nor assigned
4.983: that soul to Stygian dark. So Iris came
4.984: on dewy, saffron pinions down from heaven,
4.985: a thousand colors on her radiant way,
4.986: from the opposing sun. She stayed her flight
4.987: above that pallid brow: “I come with power
4.988: to make this gift to Death. I set thee free
4.989: from thy frail body's bound.” With her right hand
4.990: she cut the tress: then through its every limb
4.991: the sinking form grew cold; the vital breath
4.992: fled forth, departing on the viewless air.

5.1: Meanwhile Aeneas, now well launched away,
5.2: steered forth with all the fleet to open sea,
5.3: on his unswerving course, and ploughed the waves,
5.4: sped by a driving gale; but when his eyes
5.5: looked back on Carthage, they beheld the glare
5.6: of hapless Dido's fire. Not yet was known
5.7: what kindled the wild flames; but that the pang
5.8: of outraged love is cruel, and what the heart
5.9: of desperate woman dares, they knew too well,
5.10: and sad foreboding shook each Trojan soul.
5.11: Soon in mid-sea, beyond all chart of shore,
5.12: when only seas and skies were round their way,
5.13: full in the zenith loomed a purple cloud,
5.14: storm-laden, dark as night, and every wave
5.15: grew black and angry; from his Iofty seat
5.17: What means this host of storms encircling heaven?
5.18: What, Neptune, wilt thou now?” He, having said,
5.19: bade reef and tighten, bend to stronger stroke,
5.20: and slant sail to the wind; then spake again:
5.21: “High-souled Aeneas, not if Jove the King
5.22: gave happy omen, would I have good hope
5.23: of making Italy through yonder sky.
5.24: Athwart our course from clouded evening-star
5.25: rebellious winds run shifting, and the air
5.26: into a cloud-wrack rolls. Against such foes
5.27: too weak our strife and strain! Since now the hand
5.28: of Fortune triumphs, let us where she calls
5.29: obedient go. For near us, I believe,
5.30: lies Eryx' faithful and fraternal shore:
5.31: here are Sicilian havens, if my mind
5.32: of yon familiar stars have knowledge true.”
5.33: then good Aeneas: “For a friendly wind
5.34: long have I sued, and watched thee vainly strive.
5.35: Shift sail! What happier land for me and mine,
5.36: or for our storm-beat ships what safer shore,
5.38: the land whose faithful bosom cherishes
5.39: Anchises' ashes?” Heedful of his word,
5.40: they landward steer, while favoring zephyrs fill
5.41: the spreading sail. On currents swift and strong
5.42: the fleet is wafted, and with thankful soul
5.43: they moor on Sicily's familiar strand.
5.44: From a far hill-top having seen with joy
5.45: the entering ships, and knowing them for friends,
5.46: good King Acestes ran to bid them hail.
5.47: Garbed in rough pelt of Libyan bear was he,
5.48: and javelins he bore, in sylvan guise:
5.49: for him the river-god Crimisus sired
5.50: of Trojan wife. Remembering in his heart
5.51: his ancient blood, he greeted with glad words
5.52: the wanderers returned; bade welcome to
5.53: his rude abundance, and with friendly gifts
5.54: their weariness consoled. The morrow morn,
5.55: soon as the new beams of a golden day
5.56: had banished every star, Aeneas called
5.57: a council of his followers on the shore,
5.58: and from a fair green hillock gave this word:
5.59: “Proud sons of Dardanus, whose lofty line
5.60: none but the gods began! This day fulfils
5.61: the annual cycle of revolving time,
5.62: since the dear relics of my god-like sire
5.63: to earth we gave, and with dark offerings due
5.64: built altars sorrowful. If now I err not,
5.65: this is my day—ye gods have willed it so! —
5.66: for mourning and for praise. Should it befall
5.68: or sailing some Greek sea, or at the walls
5.69: of dire Mycenae, still would I renew
5.71: with thankful rites, and worshipful array,
5.72: at altars rich with gifts. But, lo, we come,
5.73: beyond all hope, where lie the very bones
5.74: of my great sire. Nor did it come to pass
5.75: without divine intent and heavenly power,
5.76: that on these hospitable shores we stand.
5.77: Up, then! For we will make a festal day,
5.78: imploring lucky winds! O, may his spirit
5.79: grant me to build my city, where his shrines
5.81: made in his name! This prince of Trojan line,
5.83: a pair of oxen. To our offerings call
5.84: the powers that bless the altars and the fires
5.85: of our ancestral hearth; and join with these
5.86: the gods of good Acestes. Presently,
5.87: when the ninth dawn shall bring its beam benign
5.88: to mortal men, and show the radiant world,
5.89: or all my Teucrian people I ordain
5.90: a holiday of games; the flying ships
5.91: shall first contend; then swiftest runners try
5.92: a foot-race; after that the champions bold
5.93: who step forth for a cast of javelins,
5.94: or boast the soaring arrow; or fear not
5.95: the boxing-bout, with gauntlet of thick thongs.
5.96: This summons is for all; let all have hope
5.97: to earn some noble palm! And from this hour
5.98: speak but well-boding words, and bind your brows
5.99: with garlands green.” So saying, he twined a wreath
5.100: of his own mother's myrtle-tree, to shade
5.101: his sacred brow; the hero Helymus,
5.102: and King Acestes for his tresses gray,
5.104: and all the warrior youth like emblems wore.
5.105: Then in th' attendant throng conspicuous,
5.106: with thousands at his side, the hero moved
5.107: from place of council to his father's tomb.
5.108: There on the ground he poured libation due,
5.109: two beakers of good wine, of sweet milk two,
5.110: two of the victim's blood—and scattered flowers
5.111: of saddest purple stain, while thus he prayed:
5.112: “Hail, hallowed sire! And hail, ye ashes dear
5.113: of him I vainly saved! O soul and shade
5.114: of my blest father! Heaven to us denied
5.115: to find together that predestined land
5.116: of Italy, or our Ausonian stream
5.117: of Tiber—ah! but where?” He scarce had said,
5.118: when from the central shrine a gliding snake,
5.119: coiled seven-fold in seven spirals wide,
5.120: twined round the tomb and trailed innocuous o'er
5.121: the very altars; his smooth back was flecked
5.122: with green and azure, and his changeful scales
5.123: gleamed golden, as the cloud-born rainbow flings
5.124: its thousand colors from th' opposing sun.
5.125: Aeneas breathless watched the serpent wind
5.126: among the bowls and cups of polished rim,
5.127: tasting the sacred feast; where, having fed,
5.128: back to the tomb all harmless it withdrew.
5.129: Then with new zeal his sacrifice he brings
5.130: in honor of his sire; for he must deem
5.131: that serpent the kind genius of the place,
5.132: or of his very father's present shade
5.133: some creature ministrant. Two lambs he slew,
5.134: the wonted way, two swine, and, sable-hued,
5.135: the yoke of bulls; from shallow bowl he poured
5.136: libation of the grape, and called aloud
5.137: on great Anchises' spirit, and his shade,
5.138: from Acheron set free. Then all the throng,
5.139: each from his separate store, heap up the shrines
5.140: with victims slain; some range in order fair
5.141: the brazen cauldrons; or along the grass,
5.142: scattered at ease, hold o'er the embers bright
5.143: the spitted flesh and roast it in the flames.
5.144: Arrived the wished-for day; through cloudless sky
5.145: the coursers of the Sun's bright-beaming car
5.146: bore upward the ninth morn. The neighboring folk
5.147: thronged eager to the shore; some hoped to see
5.148: Aeneas and his warriors, others fain
5.149: would their own prowess prove in bout and game.
5.150: Conspicuous lie the rewards, ranged in sight
5.151: in the mid-circus; wreaths of laurel green,
5.152: the honored tripod, coronals of palm
5.153: for conquerors' brows, accoutrements of war,
5.154: rare robes of purple stain, and generous weight
5.155: of silver and of gold. The trumpet's call
5.156: proclaimed from lofty mound the opening games.
5.157: First, side by side, with sturdy, rival oars,
5.158: four noble galleys, pride of all the fleet,
5.159: come forward to contend. The straining crew
5.160: of Mnestheus bring his speedy Pristis on, —
5.161: Mnestheus in Italy erelong the sire
