6.692: Toward this forlorn abode of night and cloud?”
6.693: While thus they talked, the crimsoned car of Morn
6.694: Had wheeled beyond the midmost point of heaven,
6.695: On her ethereal road. The princely pair
6.696: Had wasted thus the whole brief gift of hours;
6.697: But Sibyl spoke the warning: “Night speeds by,
6.698: And we, Aeneas, lose it in lamenting.
6.699: Here comes the place where cleaves our way in twain.
6.700: Thy road, the right, toward Pluto's dwelling goes,
6.701: And leads us to Elysium. But the left
6.702: Speeds sinful souls to doom, and is their path
6.704: Cried out: “0 priestess, be not wroth with us!
6.705: Back to the ranks with yonder ghosts I go.
6.706: 0 glory of my race, pass on! Thy lot
6.707: Be happier than mine!” He spoke, and fled.
6.708: Aeneas straightway by the leftward cliff
6.709: Beheld a spreading rampart, high begirt
6.710: With triple wall, and circling round it ran
6.711: A raging river of swift floods of flame,
6.713: Loud-thundering rocks. A mighty gate is there
6.714: Columned in adamant; no human power,
6.715: Nor even the gods, against this gate prevail.
6.716: Tall tower of steel it has; and seated there
6.718: Sleepless forever, guards the entering way.
6.719: Hence groans are heard, fierce cracks of lash and scourge,
6.720: Loud-clanking iron links and trailing chains.
6.722: o'erwhelmed at such uproar. “0 virgin, say
6.723: What shapes of guilt are these? What penal woe
6.724: Harries them thus? What wailing smites the air?”
6.725: To whom the Sibyl, “Far-famed prince of Troy,
6.726: The feet of innocence may never pass
6.727: Into this house of sin. But Hecate,
6.728: When o'er th' Avernian groves she gave me power,
6.729: Taught me what penalties the gods decree,
6.730: And showed me all. There Cretan Rhadamanth
6.731: His kingdom keeps, and from unpitying throne
6.732: Chastises and lays bare the secret sins
6.733: Of mortals who, exulting in vain guile,
6.734: Elude till death, their expiation due.
6.735: There, armed forever with her vengeful scourge,
6.737: The guilty swarm pursues; in her left hand
6.738: She lifts her angered serpents, while she calls
6.739: A troop of sister-furies fierce as she.
6.740: Then, grating loud on hinge of sickening sound,
6.741: Hell's portals open wide. 0, dost thou see
6.742: What sentinel upon that threshold sits,
6.743: What shapes of fear keep guard upon that gloom?
6.744: Far, far within the dragon Hydra broods
6.745: With half a hundred mouths, gaping and black;
6.746: And Tartarus slopes downward to the dark
6.747: Twice the whole space that in the realms of light
6.748: Th' Olympian heaven above our earth aspires. —
6.749: Here Earth's first offspring, the Titanic brood,
6.750: Roll lightning-blasted in the gulf profound;
6.752: Came on my view; their hands made stroke at Heaven
6.753: And strove to thrust Jove from his seat on high.
6.754: I saw Salmoneus his dread stripes endure,
6.755: Who dared to counterfeit Olympian thunder
6.756: And Jove's own fire. In chariot of four steeds,
6.758: Through throngs of Greeks, o'er Elis' sacred way,
6.759: Demanding worship as a god. 0 fool!
6.760: To mock the storm's inimitable flash—
6.761: With crash of hoofs and roll of brazen wheel!
6.762: But mightiest Jove from rampart of thick cloud
6.763: Hurled his own shaft, no flickering, mortal flame,
6.764: And in vast whirl of tempest laid him low.
6.765: Next unto these, on Tityos I looked,
6.766: Child of old Earth, whose womb all creatures bears:
6.767: Stretched o'er nine roods he lies; a vulture huge
6.768: Tears with hooked beak at his immortal side,
6.769: Or deep in entrails ever rife with pain
6.770: Gropes for a feast, making his haunt and home
6.771: In the great Titan bosom; nor will give
6.772: To ever new-born flesh surcease of woe.
6.774: The Lapithae, above whose impious brows
6.775: A crag of flint hangs quaking to its fall,
6.776: As if just toppling down, while couches proud,
6.777: Propped upon golden pillars, bid them feast
6.778: In royal glory: but beside them lies
6.779: The eldest of the Furies, whose dread hands
6.780: Thrust from the feast away, and wave aloft
6.781: A flashing firebrand, with shrieks of woe.
6.782: Here in a prison-house awaiting doom
6.783: Are men who hated, long as life endured,
6.784: Their brothers, or maltreated their gray sires,
6.785: Or tricked a humble friend; the men who grasped
6.786: At hoarded riches, with their kith and kin
6.788: Here slain adulterers be; and men who dared
6.789: To fight in unjust cause, and break all faith
6.790: With their own lawful lords. Seek not to know
6.791: What forms of woe they feel, what fateful shape
6.792: Of retribution hath o'erwhelmed them there.
6.793: Some roll huge boulders up; some hang on wheels,
6.794: Lashed to the whirling spokes; in his sad seat
6.795: Theseus is sitting, nevermore to rise;
6.797: In warning through the darkness, calling loud,
6.798: ‘0, ere too late, learn justice and fear God!’
6.799: Yon traitor sold his country, and for gold
6.800: Enchained her to a tyrant, trafficking
6.801: In laws, for bribes enacted or made void;
6.803: His daughter for a wife in lawless bonds.
6.804: All ventured some unclean, prodigious crime;
6.805: And what they dared, achieved. I could not tell,
6.806: Not with a hundred mouths, a hundred tongues,
6.807: Or iron voice, their divers shapes of sin,
6.808: Nor call by name the myriad pangs they bear.”
6.810: “Now up and on!” she cried. “Thy task fulfil!
6.811: We must make speed. Behold yon arching doors
6.812: Yon walls in furnace of the Cyclops forged!
6.813: 'T is there we are commanded to lay down
6.814: Th' appointed offering.” So, side by side,
6.815: Swift through the intervening dark they strode,
6.816: And, drawing near the portal-arch, made pause.
6.817: Aeneas, taking station at the door,
6.818: Pure, lustral waters o'er his body threw,
6.819: And hung for garland there the Golden Bough.
6.820: Now, every rite fulfilled, and tribute due
6.821: Paid to the sovereign power of Proserpine,
6.822: At last within a land delectable
6.823: Their journey lay, through pleasurable bowers
6.824: Of groves where all is joy,—a blest abode!
6.825: An ampler sky its roseate light bestows
6.826: On that bright land, which sees the cloudless beam
6.827: Of suns and planets to our earth unknown.
6.828: On smooth green lawns, contending limb with limb,
6.829: Immortal athletes play, and wrestle long
6.830: 'gainst mate or rival on the tawny sand;
6.831: With sounding footsteps and ecstatic song,
6.832: Some thread the dance divine: among them moves
6.833: The bard of Thrace, in flowing vesture clad,
6.835: Who sweeps the numbered strings with changeful hand,
6.836: Or smites with ivory point his golden lyre.
6.837: Here Trojans be of eldest, noblest race,
6.838: Great-hearted heroes, born in happier times,
6.840: Illustrious builders of the Trojan town.
6.841: Their arms and shadowy chariots he views,
6.842: And lances fixed in earth, while through the fields
6.843: Their steeds without a bridle graze at will.
6.844: For if in life their darling passion ran
6.845: To chariots, arms, or glossy-coated steeds,
6.846: The self-same joy, though in their graves, they feel.
6.847: Lo! on the left and right at feast reclined
6.848: Are other blessed souls, whose chorus sings
6.849: Victorious paeans on the fragrant air
6.850: Of laurel groves; and hence to earth outpours
6.852: Here dwell the brave who for their native land
6.853: Fell wounded on the field; here holy priests
6.854: Who kept them undefiled their mortal day;
6.855: And poets, of whom the true-inspired song
6.856: Deserved Apollo's name; and all who found
6.857: New arts, to make man's life more blest or fair;
6.858: Yea! here dwell all those dead whose deeds bequeath
6.859: Deserved and grateful memory to their kind.
6.860: And each bright brow a snow-white fillet wears.
6.861: Unto this host the Sibyl turned, and hailed
6.862: Musaeus, midmost of a numerous throng,
6.863: Who towered o'er his peers a shoulder higher:
6.865: Declare what dwelling or what region holds
6.866: Anchises, for whose sake we twain essayed
6.867: Yon passage over the wide streams of hell.”
6.868: And briefly thus the hero made reply:
6.869: “No fixed abode is ours. In shadowy groves
6.870: We make our home, or meadows fresh and fair,
6.871: With streams whose flowery banks our couches be.
6.872: But you, if thitherward your wishes turn,
6.873: Climb yonder hill, where I your path may show.”
6.874: So saying, he strode forth and led them on,
6.875: Till from that vantage they had prospect fair
6.876: Of a wide, shining land; thence wending down,
6.877: They left the height they trod;for far below
6.878: Father Anchises in a pleasant vale
6.879: Stood pondering, while his eyes and thought surveyed
6.880: A host of prisoned spirits, who there abode
6.882: And musing he reviewed the legions bright
6.883: Of his own progeny and offspring proud—
6.884: Their fates and fortunes, virtues and great deeds.
6.885: Soon he discerned Aeneas drawing nigh
6.886: o'er the green slope, and, lifting both his hands
6.887: In eager welcome, spread them swiftly forth.
6.888: Tears from his eyelids rained, and thus he spoke:
6.889: “Art here at last? Hath thy well-proven love
6.890: Of me thy sire achieved yon arduous way?
6.891: Will Heaven, beloved son, once more allow
6.892: That eye to eye we look? and shall I hear
6.893: Thy kindred accent mingling with my own?
6.894: I cherished long this hope. My prophet-soul
6.895: Numbered the lapse of days, nor did my thought
6.896: Deceive. 0, o'er what lands and seas wast driven
6.897: To this embrace! What perils manifold
6.898: Assailed thee, 0 my son, on every side!
6.899: How long I trembled, lest that Libyan throne
6.903: Came oft upon my vision, and impelled
6.904: My journey hitherward. Our fleet of ships
6.905: Lies safe at anchor in the Tuscan seas.
6.906: Come, clasp my hand! Come, father, I implore,
6.907: And heart to heart this fond embrace receive!”
6.908: So speaking, all his eyes suffused with tears;
6.909: Thrice would his arms in vain that shape enfold.
6.910: Thrice from the touch of hand the vision fled,
6.911: Like wafted winds or likest hovering dreams.
6.912: After these things Aeneas was aware
6.913: Of solemn groves in one deep, distant vale,
6.914: Where trees were whispering, and forever flowed
6.915: The river Lethe, through its land of calm.
6.916: Nations unnumbered roved and haunted there:
6.917: As when, upon a windless summer morn,
6.918: The bees afield among the rainbow flowers
6.919: Alight and sip, or round the lilies pure
6.920: Pour forth in busy swarm, while far diffused
6.921: Their murmured songs from all the meadows rise.
6.922: Aeneas in amaze the wonder views,
6.923: And fearfully inquires of whence and why;
6.924: What yonder rivers be; what people press,
6.925: Line after line, on those dim shores along.
6.928: Here, at the river Lethe's wave, they quaff
6.930: Of these I shall discourse, and to thy soul
6.931: Make visible the number and array
6.932: Of my posterity; so shall thy heart
6.933: In Italy, thy new-found home, rejoice.”
6.935: That from this region souls exalted rise
6.936: To upper air, and shall once more return
6.937: To cumbering flesh? 0, wherefore do they feel,
6.938: Unhappy ones, such fatal lust to live?”
6.939: “I speak, my son, nor make thee longer doubt,”
6.940: Anchises said, and thus the truth set forth,
6.941: In ordered words from point to point unfolding:
6.942: “Know first that heaven and earth and ocean's plain,
6.943: The moon's bright orb, and stars of Titan birth
6.944: Are nourished by one Life; one primal Mind,
6.945: Immingled with the vast and general frame,
6.946: Fills every part and stirs the mighty whole.
6.947: Thence man and beast, thence creatures of the air,
6.948: And all the swarming monsters that be found
6.949: Beneath the level of the marbled sea;
6.950: A fiery virtue, a celestial power,
6.951: Their native seeds retain; but bodies vile,
6.952: With limbs of clay and members born to die,
6.953: Encumber and o'ercloud; whence also spring
6.954: Terrors and passions, suffering and joy;
6.955: For from deep darkness and captivity
6.956: All gaze but blindly on the radiant world.
6.957: Nor when to life's last beam they bid farewell
6.958: May sufferers cease from pain, nor quite be freed
6.959: From all their fleshly plagues; but by fixed law,
6.960: The strange, inveterate taint works deeply in.
6.961: For this, the chastisement of evils past
6.962: Is suffered here, and full requital paid.
6.963: Some hang on high, outstretched to viewless winds;
6.964: For some their sin's contagion must be purged
6.965: In vast ablution of deep-rolling seas,
6.966: Or burned away in fire. Each man receives
6.967: His ghostly portion in the world of dark;
6.968: But thence to realms Elysian we go free,
6.969: Where for a few these seats of bliss abide,
6.970: Till time's long lapse a perfect orb fulfils,
6.971: And takes all taint away, restoring so
6.972: The pure, ethereal soul's first virgin fire.
6.973: At last, when the millennial aeon strikes,
6.974: God calls them forth to yon Lethaean stream,
6.975: In numerous host, that thence, oblivious all,
6.976: They may behold once more the vaulted sky,
6.977: And willingly to shapes of flesh return.”
6.978: So spoke Anchises; then led forth his son,
6.979: The Sibyl with him, to the assembled shades
6.980: (A voiceful throng), and on a lofty mound
6.981: His station took, whence plainly could be seen
6.982: The long procession, and each face descried.
6.983: “Hark now! for of the glories I will tell
6.984: That wait our Dardan blood; of our sons' sons
6.985: Begot upon the old Italian breed,
6.986: Who shall be mighty spirits, and prolong
6.987: Our names, their heritage. I will unfold
6.988: The story, and reveal the destined years.
6.989: Yon princeling, thou beholdest leaning there
6.990: Upon a royal lance, shall next emerge
6.991: Into the realms of day. He is the first
6.992: Of half-Italian strain, the last-born heir
6.993: To thine old age by fair Lavinia given,
6.994: Called Silvius, a royal Alban name
6.995: (Of sylvan birth and sylvan nurture he),
6.996: A king himself and sire of kings to come,
6.997: By whom our race in Alba Longa reign.
6.998: Next Procas stands, our Trojan people's boast;
6.999: Capys and Numitor, and, named like thee,
6.1001: For faithful honor and for deeds of war,
6.1002: When he ascends at last his Alban throne.
6.1003: Behold what warrior youth they be! How strong
6.1004: Their goodly limbs! Above their shaded brows
6.1005: The civic oak they wear! For thee they build
6.1006: Nomentum, and the walls of Gabii,
6.1007: Fidena too, and on the mountains pile
6.1010: Such be the names the nameless lands shall bear.
6.1011: See, in that line of sires the son of Mars,
6.1012: Great Romulus, of Ilian mother born,
6.1013: From far-descended line of Trojan kings!
6.1014: See from his helm the double crest uprear,
6.1015: While his celestial father in his mien
6.1016: Shows forth his birth divine! Of him, my son,
6.1017: Great Rome shall rise, and, favored of his star,
6.1018: Have power world-wide, and men of godlike mind.
6.1019: She clasps her seven hills in single wall,
6.1020: Proud mother of the brave! So Cybele,
6.1022: On through the Phrygian kingdoms speeds her car,
6.1023: Exulting in her hundred sons divine,
6.1024: All numbered with the gods, all throned on high.
6.1025: “Let now thy visionary glance look long
6.1026: On this thy race, these Romans that be thine.
6.1027: Here Caesar, of Iulus' glorious seed,
6.1028: Behold ascending to the world of light!
6.1029: Behold, at last, that man, for this is he,
6.1030: So oft unto thy listening ears foretold,
6.1032: He brings a golden age; he shall restore
6.1033: Old Saturn's sceptre to our Latin land,
6.1034: And o'er remotest Garamant and Ind
6.1035: His sway extend; the fair dominion
6.1036: outruns th' horizon planets, yea, beyond
6.1037: The sun's bright path, where Atlas' shoulder bears
6.1038: Yon dome of heaven set thick with burning stars.
6.1039: Against his coming the far Caspian shores
6.1040: Break forth in oracles; the Maeotian land
6.1041: Trembles, and all the seven-fold mouths of Nile.
6.1042: Not o'er domain so wide Alcides passed,
6.1043: Although the brazen-footed doe he slew
6.1044: And stilled the groves of Erymanth, and bade
6.1045: The beast of Lerna at his arrows quail.
6.1046: Nor half so far triumphant Baechus drove,
6.1047: With vine-entwisted reins, his frolic team
6.1048: Of tigers from the tall-topped Indian hill.
6.1049: “Still do we doubt if heroes' deeds can fill
6.1050: A realm so wide? Shall craven fear constrain
6.1051: Thee or thy people from Ausonia's shore?
6.1052: Look, who is he I may discern from far
6.1053: By olive-branch and holy emblems known?
6.1054: His flowing locks and hoary beard, behold!
6.1055: Fit for a Roman king! By hallowed laws
6.1056: He shall found Rome anew—from mean estate
6.1057: In lowly Cures led to mightier sway.
6.1058: But after him arises one whose reign
6.1059: Shall wake the land from slumber: Tullus then
6.1060: Shall stir slack chiefs to battle, rallying
6.1061: His hosts which had forgot what triumphs be.
6.1062: Him boastful Ancus follows hard upon,
6.1063: o'erflushed with his light people's windy praise.
6.1064: Wilt thou see Tarquins now? And haughty hand
6.1065: Of vengeful Brutus seize the signs of power?
6.1066: He first the consul's name shall take; he first
6.1068: When his own sons in rash rebellion join,
6.1069: The father and the judge shall sentence give
6.1071: Howe'er the age to come the story tell,
6.1072: 't will bless such love of honor and of Rome.
6.1073: See Decius, sire and son, the Drusi, see!
6.1074: Behold Torquatus with his axe! Look where
6.1075: Camillus brings the Gallic standards home!
6.1076: “But who are these in glorious armor clad
6.1077: And equal power? In this dark world of cloud
6.1078: Their souls in concord move;—but woe is me!
6.1079: What duel 'twixt them breaks, when by and by
6.1080: The light of life is theirs, and forth they call
6.1081: Their long-embattled lines to carnage dire!
6.1082: Allied by nuptial truce, the sire descends
6.1083: From Alpine rampart and that castled cliff,
6.1084: Monoecus by the sea; the son arrays
6.1085: His hostile legions in the lands of morn.
6.1086: Forbear, my children! School not your great souls
6.1087: In such vast wars, nor turn your giant strength
6.1088: Against the bowels of your native land!
6.1089: But be thou first, 0 first in mercy! thou
6.1090: Who art of birth Olympian! Fling away
6.1091: Thy glorious sword, mine offspring and mine heir!
6.1092: “Yonder is one whose chariot shall ascend
6.1093: The laurelled Capitolian steep; he rides
6.1094: In glory o'er Achaea's hosts laid low,
6.1095: And Corinth overthrown. There, too, is he
6.1096: Who shall uproot proud Argos and the towers
6.1098: Even of Aeacus, the warrior seed
6.1099: Of Peleus' son; such vengeance shall be wrought
6.1100: For Troy's slain sires, and violated shrines!
6.1101: “Or who could fail great Cato's name to tell?
6.1102: Or, Cossus, thine? or in oblivion leave
6.1103: The sons of Gracchus? or the Scipios,
6.1104: Twin thunderbolts of war, and Libya's bane?
6.1105: Or, more than kingly in his mean abode,
6.1106: Fabricius? or Serranus at the plough?
6.1107: Ye Fabii, how far would ye prolong
6.1108: My weary praise? But see! 'T is Maximus,
6.1109: Who by wise waiting saves his native land.
6.1110: “Let others melt and mould the breathing bronze
6.1111: To forms more fair,—aye! out of marble bring
6.1112: Features that live; let them plead causes well;
6.1113: Or trace with pointed wand the cycled heaven,
6.1114: And hail the constellations as they rise;
6.1115: But thou, 0 Roman, learn with sovereign sway
6.1116: To rule the nations. Thy great art shall be
6.1117: To keep the world in lasting peace, to spare
6.1118: humbled foe, and crush to earth the proud.”
6.1119: So did Anchises speak, then, after pause,
6.1120: Thus to their wondering ears his word prolonged:
6.1122: In lifted triumph through his warriors move!
6.1123: The Roman power in tumultuous days
6.1124: He shall establish; he rides forth to quell
6.1125: Afric and rebel Gaul; and to the shrine
6.1126: Of Romulus the third-won trophy brings.”
6.1127: Then spoke Aeneas, for he now could see
6.1128: A beauteous youth in glittering dress of war,
6.1129: Though of sad forehead and down-dropping eyes:
6.1130: “Say, father, who attends the prince? a son?
6.1131: Or of his greatness some remoter heir?
6.1132: How his friends praise him, and how matchless he!
6.1133: But mournful night Tests darkly o'er his brow.”
6.1134: With brimming eyes Anchises answer gave:
6.1135: “Ask not, 0 son, what heavy weight of woe
6.1136: Thy race shall bear, when fate shall just reveal
6.1137: This vision to the world, then yield no more.
6.1138: 0 gods above, too glorious did ye deem
6.1139: The seed of Rome, had this one gift been sure?
6.1141: Arises from the field of Mars, and strikes
6.1142: The city's heart. 0 Father Tiber, see
6.1143: What pomp of sorrow near the new-made tomb
6.1144: Beside thy fleeting stream! What Ilian youth
6.1145: Shall e'er his Latin kindred so advance
6.1146: In hope of glory? When shall the proud land
6.1147: Of Romulus of such a nursling boast?
6.1148: Ah, woe' is me! 0 loyal heart and true!
6.1149: 0 brave, right arm invincible! What foe
6.1150: Had 'scaped his onset in the shock of arms,
6.1151: Whether on foot he strode, or if he spurred
6.1152: The hot flanks of his war-horse flecked with foam?
6.1153: 0 lost, lamented child! If thou evade
6.1154: Thy evil star, Marcellus thou shalt be.
6.1155: 0 bring me lilies! Bring with liberal hand!
6.1156: Sad purple blossoms let me throw—the shade
6.1157: Of my own kin to honor, heaping high
6.1158: My gifts upon his grave! So let me pay
6.1161: Through spacious fields of air, they wander free,
6.1162: Witnessing all; Anchises guides his son
6.1163: From point to point, and quickens in his mind
6.1164: Hunger for future fame. Of wars he tells
6.1165: Soon imminent; of fair Laurentum's tribes;
6.1166: Of King Latinus' town; and shows what way
6.1167: Each task and hardship to prevent, or bear.
6.1168: Now Sleep has portals twain, whereof the one
6.1169: Is horn, they say, and easy exit gives
6.1170: To visions true; the other, gleaming white
6.1172: To people night with unsubstantial dreams.
6.1173: Here now Anchises bids his son farewell;
6.1174: And with Sibylla, his companion sage,
6.1175: Up through that ivory portal lets him rise.
6.1176: Back to his fleet and his dear comrades all
6.1177: Aeneas hastes.Then hold they their straight course
6.1178: Into Caieta's bay. An anchor holds
6.1179: Each lofty prow; the sterns stand firm on shore.

7.1: One more immortal name thy death bequeathed,
7.2: Nurse of Aeneas, to Italian shores,
7.3: Caieta; there thy honor hath a home;
7.4: Thy bones a name: and on Hesperia's breast
7.6: The tribute of sepulchral vows had paid
7.7: Beside the funeral mound, and o'er the seas
7.8: Stillness had fallen, he flung forth his sails,
7.9: And leaving port pursued his destined way.
7.10: Freshly the night-winds breathe; the cloudless moon
7.11: Outpours upon his path unstinted beam,
7.12: And with far-trembling glory smites the sea.
7.13: Close to the lands of Circe soon they fare,
7.14: Where the Sun's golden daughter in far groves
7.15: Sounds forth her ceaseless song; her lofty hall
7.16: Is fragrant every night with flaring brands
7.17: Of cedar, giving light the while she weaves
7.18: With shrill-voiced shuttle at her linens fine.
7.19: From hence are heard the loud lament and wrath
7.20: Of lions, rebels to their linked chains
7.21: And roaring all night long; great bristly boars
7.22: And herded bears, in pinfold closely kept,
7.23: Rage horribly, and monster-wolves make moan;
7.24: Whom the dread goddess with foul juices strong
7.25: From forms of men drove forth, and bade to wear
7.26: the mouths and maws of beasts in Circe's thrall.
7.27: But lest the sacred Trojans should endure
7.28: such prodigy of doom, or anchor there
7.29: on that destroying shore, kind Neptune filled
7.30: their sails with winds of power, and sped them on
7.31: in safety past the perils of that sea.
7.32: Now morning flushed the wave, and saffron-garbed
7.33: Aurora from her rose-red chariot beamed
7.34: in highest heaven; the sea-winds ceased to stir;
7.35: a sudden calm possessed the air, and tides
7.36: of marble smoothness met the laboring oar.
7.37: Then, gazing from the deep, Aeneas saw
7.38: a stretch of groves, whence Tiber's smiling stream,
7.39: its tumbling current rich with yellow sands,
7.40: burst seaward forth: around it and above
7.41: shore-haunting birds of varied voice and plume
7.42: flattered the sky with song, and, circling far
7.43: o'er river-bed and grove, took joyful wing.
7.44: Thither to landward now his ships he steered,
7.45: and sailed, high-hearted, up the shadowy stream.
7.46: Hail, Erato! while olden kings and thrones
7.47: and all their sequent story I unfold!
7.48: How Latium's honor stood, when alien ships
7.49: brought war to Italy, and from what cause
7.50: the primal conflict sprang, O goddess, breathe
7.51: upon thy bard in song. Dread wars I tell,
7.52: array of battle, and high-hearted kings
7.53: thrust forth to perish, when Etruria's host
7.54: and all Hesperia gathered to the fray.
7.55: Events of grander march impel my song,
7.56: and loftier task I try. Latinus, then
7.57: an aged king, held long-accepted sway
7.58: o'er tranquil vales and towns. He was the son
7.59: of Faunus, so the legend tells, who wed
7.60: the nymph Marica of Laurentian stem.
7.61: Picus was Faunus' father, whence the line
7.62: to Saturn's Ioins ascends. O heavenly sire,
7.63: from thee the stem began! But Fate had given
7.64: to King Latinus' body no heirs male:
7.65: for taken in the dawning of his day
7.66: his only son had been; and now his home
7.67: and spacious palace one sole daughter kept,
7.68: who was grown ripe to wed and of full age
7.69: to take a husband. Many suitors tried
7.70: from all Ausonia and Latium's bounds;
7.71: but comeliest in all their princely throng
7.72: came Turnus, of a line of mighty sires.
7.73: Him the queen mother chiefly loved, and yearned
7.74: to call him soon her son. But omens dire
7.75: and menaces from Heaven withstood her will.
7.76: A laurel-tree grew in the royal close,
7.77: of sacred leaf and venerated age,
7.78: which, when he builded there his wall and tower,
7.79: Father Latinus found, and hallowed it
7.80: to Phoebus' grace and power, wherefrom the name
7.81: Laurentian, which his realm and people bear.
7.82: Unto this tree-top, wonderful to tell,
7.83: came hosts of bees, with audible acclaim
7.84: voyaging the stream of air, and seized a place
7.85: on the proud, pointing crest, where the swift swarm,
7.87: swung from the leafy bough. “Behold, there comes,”
7.88: the prophet cried, “a husband from afar!
7.89: To the same region by the self-same path
7.90: behold an arm'd host taking lordly sway
7.91: upon our city's crown!” Soon after this,
7.92: when, coming to the shrine with torches pure,
7.93: Lavinia kindled at her father's side
7.94: the sacrifice, swift seemed the flame to burn
7.95: along her flowing hair—O sight of woe!
7.96: Over her broidered snood it sparkling flew,
7.97: lighting her queenly tresses and her crown
7.98: of jewels rare: then, wrapt in flaming cloud,
7.99: from hall to hall the fire-god's gift she flung.
7.100: This omen dread and wonder terrible
7.101: was rumored far: for prophet-voices told
7.102: bright honors on the virgin's head to fall
7.103: by Fate's decree, but on her people, war.
7.104: The King, sore troubled by these portents, sought
7.105: oracular wisdom of his sacred sire,
7.106: Faunus, the fate-revealer, where the groves
7.107: stretch under high Albunea, and her stream
7.108: roars from its haunted well, exhaling through
7.109: vast, gloomful woods its pestilential air.
7.110: Here all Oenotria's tribes ask oracles
7.111: in dark and doubtful days: here, when the priest
7.112: has brought his gifts, and in the night so still,
7.113: couched on spread fleeces of the offered flock,
7.115: a host of flitting shapes he sees, and hears
7.116: voices that come and go: with gods he holds
7.117: high converse, or in deep Avernian gloom
7.118: parleys with Acheron. Thither drew near
7.120: Obedient to the olden rite, he slew
7.121: a hundred fleecy sheep, and pillowed lay
7.122: upon their outstretched skins. Straightway a voice
7.123: out of the lofty forest met his prayer.
7.124: “Seek not in wedlock with a Latin lord
7.125: to join thy daughter, O my son and seed!
7.126: Beware this purposed marriage! There shall come
7.127: sons from afar, whose blood shall bear our name
7.128: starward; the children of their mighty loins,
7.129: as far as eve and morn enfold the seas,
7.130: shall see a subject world beneath their feet
7.132: Latinus hid not. But on restless wing
7.133: rumor had spread it, when the men of Troy
7.134: along the river-bank of mounded green
7.135: their fleet made fast.Aeneas and his chiefs,
7.136: with fair Iulus, under spreading boughs
7.137: of one great tree made resting-place, and set
7.138: the banquet on. Thin loaves of altar-bread
7.139: along the sward to bear their meats were laid
7.140: (such was the will of Jove), and wilding fruits
7.141: rose heaping high, with Ceres' gift below.
7.142: Soon, all things else devoured, their hunger turned
7.143: to taste the scanty bread, which they attacked
7.144: with tooth and nail audacious, and consumed
7.145: both round and square of that predestined leaven.
7.146: “Look, how we eat our tables even!” cried
7.147: Iulus, in a jest. Such was the word
7.148: which bade their burdens fall. From his boy's lip
7.149: the father caught this utterance of Fate,
7.150: silent with wonder at the ways of Heaven;
7.151: then swift he spoke: “Hail! O my destined shore,
7.153: Here is our home, our country here! This day
7.155: by Sire Anchises given: ‘My son,’ said he,
7.156: ‘When hunger in strange lands shall bid devour
7.157: the tables of thy banquet gone, then hope
7.158: for home, though weary, and take thought to build
7.159: a dwelling and a battlement.’ Behold!
7.160: This was our fated hunger! This last proof
7.161: will end our evil days. Up, then! For now
7.162: by morning's joyful beam we will explore
7.163: what men, what cities, in this region be,
7.164: and, leaving ship, our several errands ply.
7.165: Your gift to Jove outpour! Make thankful prayer
7.166: unto Anchises' shade! To this our feast
7.167: bring back the flowing wine!” Thereat he bound
7.168: his forehead with green garland, calling loud
7.169: upon the Genius of that place, and Earth,
7.170: eldest of names divine; the Nymphs he called,
7.171: and river-gods unknown; his voice invoked
7.172: the night, the omen-stars through night that roll.
7.173: Jove, Ida's child, and Phrygia's fertile Queen:
7.174: he called his mother from Olympian skies,
7.175: and sire from Erebus. Lo, o'er his head
7.177: in thunder spoke, and, with effulgent ray
7.178: from his ethereal tract outreaching far,
7.180: Swift, through the concourse of the Trojans, spread
7.181: news of the day at hand when they should build
7.182: their destined walls. So, with rejoicing heart
7.183: at such vast omen, they set forth a feast
7.185: the wine-cups fair with many a garland crowned.
7.186: Soon as the morrow with the lamp of dawn
7.187: looked o'er the world, they took their separate ways,
7.188: exploring shore and towns; here spread the pools
7.189: and fountain of Numicius; here they see
7.190: the river Tiber, where bold Latins dwell.
7.191: Anchises' son chose out from his brave band
7.192: a hundred envoys, bidding them depart
7.193: to the King's sacred city, each enwreathed
7.194: with Pallas' silver leaf; and gifts they bear
7.195: to plead for peace and friendship at his throne.
7.196: While on this errand their swift steps are sped,
7.197: Aeneas, by a shallow moat and small,
7.198: his future city shows, breaks ground, and girds
7.199: with mound and breastwork like a camp of war
7.200: the Trojans' first abode. Soon, making way
7.201: to where the Latin citadel uprose,
7.202: the envoys scanned the battlements, and paused
7.203: beneath its wall. Outside the city gates
7.204: fair youths and striplings in life's early bloom
7.205: course with swift steeds, or steer through dusty cloud
7.206: the whirling chariot, or stretch stout bows,
7.207: or hurl the seasoned javelin, or strive
7.208: in boxing-bout and foot-race: one of these
7.209: made haste on horseback to the aged King,
7.210: with tidings of a stranger company
7.211: in foreign garb approaching. The good King
7.212: bade call them to his house, and took his seat
7.213: in mid-court on his high, ancestral throne.
7.214: Large and majestical the castle rose:
7.215: a hundred columns lifted it in air
7.216: upon the city's crown—the royal keep
7.217: of Picus of Laurentum; round it lay
7.218: deep, gloomy woods by olden worship blest.
7.219: Here kings took sceptre and the fasces proud
7.220: with omens fair; the selfsame sacred place
7.221: was senate-house and temple; here was found
7.222: a hall for hallowed feasting, where a ram
7.223: was offered up, and at long banquet-boards
7.224: the nation's fathers sat in due array.
7.225: Here ranged ancestral statues roughly hewn
7.227: Father Sabinus, planter of the vine,
7.228: a curving sickle in his sculptured hand;
7.229: gray-bearded Saturn; and the double brow
7.230: of Janus' head; and other sires and kings
7.231: were wardens of the door, with many a chief
7.232: wounded in battle for his native land.
7.233: Trophies of arms in goodly order hung
7.234: along the columns: chariots of war
7.235: from foeman taken, axes of round blade,
7.236: plumed helmets, bolts and barriers of steel
7.237: from city-gates, shields, spears, and beaks of bronze
7.238: from captured galleys by the conqueror torn.
7.240: girt in scant shift, and bearing on his left
7.241: the sacred oval shield, appeared enthroned
7.242: Picus, breaker of horses, whom his bride,
7.243: enamoured Circe, smote with golden wand,
7.244: and, raining o'er him potent poison-dew,
7.245: changed to a bird of pied and dappled wings.
7.246: In such a temple of his gods did Sire
7.248: welcome the Trojans to his halls, and thus
7.249: with brow serene gave greeting as they came:
7.250: “O sons of Dardanus, think not unknown
7.251: your lineage and city! Rumored far
7.252: your venturous voyage has been. What seek ye here?
7.253: What cause, what quest, has brought your barks and you
7.254: o'er the blue waters to Ausonia's hills?
7.255: What way uncharted, or wild stress of storm,
7.256: or what that sailors suffer in mid-sea,
7.257: unto this river bank and haven bore?
7.258: Doubt not our welcome! We of Latin land
7.259: are Saturn's sons, whose equitable minds,
7.260: not chained by statute or compulsion, keep
7.261: in freedom what the god's good custom gave.
7.262: Now I bethink me our Ausonian seers
7.263: have dark, dim lore that 't was this land gave birth
7.264: to Dardanus, who after took his way
7.265: through Phrygian Ida's towns and Samothrace.
7.266: Once out of Tuscan Corythus he fared;
7.267: but now in golden house among the stars
7.268: he has a throne, and by his altars blest
7.269: adds to the number of the gods we praise.”
7.270: He spoke; Ilioneus this answer made:
7.271: “O King, great heir of Faunus! No dark storm
7.272: impelled us o'er the flood thy realm to find.
7.273: Nor star deceived, nor strange, bewildering shore
7.274: threw out of our true course; but we are come
7.275: by our free choice and with deliberate aim
7.276: to this thy town, though exiled forth of realms
7.277: once mightiest of all the sun-god sees
7.278: when moving from his utmost eastern bound.
7.279: From Jove our line began; the sons of Troy
7.280: boast Jove to be their sire, and our true King
7.281: is of Olympian seed. To thine abode
7.282: Trojan Aeneas sent us. How there burst
7.283: o'er Ida's vales from dread Mycenae's kings
7.284: a tempest vast, and by what stroke of doom
7.285: all Asia's world with Europe clashed in war,
7.286: that lone wight hears whom earth's remotest isle
7.287: has banished to the Ocean's rim, or he
7.288: whose dwelling is the ample zone that burns
7.289: betwixt the changeful sun-god's milder realms,
7.290: far severed from the world. We are the men
7.291: from war's destroying deluge safely borne
7.292: over the waters wide. We only ask
7.293: some low-roofed dwelling for our fathers' gods,
7.294: some friendly shore, and, what to all is free,
7.295: water and air. We bring no evil name
7.296: upon thy people; thy renown will be
7.297: but wider spread; nor of a deed so fair
7.298: can grateful memory die. Ye ne'er will rue
7.299: that to Ausonia's breast ye gathered Troy.
7.300: I swear thee by the favored destinies
7.301: of great Aeneas, by his strength of arm
7.302: in friendship or in war, that many a tribe
7.303: (O, scorn us not, that, bearing olive green,
7.304: with suppliant words we come), that many a throne
7.305: has sued us to be friends. But Fate's decree
7.306: to this thy realm did guide. Here Dardanus
7.307: was born; and with reiterate command
7.308: this way Apollo pointed to the stream
7.309: of Tiber and Numicius' haunted spring.
7.310: Lo, these poor tributes from his greatness gone
7.311: Aeneas sends, these relics snatched away
7.312: from Ilium burning: with this golden bowl
7.313: Anchises poured libation when he prayed;
7.314: and these were Priam's splendor, when he gave
7.315: laws to his gathered states; this sceptre his,
7.316: this diadem revered, and beauteous pall,
7.317: handwork of Asia's queens.” So ceased to speak
7.319: unanswering on the ground, all motionless
7.320: save for his musing eyes. The broidered pall
7.321: of purple, and the sceptre Priam bore,
7.322: moved little on his kingly heart, which now
7.323: pondered of giving to the bridal bed
7.324: his daughter dear. He argues in his mind
7.325: the oracle of Faunus:—might this be
7.326: that destined bridegroom from an alien land,
7.327: to share his throne, to get a progeny
7.328: of glorious valor, which by mighty deeds
7.329: should win the world for kingdom? So at last
7.330: with joyful brow he spoke: “Now let the gods
7.331: our purpose and their own fair promise bless!
7.332: Thou hast, O Trojan, thy desire. Thy gifts
7.333: I have not scorned; nor while Latinus reigns
7.334: shall ye lack riches in my plenteous land,
7.335: not less than Trojan store. But where is he,
7.336: Aeneas' self? If he our royal love
7.337: so much desire, and have such urgent mind
7.338: to be our guest and friend, let him draw near,
7.339: nor turn him from well-wishing looks away!
7.340: My offering and pledge of peace shall be
7.341: to clasp your monarch's hand. Bear back, I pray,
7.342: this answer to your King: my dwelling holds
7.343: a daughter, whom with husband of her blood
7.344: great signs in heaven and from my father's tomb
7.345: forbid to wed. A son from alien shores
7.346: they prophesy for Latium's heir, whose seed
7.347: shall lift our glory to the stars divine.
7.348: I am persuaded this is none but he,
7.349: that man of destiny; and if my heart
7.350: be no false prophet, I desire it so.”
7.351: Thus having said, the sire took chosen steeds
7.352: from his full herd, whereof, well-groomed and fair,
7.353: three hundred stood within his ample pale.
7.354: Of these to every Teucrian guest he gave
7.355: a courser swift and strong, in purple clad
7.356: and broidered housings gay; on every breast
7.357: hung chains of gold; in golden robes arrayed,
7.358: they champed the red gold curb their teeth between.
7.359: For offering to Aeneas, he bade send
7.360: a chariot, with chargers twain of seed
7.362: the famous kind which guileful Circe bred,
7.363: cheating her sire, and mixed the sun-god's team
7.364: with brood-mares earthly born. The sons of Troy,
7.365: such gifts and greetings from Latinus bearing,
7.366: rode back in pomp his words of peace to bring.
7.367: But lo! from Argos on her voyage of air
7.368: rides the dread spouse of Jove. She, sky-enthroned
7.371: and all Aeneas' joy. The prospect shows
7.372: houses a-building, lands of safe abode,
7.373: and the abandoned ships. With bitter grief
7.374: she stands at gaze: then with storm-shaken brows,
7.375: thus from her heart lets loose the wrathful word:
7.378: a scandal and offense! Did no one die
7.379: on Troy's embattled plain? Could captured slaves
7.380: not be enslaved again? Was Ilium's flame
7.381: no warrior's funeral pyre? Did they walk safe
7.382: through serried swords and congregated fires?
7.383: At last, methought, my godhead might repose,
7.384: and my full-fed revenge in slumber lie.
7.385: But nay! Though flung forth from their native land,
7.386: I o'er the waves, with enmity unstayed,
7.387: dared give them chase, and on that exiled few
7.388: hurled the whole sea. I smote the sons of Troy
7.389: with ocean's power and heaven's. But what availed
7.390: Syrtes, or Scylla, or Charybdis' waves?
7.391: The Trojans are in Tiber; and abide
7.393: safe from the seas and me! Mars once had power
7.394: the monstrous Lapithae to slay; and Jove
7.395: to Dian's honor and revenge gave o'er
7.396: the land of Calydon. What crime so foul
7.397: was wrought by Lapithae or Calydon?
7.398: But I, Jove's wife and Queen, who in my woes
7.399: have ventured each bold stroke my power could find,
7.400: and every shift essayed,—behold me now
7.401: outdone by this Aeneas! If so weak
7.402: my own prerogative of godhead be,
7.403: let me seek strength in war, come whence it will!
7.404: If Heaven I may not move, on Hell I call.
7.405: To bar him from his Latin throne exceeds
7.406: my fated power. So be it! Fate has given
7.407: Lavinia for his bride. But long delays
7.408: I still can plot, and to the high event
7.409: deferment and obstruction. I can smite
7.410: the subjects of both kings. Let sire and son
7.411: buy with their people's blood this marriage-bond!
7.412: Let Teucrian and Rutulian slaughter be
7.413: thy virgin dower, and Bellona's blaze
7.414: light thee the bridal bed! Not only teemed
7.415: the womb of Hecuba with burning brand,
7.416: and brought forth nuptial fires; but Venus, too,
7.417: such offspring bore, a second Paris, who
7.418: to their new Troy shall fatal wedlock bring.”
7.419: So saying, with aspect terrible she sped
7.420: earthward her way; and called from gloom of hell
7.421: Alecto, woeful power, from cloudy throne
7.422: among the Furies, where her heart is fed
7.423: with horrid wars, wrath, vengeance, treason foul,
7.424: and fatal feuds. Her father Pluto loathes
7.425: the creature he engendered, and with hate
7.426: her hell-born sister-fiends the monster view.
7.427: A host of shapes she wears, and many a front
7.429: Juno to her this goading speech addressed:
7.430: “O daughter of dark Night, arouse for me
7.431: thy wonted powers and our task begin!
7.432: Lest now my glory fail, my royal name
7.433: be vanquished, while Aeneas and his crew
7.434: cheat with a wedlock bond the Latin King
7.435: and seize Italia's fields. Thou canst thrust on
7.436: two Ioving brothers to draw sword and slay,
7.437: and ruin homes with hatred, calling in
7.438: the scourge of Furies and avenging fires.
7.439: A thousand names thou bearest, and thy ways
7.441: Arouse thy fertile breast! Go, rend in twain
7.442: this plighted peace! Breed calumnies and sow
7.443: causes of battle, till yon warrior hosts
7.444: cry out for swords and leap to gird them on.”
7.445: Straightway Alecto, through whose body flows
7.446: the Gorgon poison, took her viewless way
7.447: to Latium and the lofty walls and towers
7.448: of the Laurentian King. Crouching she sate
7.449: in silence on the threshold of the bower
7.450: where Queen Amata in her fevered soul
7.451: pondered, with all a woman's wrath and fear,
7.452: upon the Trojans and the marriage-suit
7.453: of Turnus. From her Stygian hair the fiend
7.454: a single serpent flung, which stole its way
7.455: to the Queen's very heart, that, frenzy-driven,
7.456: she might on her whole house confusion pour.
7.457: Betwixt her smooth breast and her robe it wound
7.458: unfelt, unseen, and in her wrathful mind
7.459: instilled its viper soul. Like golden chain
7.460: around her neck it twined, or stretched along
7.461: the fillets on her brow, or with her hair
7.462: enwrithing coiled; then on from limb to limb
7.463: slipped tortuous. Yet though the venom strong
7.464: thrilled with its first infection every vein,
7.465: and touched her bones with fire, she knew it not,
7.466: nor yielded all her soul, but made her plea
7.467: in gentle accents such as mothers use;
7.468: and many a tear she shed, about her child,
7.469: her darling, destined for a Phrygian's bride:
7.470: “O father! can we give Lavinia's hand
7.471: to Trojan fugitives? why wilt thou show
7.472: no mercy on thy daughter, nor thyself;
7.473: nor unto me, whom at the first fair wind
7.474: that wretch will leave deserted, bearing far
7.475: upon his pirate ship my stolen child?
7.476: Was it not thus that Phrygian shepherd came
7.478: Helen, the child of Leda, whom he bore
7.479: to those false Trojan lands? Hast thou forgot
7.480: thy plighted word? Where now thy boasted love
7.481: of kith and kin, and many a troth-plight given
7.482: unto our kinsman Turnus? If we need
7.483: an alien son, and Father Faunus' words
7.485: I tell thee every land not linked with ours
7.486: under one sceptre, but distinct and free,
7.487: is alien; and 't is thus the gods intend.
7.488: Indeed, if Turnus' ancient race be told,
7.490: and out of mid-Mycenae.” But she sees
7.491: her lord Latinus resolute, her words
7.492: an effort vain; and through her body spreads
7.494: Then, woe-begone, by dark dreams goaded on,
7.495: she wanders aimless, fevered and unstrung
7.496: along the public ways; as oft one sees
7.497: beneath the twisted whips a leaping top
7.498: sped in long spirals through a palace-close
7.499: by lads at play: obedient to the thong,
7.500: it weaves wide circles in the gaping view
7.501: of its small masters, who admiring see
7.502: the whirling boxwood made a living thing
7.503: under their lash. So fast and far she roved
7.504: from town to town among the clansmen wild.
7.505: Then to the wood she ran, feigning to feel
7.506: the madness Bacchus loves; for she essays
7.507: a fiercer crime, by fiercer frenzy moved.
7.508: Now in the leafy dark of mountain vales
7.509: she hides her daughter, ravished thus away
7.510: from Trojan bridegroom and the wedding-feast.
7.511: “Hail, Bacchus! Thou alone,” she shrieked and raved,
7.512: “art worthy such a maid. For thee she bears
7.513: the thyrsus with soft ivy-clusters crowned,
7.514: and trips ecstatic in thy beauteous choir.
7.515: For thee alone my daughter shall unbind
7.516: the glory of her virgin hair.” Swift runs
7.517: the rumor of her deed; and, frenzy-driven,
7.518: the wives of Latium to the forests fly,
7.519: enkindled with one rage. They leave behind
7.520: their desolated hearths, and let rude winds
7.521: o'er neck and tresses blow; their voices fill
7.522: the welkin with convulsive shriek and wail;
7.523: and, with fresh fawn-skins on their bodies bound,
7.524: they brandish vine-clad spears. The Queen herself
7.525: lifts high a blazing pine tree, while she sings
7.526: a wedding-song for Turnus and her child.
7.527: With bloodshot glance and anger wild, she cries:
7.528: “Ho! all ye Latin wives, if e'er ye knew
7.529: kindness for poor Amata, if ye care
7.530: for a wronged mother's woes, O, follow me!
7.531: Cast off the matron fillet from your brows,
7.532: and revel to our mad, voluptuous song.”
7.533: Thus, through the woodland haunt of creatures wild,
7.534: Alecto urges on the raging Queen
7.535: with Bacchus' cruel goad. But when she deemed
7.536: the edge of wrath well whetted, and the house
7.537: of wise Latinus of all reason reft,
7.538: then soared the black-winged goddess to the walls
7.539: of the bold Rutule, to the city built
7.540: (So runs the tale) by beauteous Danae
7.541: and her Acrisian people, shipwrecked there
7.542: by south wind strong. Its name was Ardea
7.543: in language of our sires, and that proud name
7.544: of Ardea still it wears, though proud no more.
7.545: Here Turnus in the gloom of midnight lay
7.546: half-sleeping in his regal hall. For him
7.547: Alecto her grim fury-guise put by,
7.548: and wore an old crone's face, her baleful brow
7.549: delved deep with wrinkled age, her hoary hair
7.550: in sacred fillet bound, and garlanded
7.551: with leaf of olive: Calybe she seemed,
7.552: an aged servitress ot Juno's shrine,
7.553: and in this seeming thus the prince addressed:—
7.554: “O Turnus, wilt thou tamely see thy toil
7.555: lavished in vain? and thy true throne consigned
7.556: to Trojan wanderers? The King repels
7.557: thy noble wooing and thy war-won dower.
7.558: He summons him a son of alien stem
7.559: to take his kingdom. Rouse thee now, and front,
7.560: scorned and without reward, these perilous days.
7.561: Tread down that Tuscan host! Protect the peace
7.562: of Latium from its foe! Such is the word
7.563: which, while in night and slumber thou wert laid,
7.565: bade me declare. Up, therefore, and array
7.566: thy warriors in arms! Swift sallying forth
7.567: from thy strong city-gates, on to the fray
7.568: exultant go! Assail the Phrygian chiefs
7.569: who tent them by thy beauteous river's marge,
7.570: and burn their painted galleys! 't is the will
7.571: of gods above that speaks. Yea, even the King
7.572: Latinus, if he will not heed thy plea,
7.573: or hear thy wooing, shall be taught too late
7.574: what Turnus is in panoply of war.”
7.575: In mocking answer to the prophetess
7.576: the warrior thus replied: “That stranger fleet
7.577: in Tiber moored, not, as thy folly prates,
7.578: of me unnoted lies. Vex me no more
7.579: with thy fantastic terror. Juno's power
7.580: is watchful of my cause. 'T is mere old age,
7.581: gone to decay and dotage, fills thy breast
7.582: with vain foreboding, and, while kings contend,
7.583: scares and deceives thy visionary eye.
7.584: Guard thou in yonder temple's holy shade
7.585: the images divine! Of peace and war
7.586: let men and warriors the burden bear!”
7.587: So kindled he Alecto's wrath to flame;
7.588: and even as he spoke a shudder thrilled
7.589: the warrior's body, and his eyeballs stood
7.590: stonily staring at the hydra hair
7.591: which hissed and writhed above the grisly head
7.592: of the large-looming fiend. With eyes of fire
7.593: horribly rolling, she repelled him far,
7.594: while he but faltered speechless. She upraised
7.595: two coiling snakes out of her tresses, cracked
7.596: the lashes of her scourge, and wrathfully,
7.597: with raving lips replied: “Look well on me,
7.598: gone to decay and dotage of old age!
7.599: And mocked with foolish fear while kings contend!
7.600: Wilt hearken now! Behold me, hither flown
7.601: from where my sister-furies dwell! My hands
7.602: bring bloody death and war.” She spoke, and hurled
7.603: her firebrand at the hero, thrusting deep
7.604: beneath his heart her darkly smouldering flame.
7.605: Then horror broke his sleep, and fearful sweat
7.606: dripped from his every limb. He shrieked aloud
7.607: for arms; and seized the ready arms that lay
7.608: around his couch and hall. Then o'er his soul
7.609: the lust of battle and wild curse of war
7.610: broke forth in angry power, as when the flames
7.611: of faggots round the bubbling cauldron sing,
7.612: and up the waters leap; the close-kept flood
7.613: brims over, streaming, foaming, breaking bound,
7.614: and flings thick clouds in air. He, summoning
7.615: his chieftains, bade them on Latinus move,
7.616: break peace, take arms, and, over Italy
7.617: their shields extending, to thrust forth her foe:
7.618: himself for Teucrian with Latin joined
7.619: was more than match. He called upon the gods
7.620: in witness of his vows: while, nothing loth,
7.622: some by his youth and noble beauty moved,
7.623: some by his kingly sires and fame in arms.
7.624: While Turnus stirred Rutulia's valiant souls,
7.625: Alecto on her Stygian pinions sped
7.626: to where the Teucrians lay. She scanned the ground
7.627: with eager guile, where by the river's marge
7.628: fair-browed Iulus with his nets and snares
7.629: rode fiercely to the chase. Then o'er his hounds
7.630: that hell-born virgin breathed a sudden rage,
7.631: and filled each cunning nostril with the scent
7.632: of stags, till forth in wild pursuit they flew.
7.633: Here all the woe began, and here awoke
7.634: in rustic souls the swift-enkindling war.
7.635: For a fair stag, tall-antlered, stolen away
7.636: even from its mother's milk, had long been kept
7.637: by Tyrrhus and his sons—the shepherd he
7.638: of all the royal flocks, and forester
7.639: of a wide region round. With fondest care
7.640: their sister Silvia entwined its horns
7.641: with soft, fresh garlands, tamed it to run close,
7.642: and combed the creature, or would bring to bathe
7.643: at a clear, crystal spring. It knew the hands
7.644: of all its gentle masters, and would feed
7.645: from their own dish; or wandering through the wood,
7.646: come back unguided to their friendly door,
7.647: though deep the evening shade. Iulus' dogs
7.648: now roused this wanderer in their ravening chase,
7.649: as, drifted down-stream far from home it lay,
7.650: on a green bank a-cooling. From bent bow
7.651: Ascanius, eager for a hunter's praise,
7.652: let go his shaft; nor did Alecto fail
7.653: his aim to guide: but, whistling through the air,
7.654: the light-winged reed pierced deep in flank and side.
7.655: Swift to its cover fled the wounded thing,
7.656: and crept loud-moaning to its wonted stall,
7.657: where, like a blood-stained suppliant, it seemed
7.658: to fill that shepherd's house with plaintive prayer.
7.659: Then Silvia the sister, smiting oft
7.660: on breast and arm, made cry for help, and called
7.661: the sturdy rustics forth in gathering throng.
7.662: These now (for in the silent forest couched
7.663: the cruel Fury) swift to battle flew.
7.664: One brandished a charred stake, another swung
7.665: a knotted cudgel, as rude anger shapes
7.666: its weapon of whate'er the searching eye
7.667: first haps to fall on. Tyrrhus roused his clans,
7.668: just when by chance he split with blows of wedge
7.669: an oak in four; and, panting giant breath,
7.670: shouldered his woodman's axe. Alecto then,
7.671: prompt to the stroke of mischief, soared aloft
7.672: from where she spying sate, to the steep roof
7.673: of a tall byre, and from its peak of straw
7.674: blew a wild signal on a shepherd's horn,
7.675: outflinging her infernal note so far
7.676: that all the forest shuddered, and the grove
7.677: throbbed to its deepest glen. Cold Trivia's lake
7.678: from end to end gave ear, and every wave
7.679: of the white stream of Nar, the lonely pools
7.680: of still Velinus heard: while at the sound
7.681: pale mothers to their breasts their children drew.
7.682: Swift to the signal of the dreadful horn,
7.683: snatching their weapons rude, the freeborn swains
7.684: assembled for the fray; the Trojan bands
7.685: poured from their bivouac with instant aid
7.686: for young Ascanius. In array of war
7.687: both stand confronting. Not mere rustic brawl
7.688: with charred oak-staff and cudgel is the fight,
7.689: but with the two-edged steel; the naked swords
7.690: wave like dark-bladed harvest-field, while far
7.691: the brazen arms flash in the smiting sun,
7.692: and skyward fling their beam: so some wide sea,
7.693: at first but whitened in the rising wind,
7.694: swells its slow-rolling mass and ever higher
7.695: its billows rears, until the utmost deep
7.696: lifts in one surge to heaven. The first to fall
7.697: was Almo, eldest-born of Tyrrhus' sons,
7.698: whom, striding in the van, a loud-winged shaft
7.699: laid low in death; deep in his throat it clung,
7.700: and silenced with his blood the dying cry
7.701: of his frail life. Around him fell the forms
7.702: of many a brave and strong; among them died
7.703: gray-haired Galaesus pleading for a truce:
7.704: righteous he was, and of Ausonian fields
7.705: a prosperous master; five full flocks had he
7.706: of bleating sheep, and from his pastures came
7.707: five herds of cattle home; his busy churls
7.708: turned with a hundred ploughs his fruitful glebe.
7.709: While o'er the battle-field thus doubtful swung
7.710: the scales of war, the Fury (to her task
7.711: now equal proven) having dyed the day
7.712: a deep-ensanguined hue, and opened fight
7.713: with death and slaughter, made no tarrying
7.715: and, Ioud in triumph, insolently thus
7.716: to Juno called: “See, at thy will, their strife
7.717: full-blown to war and woe! Could even thyself
7.718: command them now to truce and amity?
7.719: But I, that with Ausonia's blood befoul
7.720: their Trojan hands, yet more can do, if thou
7.721: shift not thy purpose. For with dire alarms
7.722: I will awake the bordering states to war
7.723: enkindling in their souls the frenzied lust
7.724: the war-god breathes; till from th' horizon round
7.726: of carnage through the land.” In answer spoke
7.728: Thy provocation works. Now have they joined
7.729: in close and deadly combat, and warm blood
7.731: which chance put in their hands. Such nuptial joys,
7.732: such feast of wedlock, let the famous son
7.733: of Venus with the King Latinus share!
7.734: But yon Olympian Sire and King no more
7.735: permits thee freely in our skies to roam.
7.736: Go, quit the field! Myself will take control
7.737: of hazards and of labors yet to be.”
7.738: Thus Saturn's daughter spoke. Alecto then,
7.739: unfolding far her hissing, viperous wings,
7.740: turned toward her Stygian home, and took farewell
7.741: of upper air. Deep in Italia lies
7.743: and known in olden songs from land to land:
7.744: the valley of Amsanctus; deep, dark shades
7.747: a roaring fall. Here in a monstrous cave
7.748: are breathing-holes of hell, a vast abyss
7.749: where Acheron opes wide its noisome jaws:
7.750: in this Alecto plunged, concealing so
7.751: her execrable godhead, while the air
7.752: of earth and heaven felt the curse removed.
7.753: Forthwith the sovereign hands of Juno haste
7.754: to consummate the war. The shepherds bear
7.755: back from the field of battle to the town
7.756: the bodies of the slain: young Almo's corse
7.757: and gray Galaesus' bleeding head. They call
7.758: just gods in heaven to Iook upon their wrong,
7.759: and bid Latinus see it. Turnus comes,
7.760: and, while the angry mob surveys the slain,
7.761: adds fury to the hour. “Shall the land
7.762: have Trojan lords? Shall Phrygian marriages
7.763: debase our ancient, royal blood—and I
7.764: be spurned upon the threshold?” Then drew near
7.765: the men whose frenzied women-folk had held
7.766: bacchantic orgies in the pathless grove,
7.767: awed by Amata's name: these, gathering,
7.768: sued loud for war. Yea, all defied the signs
7.770: divine decrees, and clamored for revenge,
7.771: prompted by evil powers. They besieged
7.772: the house of King Latinus, shouting-loud
7.773: with emulous rage. But like a sea-girt rock
7.774: unmoved he stood; like sea-girt rock when surge
7.775: of waters o'er it sweeps, or howling waves
7.776: surround; it keeps a ponderous front of power,
7.777: though foaming cliffs around it vainly roar;
7.778: from its firm base the broken sea-weeds fall.
7.779: But when authority no whit could change
7.780: their counsels blind, and each event fulfilled
7.781: dread Juno's will, then with complaining prayer
7.782: the aged sire cried loud upon his gods
7.783: and on th' unheeding air: “Alas,” said he,
7.784: “My doom is shipwreck, and the tempest bears
7.785: my bark away! O wretches, your own blood
7.786: shall pay the forfeit for your impious crime.
7.788: Avenging woes pursue thee; to deaf gods
7.789: thy late and unavailing prayer shall rise.
7.790: Now was my time to rest. But as I come
7.791: close to my journey's end, thou spoilest me
7.792: of comfort in my death.” With this the King
7.793: fled to his house and ceased his realm to guide.
7.794: A sacred custom the Hesperian land
7.795: of Latium knew, by all the Alban hills
7.797: keeps to this day, when to new stroke she stirs
7.798: the might of Mars; if on the Danube's wave
7.799: resolved to fling the mournful doom of war,
7.800: or on the Caspian folk or Arabs wild;
7.801: or chase the morning far as India's verge,
7.802: ind from the Parthian despot wrest away
7.803: our banners Iost. Twin Gates of War there be,
7.804: of fearful name, to Mars' fierce godhead vowed:
7.805: a hundred brass bars shut them, and the strength
7.806: of uncorrupting steel; in sleepless watch
7.807: Janus the threshold keeps. 'T is here, what time
7.808: the senate's voice is war, the consul grave
7.809: in Gabine cincture and Quirinal shift
7.810: himself the griding hinges backward moves,
7.811: and bids the Romans arm; obedient then
7.812: the legionary host makes Ioud acclaim,
7.813: and hoarse consent the brazen trumpets blow.
7.814: Thus King Latinus on the sons of Troy
7.815: was urged to open war, and backward roll
7.816: those gates of sorrow: but the aged king
7.817: recoiled, refused the loathsome task, and fled
7.818: to solitary shades. Then from the skies
7.819: the Queen of gods stooped down, and her sole hand
7.821: swung on their hinges the barred gates of war.
7.823: bursts forth in flame. Foot-soldiers through the field
7.824: run to and fro; and mounted on tall steeds
7.825: the cavaliers in clouds of dust whirl by.
7.826: All arm in haste. Some oil the glittering shield
7.827: or javelin bright, or on the whetstone wear
7.828: good axes to an edge, while joyful bands
7.829: uplift the standards or the trumpets blow.
7.830: Five mighty cities to their anvils bring
7.833: and river-walled Antemnae, crowned with towers
7.834: strong hollow helmets on their brows they draw
7.835: and weave them willow-shields; or melt and mould
7.836: corselets of brass or shining silver greaves;
7.837: none now for pruning-hook or sacred plough
7.838: have love or care: but old, ancestral swords
7.839: for hardier tempering to the smith they bring.
7.840: Now peals the clarion; through the legions pass
7.841: the watchwords: the impatient yeoman takes
7.842: his helmet from the idle roof-tree hung;
7.843: while to his chariot the master yokes
7.844: the mettled war-horse, dons a shining shield
7.845: and golden mail, and buckles his good sword.
7.846: Virgins of Helicon, renew my song!
7.847: Instruct me what proud kings to battle flown
7.848: with following legions throng the serried plain.
7.849: Tell me what heroes and illustrious arms
7.850: Italia's bosom in her dawning day
7.851: benignant bore: for your celestial minds,
7.852: have memory of the past, but faint and low
7.853: steals glory's whisper on a mortal ear.
7.854: Foremost in fight, from shores Etrurian came
7.856: his people all in arms; and at his side
7.857: Lausus his heir (no fairer youth than he,
7.858: save Turnus of Laurentum), Lausus, skilled
7.859: o break proud horses and wild beasts to quell;
7.860: who from Agylla's citadel in vain
7.861: led forth his thousand warriors: worthy he
7.862: to serve a nobler sire, and happier far
7.863: he had ne'er been born Mezentius' son.
7.864: Next after these, conspicuous o'er the plain,
7.865: with palm-crowned chariot and victorious steeds,
7.867: from shapely Hercules; upon the shield
7.868: his blazon was a hundred snakes, and showed
7.870: him deep in Aventine's most secret grove
7.871: the priestess Rhea bore—a mortal maid
7.872: clasped in a god's embrace the wondrous day
7.873: when, flushed with conquest of huge Geryon,
7.874: the lord of Tiryns to Laurentum drove,
7.875: and washed in Tiber's wave th' Iberian kine.
7.876: His followers brandished pointed pikes and staves,
7.877: or smooth Sabellian bodkin tipped with steel;
7.878: but he, afoot, swung round him as he strode
7.879: a monstrous lion-skin, its bristling mane
7.880: and white teeth crowning his ferocious brow:
7.881: for garbed as Hercules he sought his King.
7.882: Then came twin brethren, leaving Tibur's keep
7.883: (named from Tiburtus, brother of them twain)
7.885: of Argive seed, who foremost in the van
7.886: pressed ever where the foemen densest throng:
7.887: as when two centaurs, children of the cloud,
7.888: from mountain-tops descend in swift career,
7.889: the snows of Homole and Othrys leaving,
7.890: while crashing thickets in their pathway fall.
7.891: Nor was Praeneste's founder absent there,
7.892: by Vulcan sired, among the herds and hinds,
7.893: and on a hearth-stone found (so runs the tale
7.894: each pious age repeats) King Caeculus
7.895: with rustic legions gathered from afar:
7.896: from steep Praeneste and the Gabian vale
7.897: to Juno dear, from Anio's cold stream,
7.898: from upland Hernic rocks and foaming rills,
7.899: from rich Anagnia's pastures, and the plain
7.900: whence Amasenus pours his worshipped wave.
7.901: Not all of armor boast, and seldom sound
7.902: the chariot and shield; but out of slings
7.903: they hurl blue balls of lead, or in one hand
7.904: a brace of javelins bear; pulled o'er their brows
7.905: are hoods of tawny wolf-skin; as they march
7.906: the left foot leaves a barefoot track behind,
7.907: a rawhide sandal on the right they wear.
7.909: by sword and fire invincible: this day,
7.910: though mild his people and unschooled in war,
7.911: he calls them to embattled lines, and draws
7.912: no lingering sword. Fescennia musters there,
7.913: Aequi Falisci, and what clans possess
7.915: Ciminian lake and mountain, and the groves
7.916: about Capena. Rank on rank they move,
7.917: loud singing of their chieftain's praise: as when
7.918: a flock of snowy swans through clouded air
7.919: return from feeding, and make tuneful cry
7.920: from their long throats, while Asia's rivers hear,
7.921: and lone Cayster's startled moorland rings:
7.922: for hardly could the listening ear discern
7.923: the war-cry of a mail-clad host; the sound
7.924: was like shrill-calling birds, when home from sea
7.925: their soaring flock moves shoreward like a cloud.
7.926: Then, one of far-descended Sabine name,
7.927: Clausus advanced, the captain of a host,
7.928: and in himself an equal host he seemed;
7.929: from his proud loins the high-born Claudian stem
7.930: through Latium multiplies, since Roman power
7.931: with Sabine first was wed. A cohort came
7.932: from Amiternum and the olden wall
7.933: of Cures, called Quirites even then;
7.935: with olives clad, Velinus' flowery field,
7.939: Tiber and Fabaris, and wintry streams
7.940: of Nursia; to the same proud muster sped
7.941: Tuscan with Latin tribes, and loyal towns
7.942: beside whose walls ill-omened Allia flows.
7.943: As numerous they moved as rolling waves
7.944: that stir smooth Libyan seas, when in cold floods
7.945: sinks grim Orion's star; or like the throng
7.946: of clustering wheat-tops in the summer sun,
7.947: near Hermus or on Lycia's yellowing plain:
7.948: shields clashed; their strong tramp smote the trembling ground.
7.950: to the mere name of Troy, Halaesus, yokes
7.951: the horses of his car and summons forth
7.952: a thousand savage clans at Turnus' call :
7.953: rude men whose mattocks to the Massic hills
7.954: bring Bacchus' bounty, or by graybeard sires
7.955: sent from Auruncan upland and the mead
7.956: of Sidicinum; out of Cales came
7.957: its simple folk; and dwellers by the stream
7.959: with bold Saticulan or Oscan swains.
7.960: Their arms are tapered javelins, which they wear
7.961: bound by a coiling thong; a shield conceals
7.962: the left side, and they fight with crooked swords.
7.963: Nor shalt thou, Oebalus, depart unsung,
7.964: whom minstrels say the nymph Sebethis bore
7.965: to Telon, who in Capri was a king
7.966: when old and gray; but that disdaining son
7.967: quitted so small a seat, and conquering sway
7.968: among Sarrastian folk and those wide plains
7.969: watered by Sarnus' wave, became a king
7.971: and where among her apple-orchards rise
7.972: Abella's walls. All these, as Teutons use,
7.973: hurl a light javelin; for helm they wear
7.974: stripped cork-tree bark; the crescent of their shields
7.975: is gleaming bronze, and gleaming bronze the sword.
7.976: Next Ufens, mountain-bred, from Nersae came
7.977: to join the war; of goodly fame was he
7.978: for prosperous arms: his Aequian people show
7.979: no gentle mien, but scour the woods for prey,
7.980: or, ever-armed, across the stubborn glebe
7.981: compel the plough; though their chief pride and joy
7.982: are rapine, violence, and plundered store.
7.983: Next after these, his brows and helmet bound
7.984: with noble olive, from Marruvium came
7.985: a priest, brave Umbro, ordered to the field
7.986: by King Archippus: o'er the viper's brood,
7.987: and venomed river-serpents he had power
7.988: to scatter slumber with wide-waving hands
7.989: and wizard-songs. His potent arts could soothe
7.990: their coiling rage and heal the mortal sting:
7.991: but 'gainst a Trojan sword no drug had he,
7.992: nor could his drowsy spells his flesh repair,
7.993: nor gathered simples from the Marsic hills.
7.994: Thee soon in wailing woods Anguitia mourned,
7.995: thee, Fucinus, the lake of crystal wave,
7.997: Next, Virbius in martial beauty rode,
7.998: son of Hippolytus, whose mother, proud
7.999: Aricia, sent him in his flower of fame
7.1000: out of Egeria's hills and cloudy groves
7.1001: where lies Diana's gracious, gifted fane.
7.1003: by step-dame's plot undone, his life-blood gave
7.1004: to sate his vengeful father, and was rent
7.1005: in sunder by wild horses; but the grave
7.1006: to air of heaven and prospect of the stars
7.1007: restored him;—for Diana's love and care
7.1008: poured out upon him Paeon's healing balm.
7.1009: But Jove, almighty Sire, brooked not to see
7.1010: a mortal out of death and dark reclimb
7.1011: to light of life, and with a thunderbolt
7.1012: hurled to the Stygian river Phoebus' son,
7.1013: who dared such good elixir to compound.
7.1015: in her most secret cave, and gave in ward
7.1016: to the wise nymph Egeria in her grove;
7.1017: where he lived on inglorious and alone,
7.1018: ranging the woods of Italy, and bore
7.1019: the name of Virbius. 'T is for this cause
7.1020: the hallowed woods to Trivia's temple vowed
7.1021: forbid loud-footed horses, such as spilled
7.1022: stripling and chariot on the fatal shore,
7.1023: scared by the monsters peering from the sea.
7.1024: Yet did the son o'er that tumultuous plain
7.1025: his battle-chariot guide and plunging team.
7.1026: Lo, Turnus strides conspicuous in the van,
7.1027: full armed, of mighty frame, his lordly head
7.1028: high o'er his peers emerging! His tall helm
7.1029: with flowing triple crest for ensign bears
7.1031: volcanic fires; where'er the menace moves
7.1032: of her infernal flames and wrathful frown,
7.1033: there wildest flows the purple flood of war.
7.1034: On his smooth shield deep graven in the gold
7.1036: a shaggy heifer-shape the maiden shows;
7.1037: Argus is watching her, while Inachus
7.1038: pours forth his river from the pictured urn.
7.1039: A storm of tramping troops, to Turnus sworn,
7.1040: throngs all the widespread plain with serried shields:
7.1041: warriors of Argos, and Auruncan bands,
7.1043: Labicum's painted shields; all who till
7.1044: thy woodland vales, O Tiber! or the shore
7.1045: Numicius hallows; all whose ploughs upturn
7.1046: Rutulia's hills, or that Circaean range
7.1047: where Jove of Anxur guards, and forests green
7.1048: make fair Feronia glad; where lie the fens
7.1049: of Satura, and Ufens' icy wave
7.1050: through lowland valleys seeks his seaward way.
7.1051: Last came Camilla, of the Volscians bred,
7.1054: of web and distaff, fit for woman's toil,
7.1055: no follower she; but bared her virgin breast
7.1056: to meet the brunt of battle, and her speed
7.1057: left even the winds behind; for she would skim
7.1058: an untouched harvest ere the sickle fell,
7.1059: nor graze the quivering wheat-tops as she ran;
7.1060: or o'er the mid-sea billows' swollen surge
7.1061: so swiftly race, she wet not in the wave
7.1062: her flying feet. For sight of her the youth
7.1063: from field and fortress sped, and matrons grave
7.1064: stood wondering as she passed, well-pleased to see
7.1065: her royal scarf in many a purple fold
7.1066: float off her shining shoulder, her dark hair
7.1067: in golden clasp caught fast, and how she bore
7.1068: for arms a quiver of the Lycian mode,
7.1069: and shepherd's shaft of myrtle tipped with steel.

8.1: When Turnus from Laurentum's bastion proud
8.2: published the war, and roused the dreadful note
8.3: of the harsh trumpet's song; when on swift steeds
8.4: the lash he laid and clashed his sounding arms;
8.5: then woke each warrior soul; all Latium stirred
8.6: with tumult and alarm; and martial rage
8.7: enkindled youth's hot blood. The chieftains proud,
8.8: Messapus, Ufens, and that foe of Heaven,
8.9: Mezentius, compel from far and wide
8.10: their loyal hosts, and strip the field and farm
8.11: of husbandmen. To seek auxiliar arms
8.12: they send to glorious Diomed's domain
8.13: the herald Venulus, and bid him cry:
8.14: “Troy is to Latium come; Aeneas' fleet
8.15: has come to land. He brings his vanquished gods,
8.16: and gives himself to be our destined King.
8.17: Cities not few accept him, and his name
8.18: through Latium waxes large. But what the foe
8.19: by such attempt intends, what victory
8.20: is his presumptuous hope, if Fortune smile,
8.21: Aetolia's lord will not less wisely fear
8.22: than royal Turnus or our Latin King.”
8.23: Thus Latium's cause moved on. Meanwhile the heir
8.24: of great Laomedon, who knew full well
8.25: the whole wide land astir, was vexed and tossed
8.26: in troubled seas of care. This way and that
8.27: his swift thoughts flew, and scanned with like dismay
8.28: each partial peril or the general storm.
8.29: Thus the vexed waters at a fountain's brim,
8.30: smitten by sunshine or the silver sphere
8.31: of a reflected moon, send forth a beam
8.32: of flickering light that leaps from wall to wall,
8.33: or, skyward lifted in ethereal flight,
8.34: glances along some rich-wrought, vaulted dome.
8.35: Now night had fallen, and all weary things,
8.36: all shapes of beast or bird, the wide world o'er,
8.37: lay deep in slumber. So beneath the arch
8.38: of a cold sky Aeneas laid him down
8.39: upon the river-bank, his heart sore tried
8.40: by so much war and sorrow, and gave o'er
8.41: his body to its Iong-delayed repose.
8.42: There, 'twixt the poplars by the gentle stream,
8.43: the River-Father, genius of that place,
8.45: a cloak of gray-green lawn he wore, his hair
8.46: o'erhung with wreath of reeds. In soothing words
8.47: thus, to console Aeneas' cares, he spoke:
8.48: “Seed of the gods! who bringest to my shore
8.49: thy Trojan city wrested from her foe,
8.51: and fair Laurentum long have looked for thee.
8.52: Here truly is thy home. Turn not away.
8.53: Here the true guardians of thy hearth shall be.
8.54: Fear not the gathering war. The wrath of Heaven
8.55: has stilled its swollen wave. A sign I tell:
8.56: Lest thou shouldst deem this message of thy sleep
8.57: a vain, deluding dream, thou soon shalt find
8.58: in the oak-copses on my margent green,
8.59: a huge sow, with her newly-littered brood
8.60: of thirty young; along the ground she lies,
8.61: snow-white, and round her udders her white young.
8.62: There shall thy city stand, and there thy toil
8.63: shall find untroubled rest. After the lapse
8.64: of thrice ten rolling years, Ascanius
8.65: shall found a city there of noble name,
8.66: White-City, Alba; 't is no dream I sing!
8.67: But I instruct thee now by what wise way
8.68: th' impending wars may bring thee victory:
8.69: receive the counsel, though the words be few:
8.70: within this land are men of Arcady,
8.71: of Pallas' line, who, following in the train
8.72: of King Evander and his men-at-arms,
8.73: built them a city in the hills, and chose
8.75: the name of Pallanteum. They make war
8.76: incessant with the Latins. Therefore call
8.77: this people to thy side and bind them close
8.78: in federated power. My channel fair
8.79: and shaded shore shall guide thee where they dwell,
8.80: and thy strong oarsmen on my waters borne
8.81: shall mount my falling stream. Rise, goddess-born,
8.82: and ere the starlight fade give honor due
8.83: to Juno, and with supplicating vow
8.84: avert her wrath and frown. But unto me
8.85: make offering in thy victorious hour,
8.86: in time to come. I am the copious flood
8.87: which thou beholdest chafing at yon shores
8.88: and parting fruitful fields: cerulean stream
8.89: of Tiber, favored greatly of high Heaven.
8.90: here shall arise my house magnificent,
8.91: a city of all cities chief and crown.”
8.92: So spake the river-god, and sank from view
8.93: down to his deepest cave; then night and sleep
8.95: He rose, and to the orient beams of morn
8.96: his forehead gave; in both his hollowed palms
8.97: he held the sacred waters of the stream,
8.98: and called aloud: “O ye Laurentian nymphs,
8.99: whence flowing rills be born, and chiefly thou,
8.100: O Father Tiber, worshipped stream divine,
8.101: accept Aeneas, and from peril save!
8.102: If in some hallowed lake or haunted spring
8.103: thy power, pitying my woes, abides,
8.104: or wheresoe'er the blessed place be found
8.105: whence first thy beauty flows, there evermore
8.106: my hands shall bring thee gift and sacrifice.
8.107: O chief and sovereign of Hesperian streams,
8.108: O river-god that hold'st the plenteous horn,
8.109: protect us, and confirm thy words divine!”
8.110: He spoke; then chose twin biremes from the fleet,
8.111: gave them good gear and armed their loyal crews.
8.112: But, lo! a sudden wonder met his eyes:
8.113: white gleaming through the grove, with all her brood
8.114: white like herself, on the green bank the Sow
8.115: stretched prone. The good Aeneas slew her there,
8.116: Great Juno, for a sacrifice to thee,
8.117: himself the priest, and with the sucklings all
8.118: beside shine altar stood. So that whole night
8.119: the god of Tiber calmed his swollen wave,
8.120: ebbing or lingering in silent flow,
8.121: till like some gentle lake or sleeping pool
8.122: his even waters lay, and strove no more
8.123: against the oarsmen's toil. Upon their way
8.124: they speed with joyful sound; the well-oiled wood
8.125: slips through the watery floor; the wondering waves,
8.126: and all the virgin forests wondering,
8.127: behold the warriors in far-shining arms
8.128: their painted galleys up the current drive.
8.129: O'er the long reaches of the winding flood
8.130: their sturdy oars outweary the slow course
8.131: of night and day. Fair groves of changeful green
8.132: arch o'er their passage, and they seem to cleave
8.133: green forests in the tranquil wave below.
8.134: Now had the flaming sun attained his way
8.135: to the mid-sphere of heaven, when they discerned
8.136: walls and a citadel in distant view,
8.137: with houses few and far between; 't was there,
