10.208: at midnight through the waters. He had fared
10.209: from old Evander to th' Etruscan folk,
10.210: addressed their King, and to him told the tale
10.211: of his own race and name, his suit, his powers;
10.212: of what allies Mezentius had embraced,
10.213: and Turnus' lawless rage. He bids him know
10.214: how mutable is man, and warning gives,
10.216: Tarchon made amity and sacred league,
10.217: uniting with his cause. The Lydian tribe,
10.218: now destined from its tyrant to be free,
10.219: embarked, obedient to the gods, and gave
10.220: allegiance to the foreign King. The ship
10.221: Aeneas rode moved foremost in the line:
10.222: its beak a pair of Phrygian lions bore;
10.223: above them Ida rose, an emblem dear
10.224: to exiled Trojans. On his Iofty seat
10.225: was great Aeneas, pondering the events
10.226: of changeful war; and clinging to his side
10.227: the youthful Pallas fain would learn the lore
10.228: of stars, the highway of dark night, and asks
10.229: the story of his toils on land and sea.
10.230: Now open Helicon and move my song,
10.231: ye goddesses, to tell what host in arms
10.232: followed Aeneas from the Tuscan shore,
10.233: and manned his ships and traveiled o'er the sea!
10.234: First Massicus his brazen Tigress rode,
10.235: cleaving the brine; a thousand warriors
10.236: were with him out of Clusium's walls, or from
10.237: the citadel of Coste, who for arms
10.238: had arrows, quivers from the shoulder slung,
10.239: and deadly bows. Grim Abas near him sailed;
10.240: his whole band wore well-blazoned mail; his ship
10.241: displayed the form of Phoebus, all of gold:
10.244: well-proven in war; three hundred Elba gave,
10.245: an island rich in unexhausted ores
10.246: of iron, like the Chalybes. Next came
10.247: Asilas, who betwixt the gods and men
10.248: interprets messages and reads clear signs
10.249: in victims' entrails, or the stars of heaven,
10.250: or bird-talk, or the monitory flames
10.251: of lightning: he commands a thousand men
10.252: close lined, with bristling spears, of Pisa all,
10.253: that Tuscan city of Alpheus sprung.
10.254: Then Astur followed, a bold horseman he,
10.255: Astur in gorgeous arms, himself most fair:
10.256: three hundred are his men, one martial mind
10.257: uniting all: in Caere they were bred
10.258: and Minio's plain, and by the ancient towers
10.259: of Pyrgo or Gravisca's storm-swept hill.
10.260: Nor thy renown may I forget, brave chief
10.261: of the Ligurians, Cinyrus; nor thine,
10.262: Cupavo, with few followers, thy crest
10.263: the tall swan-wings, of love unblest the sign
10.264: and of a father fair: for legends tell
10.265: that Cycnus, for his Phaethon so dear
10.266: lamenting loud beneath the poplar shade
10.267: of the changed sisters, made a mournful song
10.268: to soothe his grief and passion: but erewhile,
10.269: in his old age, there clothed him as he sang
10.270: soft snow-white plumes, and spurning earth he soared
10.271: on high, and sped in music through the stars.
10.272: His son with bands of youthful peers urged on
10.273: a galley with a Centaur for its prow,
10.274: which loomed high o'er the waves, and seemed to hurl
10.275: a huge stone at the water, as the keel
10.276: ploughed through the deep. Next Ocnus summoned forth
10.277: a war-host from his native shores, the son
10.278: of Tiber, Tuscan river, and the nymph
10.279: Manto, a prophetess: he gave good walls,
10.280: O Mantua, and his mother's name, to thee,—
10.281: to Mantua so rich in noble sires,
10.282: but of a blood diverse, a triple breed,
10.283: four stems in each; and over all enthroned
10.284: she rules her tribes: her strength is Tuscan born.
10.285: Hate of Mezentius armed against his name
10.286: five hundred men: upon their hostile prow
10.287: was Mincius in a cloak of silvery sedge,—
10.288: Lake Benacus the river's source and sire.
10.289: Last good Aulestes smites the depths below,
10.290: with forest of a hundred oars: the flood
10.291: like flowing marble foams; his Triton prow
10.292: threatens the blue waves with a trumpet-shell;
10.293: far as the hairy flanks its form is man,
10.294: but ends in fish below—the parting waves
10.295: beneath the half-brute bosom break in foam.
10.296: Such chosen chiefs in thirty galleys ploughed
10.297: the salt-wave, bringing help to Trojan arms.
10.298: Day now had left the sky. The moon benign
10.300: to the mid-arch of heaven. Aeneas sate,
10.301: for thought and care allowed him no repose,
10.302: holding the helm and tending his own sails.
10.303: but, as he sped, behold, the beauteous train,
10.304: lately his own, of nymphs, anon transformed
10.305: by kind Cybebe to sea-ruling powers.
10.306: In even ranks they swam the cloven wave,—
10.307: nymphs now, but once as brazen galleys moored
10.308: along the sandy shore. With joy they knew
10.309: their King from far, and with attending train
10.311: best skilled in mortal speech, sped close behind,
10.312: with her right hand upon the stern, uprose
10.313: breast-high, and with her left hand deeply plied
10.314: the silent stream, as to the wondering King
10.315: she called: “So late on watch, O son of Heaven,
10.316: Aeneas? Slack thy sail, but still watch on!
10.317: We were the pine-trees on the holy top
10.318: of Ida's mountain. Sea-nymphs now are we,
10.319: and thine own fleet. When, as we fled, the flames
10.320: rained o'er us from the false Rutulian's hand
10.321: 't was all unwillingly we cast away
10.322: thy serviceable chains: and now once more
10.323: we follow thee across the sea. These forms
10.324: our pitying mother bade us take, with power
10.325: to haunt immortally the moving sea.
10.326: Lo, thy Ascanius lies close besieged
10.327: in moated walls, assailed by threatening arms
10.328: and Latium's front of war. Arcadia,
10.329: her horsemen with the bold Etruscan joined,
10.330: stands at the place appointed. Turnus means,
10.331: with troop opposing, their advance to bar
10.332: and hold them from the camp. Arouse thee, then,
10.333: and with the rising beams of dawn call forth
10.334: thy captains and their followers. Take that shield
10.335: victorious, which for thee the Lord of Fire
10.336: forged for a gift and rimmed about with gold.
10.337: To-morrow's light—deem not my words be vain!—
10.338: shall shine on huge heaps of Rutulia's dead.”
10.339: So saying, she pushed with her right hand the stern
10.340: with skilful thrust, and vanished. The ship sped
10.341: swift as a spear, or as an arrow flies
10.342: no whit behind the wind: and all the fleet
10.343: quickened its course. Anchises' princely son,
10.344: dumb and bewildered stood, but took good heart
10.345: at such an omen fair. Then in few words
10.346: with eyes upturned to heaven he made his prayer:
10.347: “Mother of gods, O Ida's Queen benign,
10.348: who Iovest Dindymus and towns with towers,
10.349: and lion-yokes obedient to thy rein,
10.350: be thou my guide in battle, and fulfil
10.351: thine augury divine. In Phrygia's cause
10.352: be present evermore with favoring power!”
10.353: He spoke no more. For now the wheels of day
10.354: had sped full circle into perfect light,
10.355: the dark expelling. Then, for his first care,
10.356: he bade his captains heed the signal given,
10.357: equip their souls for war, and wait in arms
10.358: the coming fray. Now holds he full in view
10.359: his Trojans and their fortress, as he stands
10.360: upon his towering ship. With his left hand
10.361: he lifts his radiant shield; then from the wall
10.362: the Dardan warriors send a battle-cry
10.363: that echoes to the stars, as kindling hope
10.364: their rage renews. A flight of spears they hurl:
10.365: 't was like the cranes of Strymon, through dark clouds
10.366: each other calling, when they cleave the skies
10.368: the swift south winds—Ioud music them pursues.
10.370: and Turnus, as they gazed. But soon they saw
10.371: ships pointing shoreward and the watery plain
10.372: all stirring with a fleet. Aeneas' helm
10.373: uplifted its bright peak,—like streaming flame
10.374: the crimson crest; his shield of orbed gold
10.375: poured forth prodigious fire: it seemed as when
10.376: in cloudless night a comet's blood-red beam
10.377: makes mournful splendor, or the Dog-star glows,
10.378: which rises to bring drought and pestilence
10.379: to hapless men, and with ill-omened ray
10.380: saddens the sky. But Turnus, undismayed,
10.381: trusted not less to hurl th' invaders back
10.382: and hold the shore against them. “Look!” he cried,
10.383: your prayer is come to pass,—that sword in hand
10.384: ye now may shatter them. The might of Mars
10.385: is in a true man's blow. Remember well
10.386: each man his home and wife! Now call to mind
10.387: the glory and great deeds of all your sires!
10.388: Charge to yon river-bank, while yet they take
10.389: with weak and fearful steps their shoreward way!
10.390: Fortune will help the brave.” With words like these,
10.391: he chose, well-weighing, who should lead the charge,
10.392: who at the leaguered walls the fight sustain.
10.393: Aeneas straightway from his lofty ships
10.394: lets down his troop by bridges. Some await
10.395: the ebbing of slack seas, and boldly leap
10.396: into the shallows; others ply the oar.
10.397: Tarchon a beach discovers, where the sands
10.398: sing not, nor waves with broken murmur fall,
10.399: but full and silent swells the gentle sea.
10.400: Steering in haste that way, he called his crews:
10.401: “Now bend to your stout oars, my chosen brave.
10.402: Lift each ship forward, till her beak shall cleave
10.403: yon hostile shore; and let her keel's full weight
10.404: the furrow drive. I care not if we break
10.405: our ship's side in so sure an anchorage,
10.406: if once we land.” While Tarchon urged them thus,
10.407: the crews bent all together to their blades
10.408: and sped their foaming barks to Latium's plain,
10.409: till each beak gripped the sand and every keel
10.410: lay on dry land unscathed:—all save thine own,
10.411: O Tarchon! dashed upon a sand-bar, she!
10.412: Long poised upon the cruel ridge she hung,
10.413: tilted this way or that and beat the waves,
10.414: then split, and emptied forth upon the tide
10.415: her warriors; and now the drifting wreck
10.416: of shattered oars and thwarts entangles them,
10.417: or ebb of swirling waters sucks them down.
10.418: Turnus no lingering knows, but fiercely hurls
10.419: his whole line on the Teucrians, and makes stand
10.420: along the shore. Now peals the trumpet's call.
10.421: Aeneas in the van led on his troop
10.422: against the rustic foe, bright augury
10.423: for opening war, and laid the Latins low,
10.424: slaughtering Theron, a huge chief who dared
10.425: offer Aeneas battle; through the scales
10.426: of brazen mail and corselet stiff with gold
10.427: the sword drove deep, and gored the gaping side.
10.428: Then smote he Lichas, from his mother's womb
10.429: ripped in her dying hour, and unto thee,
10.430: O Phoebus, vowed, because his infant days
10.431: escaped the fatal steel. Hard by him fell
10.432: stout Cisseus and gigantic Gyas; these
10.433: to death were hurled, while with their knotted clubs
10.434: they slew opposing hosts; but naught availed
10.435: Herculean weapons, nor their mighty hands,
10.436: or that Melampus was their sire, a peer
10.437: of Hercules, what time in heavy toils
10.438: through earth he roved. See next how Pharon boasts!
10.439: But while he vainly raves, the whirling spear
10.440: smites full on his loud mouth. And also thou,
10.441: Cydon, wast by the Trojan stroke o'erthrown,
10.442: while following in ill-omened haste the steps
10.443: of Clytius, thy last joy, whose round cheek wore
10.444: its youthful golden down: soon hadst thou lain
10.445: in death, unheeding of thy fancies fond
10.446: which ever turned to youth;—but now arose
10.447: the troop of all thy brothers, Phorcus' sons,
10.448: a close array of seven, and seven spears
10.449: they hurled: some from Aeneas' helm or shield
10.450: glanced off in vain; some Venus' kindly power,
10.451: just as they touched his body, turned away.
10.452: Aeneas then to true Achates cried:
10.453: “Bring on my spears: not one shall fruitless fly
10.454: against yon Rutules, even as they pierced
10.455: the breasts of Greeks upon the Ilian plain.”
10.456: Then one great shaft he seized and threw; it sped
10.457: straight into Maeon's brazen shield, and clove
10.458: his mail-clad heart. Impetuous to his aid
10.459: brother Alcanor came, and lifted up
10.460: with strong right hand his brother as he fell:
10.461: but through his arm a second skilful shaft
10.462: made bloody way, and by the sinews held
10.463: the lifeless right hand from the shoulder swung.
10.464: Then from his brother's body Numitor
10.465: the weapon plucked and hurled it, furious,
10.466: upon Aeneas; but it could not strike
10.467: the hero's self, and grazed along the thigh
10.468: of great Achates. Next into the fight
10.469: Clausus of Cures came, in youthful bloom
10.471: struck Dryops at the chin, and took away
10.472: from the gashed, shrieking throat both life and voice;
10.473: the warrior's fallen forehead smote the dust;
10.474: his lips poured forth thick blood. There also fell
10.475: three Thracians, odspring of the lordly stem
10.476: of Boreas, and three of Idas' sons
10.477: from Ismara, by various doom struck down.
10.478: Halaesus here his wild Auruncans brings;
10.479: and flying to the fight comes Neptune's son,
10.480: Messapus, famous horseman. On both sides
10.481: each charges on the foe. Ausonia's strand
10.482: is one wide strife. As when o'er leagues of air
10.483: the envious winds give battle to their peers,
10.484: well-matched in rage and power; and neither they
10.485: nor clouds above, nor plunging seas below
10.486: will end the doubtful war, but each withstands
10.487: the onset of the whole—in such wild way
10.488: the line of Trojans on the Latian line
10.489: hurls itself, limb on limb and man on man.
10.490: But at a distance where the river's flood
10.491: had scattered rolling boulders and torn trees
10.492: uprooted from the shore, young Pallas spied
10.493: th' Arcadian band, unused to fight on foot,
10.494: in full retreat, the Latins following close—
10.495: who also for the roughness of the ground
10.496: were all unmounted: he (the last resource
10.497: of men in straits) to wild entreaty turned
10.498: and taunts, enkindling their faint hearts anew:
10.499: “Whither, my men! O, by your own brave deeds,
10.500: O, by our lord Evander's happy wars,
10.501: the proud hopes I had to make my name
10.502: a rival glory,—think not ye can fly!
10.503: Your swords alone can carve ye the safe way
10.504: straight through your foes. Where yonder warrior-throng
10.505: is fiercest, thickest, there and only there
10.506: your Country's honor calls for men like you,
10.507: and for your captain Pallas. Nay, no gods
10.508: against us fight; we are but mortal men
10.509: pressed by a mortal foe. Not more than ours
10.510: the number of their lives or swords. Behold,
10.511: the barrier of yonder spreading sea
10.512: emprisons us, and for a craven flight
10.513: yon lands are all too small. Ha! Shall we steer
10.514: across the sea to Troy?” He said, and sprang
10.515: full in the centre of his gathered foes.
10.516: First in his path was Lagus, thither led
10.517: by evil stars; whom, as he tried to lift
10.518: a heavy stone, the shaft of Pallas pierced
10.519: where ribs and spine divide: backward he drew
10.520: the clinging spear; But Hisbo from above
10.521: surprised him not, though meaning it; for while
10.522: (In anger blind for friend unpitying slain)
10.523: at Pallas' face he flew:—he, standing firm,
10.524: plunged deep into that swelling breast the sword.
10.525: Then Sthenius he slew; and next Anchemolus
10.526: of Rhoetus' ancient line, who dared defile
10.527: his step-dame's bridal bed. And also ye,
10.528: fair Thymber and Larides, Daucus' twins,
10.529: fell on that Rutule field; so like were ye,
10.530: your own kin scarce discerned, and parents proud
10.531: smiled at the dear deceit; but now in death
10.532: cruel unlikeness Pallas wrought; thy head
10.533: fell, hapless Thymber, by Evander's sword;
10.534: and thy right hand, Larides, shorn away,
10.535: seemed feeling for its Iord; the fingers cold
10.536: clutched, trembling, at the sword. Now all the troop
10.537: of Arcady, their chief's great action seen,
10.538: and by his warning roused, made at their foes,
10.539: spurred on by grief and shame. Next Pallas pierced
10.540: the flying Rhoetus in his car; this gained
10.541: for Ilus respite and delay, for him
10.542: the stout spear aimed at; but its flight was stopped
10.543: by Rhoetus, as in swift retreat he rode,
10.544: by the two high-born brothers close pursued,
10.545: Teuthras and Tyres: from his car he rolled,
10.546: making deep furrows with his lifeless heels
10.547: along the Rutule plain. Oft when the winds
10.548: of summer, long awaited, rise and blow,
10.549: a shepherd fires the forest, and the blaze
10.550: devours the dense grove, while o'er the fields,
10.551: in that one moment, swift and sudden spread
10.552: grim Vulcan's serried flames; from some high seat
10.553: on distant hill, the shepherd peering down
10.554: sees, glad at heart, his own victorious fires:
10.555: so now fierce valor spreads, uniting all
10.556: in one confederate rage, 'neath Pallas' eyes.
10.557: But the fierce warrior Halaesus next
10.558: led on the charge, behind his skilful shield
10.560: and Pheres he struck down; his glittering blade
10.561: cut Strymon's hand, which to his neck was raised,
10.562: sheer off; with one great stone he crushed the brows
10.563: of Thoas, scattering wide the broken skull,
10.564: bones, brains, and gore. Halaesus' prophet-sire,
10.565: foreseeing doom, had hid him in dark groves;
10.566: but when the old man's fading eyes declined
10.567: in death, the hand of Fate reached forth and doomed
10.568: the young life to Evander's sword; him now
10.569: Pallas assailed, first offering this prayer:
10.570: “O Father Tiber, give my poising shaft
10.571: through stout Halaesus' heart its lucky way!
10.572: The spoil and trophy of the hero slain
10.573: on thine own oak shall hang.” The god received
10.574: the vow, and while Halaesus held his shield
10.576: lay naked to th' Arcadian's hungry spear.
10.577: But Lausus, seeing such a hero slain,
10.578: bade his troop have no fear, for he himself
10.579: was no small strength in war; and first he slew
10.580: Abas, who fought hard, and had ever seemed
10.581: himself the sticking-point and tug of war.
10.582: Down went Arcadia's warriors, and slain
10.583: etruscans fell, with many a Trojan brave
10.584: the Greek had spared. Troop charges upon troop
10.585: well-matched in might, with chiefs of like renown;
10.586: the last rank crowds the first;—so fierce the press
10.587: scarce hand or sword can stir. Here Pallas stands,
10.588: and pushes back the foe; before him looms
10.589: Lausus, his youthful peer, conspicuous both
10.590: in beauty; but no star will them restore
10.591: to home and native land. Yet would the King
10.592: of high Olympus suffer not the pair
10.593: to close in battle, but each hero found
10.594: a later doom at hands of mightier foes.
10.595: Now Turnus' goddess-sister bids him haste
10.596: to Lausus' help. So he, in wheeling car,
10.597: cut through the lines; and when his friends he saw,
10.598: “Let the fight stop! “ he cried, “for none but I
10.599: may strike at Pallas; unto me alone
10.600: the prize of Pallas falls. I would his sire
10.601: stood by to see.” He spake: his troop withdrew
10.602: a fitting space. But as they made him room,
10.603: the young prince, wondering at the scornful words,
10.604: looked upon Turnus, glancing up and down
10.605: that giant frame, and with fierce-frowning brows
10.606: scanned him from far, hurling defiant words
10.607: in answer to the King's. “My honor now
10.608: shall have the royal trophy of this war,
10.609: or glorious death. For either fortune fair
10.610: my sire is ready. Threaten me no more!”
10.611: So saying, to the midmost space he strode,
10.612: and in Arcadian hearts the blood stood still.
10.613: Swift from his chariot Turnus leaped, and ran
10.614: to closer fight. As when some lion sees
10.615: from his far mountain-lair a raging bull
10.616: that sniffs the battle from the grassy field,
10.617: and down the steep he flies—such picture showed
10.618: grim Turnus as he came. But when he seemed
10.619: within a spear's cast, Pallas opened fight,
10.620: expecting Fortune's favor to the brave
10.621: in such unequal match; and thus he prayed:
10.623: where thou didst enter as a stranger-guest,
10.624: hear me, Alcides, and give aid divine
10.625: to this great deed. Let Turnus see these hands
10.626: strip from his half-dead breast the bloody spoil!
10.627: and let his eyes in death endure to see
10.628: his conqueror!” Alcides heard the youth:
10.629: but prisoned in his heart a deep-drawn sigh,
10.630: and shed vain tears; for Jove, the King and Sire, .
10.631: spoke with benignant accents to his son:
10.632: “To each his day is given. Beyond recall
10.633: man's little time runs by: but to prolong
10.634: life's glory by great deeds is virtue's power.
10.635: Beneath the lofty walls of fallen Troy
10.636: fell many a son of Heaven. Yea, there was slain
10.637: Sarpedon, my own offspring. Turnus too
10.638: is summoned to his doom, and nears the bounds
10.639: of his appointed span.” So speaking, Jove
10.640: turned from Rutulia's war his eyes away.
10.641: But Pallas hurled his lance with might and main,
10.642: and from its hollow scabbard flashed his sword.
10.643: The flying shaft touched where the plated steel
10.644: over the shoulders rose, and worked its way
10.645: through the shield's rim—then falling, glanced aside
10.646: from Turnus' giant body. Turnus then
10.647: poised, without haste, his iron-pointed spear,
10.648: and, launching it on Pallas, cried, “Look now
10.649: will not this shaft a good bit deeper drive?”
10.650: He said: and through the mid-boss of the shield,
10.651: steel scales and brass with bull's-hide folded round,
10.653: and through the corselet's broken barrier
10.654: pierced Pallas' heart. The youth plucked out in vain
10.655: the hot shaft from the wound; his life and blood
10.656: together ebbed away, as sinking prone
10.657: on his rent side he fell; above him rang
10.658: his armor; and from lips with blood defiled
10.659: he breathed his last upon his foeman's ground.
10.661: He cried, “take tidings of this feat of arms
10.662: to King Evander. With a warrior's wage
10.663: his Pallas I restore, and freely grant
10.664: what glory in a hero's tomb may lie,
10.665: or comfort in a grave. They dearly pay
10.666: who bid Aeneas welcome at their board.”
10.667: So saying, with his left foot he held down
10.668: the lifeless form, and raised the heavy weight
10.669: of graven belt, which pictured forth that crime
10.670: of youthful company by treason slain,
10.671: all on their wedding night, in bridal bowers
10.672: to horrid murder given,—which Clonus, son
10.673: of Eurytus, had wrought in lavish gold;
10.674: this Turnus in his triumph bore away,
10.675: exulting in the spoil. O heart of man,
10.676: not knowing doom, nor of events to be!
10.677: Nor, being lifted up, to keep thy bounds
10.678: in prosperous days! To Turnus comes the hour
10.679: when he would fain a prince's ransom give
10.680: had Pallas passed unscathed, and will bewail
10.681: cuch spoil of victory. With weeping now
10.682: and lamentations Ioud his comrades lay
10.683: young Pallas on his shield, and thronging close
10.684: carry him homeward with a mournful song:
10.685: alas! the sorrow and the glorious gain
10.686: thy sire shall have in thee. For one brief day
10.687: bore thee to battle and now bears away;
10.688: yet leavest thou full tale of foemen slain.
10.689: No doubtful rumor to Aeneas breaks
10.690: the direful news, but a sure messenger
10.691: tells him his followers' peril, and implores
10.692: prompt help for routed Troy. His ready sword
10.693: reaped down the nearest foes, and through their line
10.694: clove furious path and broad; the valiant blade
10.695: through oft-repeated bloodshed groped its way,
10.696: proud Turnus, unto thee! His heart beholds
10.697: Pallas and Sire Evander, their kind board
10.698: in welcome spread, their friendly league of peace
10.699: proffered and sealed with him, the stranger-guest.
10.700: So Sulmo's sons, four warriors, and four
10.701: of Ufens sprung, he took alive—to slay
10.702: as victims to the shades, and pour a stream
10.703: of captives' blood upon a flaming pyre.
10.704: Next from afar his hostile shaft he threw
10.705: at Mago, who with wary motion bowed
10.706: beneath the quivering weapon, as it sped
10.707: clean over him; then at Aeneas' knees
10.708: he crouched and clung with supplicating cry:
10.709: “O, by thy father's spirit, by thy hope
10.710: in young Iulus, I implore thee, spare
10.711: for son and father's sake this life of mine.
10.712: A lofty house have I, where safely hid
10.713: are stores of graven silver and good weight
10.714: of wrought and unwrought gold. The fate of war
10.715: hangs not on me; nor can one little life
10.716: thy victory decide.” In answer spoke
10.717: Aeneas: “Hoard the silver and the gold
10.718: for thy own sons. Such bartering in war
10.719: finished with Turnus, when fair Pallas fell.
10.721: He spoke: and, grasping with his mighty left
10.722: the helmet of the vainly suppliant foe,
10.723: bent back the throat and drove hilt-deep his sword.
10.725: priest of Phoebus and pale Trivia, stood,
10.726: whose ribboned brows a sacred fillet bound:
10.727: in shining vesture he, and glittering arms.
10.728: Him too the Trojan met, repelled, and towered
10.729: above the fallen form, o'ermantling it
10.730: in mortal shade; Serestus bore away
10.731: those famous arms a trophy vowed to thee,
10.732: Gradivus, Iord of war! Soon to fresh fight
10.733: came Caeculus, a child of Vulcan's line,
10.734: and Umbro on the Marsic mountains bred:
10.735: these met the Trojan's wrath. His sword shore off
10.736: Anxur's left hand, and the whole orbed shield
10.737: dropped earthward at the stroke: though Anxur's tongue
10.738: had boasted mighty things, as if great words
10.739: would make him strong, and lifting his proud heart
10.740: as high as heaven, had hoped perchance to see
10.741: gray hairs and length of days. Then Tarquitus
10.742: strode forth, exulting in his burnished arms
10.743: (Him Dryope, the nymph, to Faunus bore),
10.744: and dared oppose Aeneas' rage. But he
10.745: drew back his lance and, charging, crushed at once
10.746: corselet and ponderous shield; then off he struck
10.747: the supplicating head, which seemed in vain
10.748: preparing speech; while o'er the reeking corpse
10.749: the victor stood, and thrusting it away
10.750: spoke thus with wrathful soul: “Now lie thou there,
10.751: thou fearsome sight! No noble mother's hand
10.752: shall hide thee in the ground, or give those limbs
10.753: to their ancestral tomb. Thou shalt be left
10.754: to birds of ravin; or go drifting far
10.755: along yon river to engulfing seas,
10.756: where starving fishes on those wounds shall feed.”
10.757: Antceus next and Lucas he pursues,
10.758: though all in Turnus' van; and Numa bold
10.759: and Camers tawny-tressed, the son and heir
10.760: of Volscens the stout-hearted, whose domain
10.761: surpassed the richest of Ausonia's lords,
10.762: when over hushed Amyclae he was king.
10.763: Like old Aegaeon of the hundred arms,
10.764: the hundred-handed, from whose mouths and breasts
10.765: blazed fifty fiery blasts, as he made war
10.766: with fifty sounding shields and fifty swords
10.768: victorious o'er the field, when once his steel
10.769: warmed to its work. But lo, he turns him now
10.771: and coursers four, who, when at furious speed
10.772: they faced his giant stride and dreadful cry,
10.773: upreared in panic, and reversing spilled
10.774: their captain to the ground, and bore away
10.775: the chariot to the river's distant shore.
10.776: Meanwhile, with two white coursers to their car,
10.777: the brothers Lucagus and Liger drove
10.778: into the heart of battle: Liger kept
10.779: with skilful hand the manage of the steeds;
10.780: bold Lucagus swung wide his naked sword.
10.781: Aeneas, by their wrathful brows defied,
10.782: brooked not the sight, but to the onset flew,
10.783: huge-looming, with adverse and threatening spear.
10.785: Nor team of Diomed on Phrygia's plain!
10.786: The last of life and strife shall be thy meed
10.787: upon this very ground.” Such raving word
10.788: flowed loud from Liger's lip: not with a word
10.789: the Trojan hero answered him, but flung
10.790: his whirling spear; and even as Lucagus
10.791: leaned o'er the horses, goading them with steel,
10.792: and, left foot forward, gathered all his strength
10.793: to strike—the spear crashed through the under rim
10.794: of his resplendent shield and entered deep
10.795: in the left groin; then from the chariot fallen,
10.796: the youth rolled dying on the field, while thus
10.797: pious Aeneas paid him taunting words:
10.798: “O Lucagus, thy chariot did not yield
10.799: because of horses slow to fly, or scared
10.800: by shadows of a foe. It was thyself
10.801: leaped o'er the wheel and fled.” So saying, he grasped
10.802: the horses by the rein. The brother then,
10.803: spilled also from the car, reached wildly forth
10.804: his helpless hands: “O, by thy sacred head,
10.805: and by the parents who such greatness gave,
10.806: good Trojan, let me live! Some pity show
10.807: to prostrate me!” But ere he longer sued,
10.808: Aeneas cried, “Not so thy language ran
10.809: a moment gone! Die thou! Nor let this day
10.810: brother from brother part!” Then where the life
10.811: hides in the bosom, he thrust deep his sword.
10.812: Thus o'er the field of war the Dardan King
10.813: moved on, death-dealing: like a breaking flood
10.814: or cloudy whirlwind seemed his wrath. Straightway
10.815: the boy Ascanius from the ramparts came,
10.816: his warriors with him; for the siege had failed.
10.817: Now Jupiter to Juno thus began:
10.819: surely 't is Venus—as thy mind misgave—
10.820: whose favor props—O, what discernment thine!
10.821: Yon Trojan power; not swift heroic hands,
10.822: or souls of fury facing perilous war!”
10.823: Juno made meek reply: “O noblest spouse!
10.824: Why vex one sick at heart, who humbly fears
10.825: thy stern command? If I could claim to-day
10.826: what once I had, my proper right and due,
10.827: love's induence, I should not plead in vain
10.828: to thee, omnipotent, to give me power
10.829: to lead off Turnus from the fight unscathed,
10.830: and save him at his father Daunus' prayer.
10.831: Aye, let him die! And with his loyal blood
10.832: the Teucrians' vengeance feed! Yet he derives
10.833: from our Saturnian stem, by fourth remove
10.834: sprung from Pilumnus. Oft his liberal hands
10.835: have heaped unstinted offering at thy shrine.”
10.836: Thus in few words th' Olympian King replied:
10.837: “If for the fated youth thy prayer implores
10.838: delay and respite of impending doom,
10.839: if but so far thou bidst me interpose,—
10.840: go—favor Turnus' flight, and keep him safe
10.841: in this imperilled hour; I may concede
10.842: such boon. But if thy pleading words intend
10.843: some larger grace, and fain would touch or change
10.844: the issue of the war, then art thou fed
10.845: on expectation vain.” With weeping eyes
10.846: Juno made answer: “Can it be thy mind
10.847: gives what thy words refuse, and Turnus' life,
10.848: if rescued, may endure? Yet afterward
10.849: some cruel close his guiltless day shall see—
10.850: or far from truth I stray! O, that I were
10.851: the dupe of empty fears! and O, that thou
10.852: wouldst but refashion to some happier end
10.853: the things by thee begun—for thou hast power!”
10.854: She ceased; and swiftly from the peak of heaven
10.855: moved earthward, trailing cloud-wrack through the air,
10.856: and girdled with the storm. She took her way
10.857: to where Troy's warriors faced Laurentum's line.
10.858: There of a hollow cloud the goddess framed
10.859: a shape of airy, unsubstantial shade,
10.861: and decked it with a Dardan lance and shield,
10.862: a crested helmet on the godlike head;
10.863: and windy words she gave of soulless sound,
10.864: and motion like a stride—such shapes, they say,
10.865: the hovering phantoms of the dead put on,
10.866: or empty dreams which cheat our slumbering eyes.
10.867: Forth to the front of battle this vain shade
10.868: stalked insolent, and with its voice and spear
10.869: challenged the warrior. At it Turnus flew,
10.870: and hurled a hissing spear with distant aim;
10.871: the thing wheeled round and fled. The foe forthwith,
10.872: thinking Aeneas vanquished, with blind scorn
10.873: flattered his own false hope: “Where wilt thou fly,
10.874: Aeneas? Wilt thou break a bridegroom's word?
10.875: This sword will give thee title to some land
10.876: thou hast sailed far to find!” So clamoring loud
10.877: he followed, flashing far his naked sword;
10.878: nor saw the light winds waft his dream away.
10.879: By chance in covert of a lofty crag
10.880: a ship stood fastened and at rest; her sides
10.881: showed ready bridge and stairway; she had brought
10.882: Osinius, king of Clusium. Thither came
10.883: Aeneas' counterfeit of flight and fear,
10.884: and dropped to darkness. Turnus, nothing loth,
10.885: gave close chase, overleaping every bar,
10.886: and scaling the high bridge; but scarce he reached
10.887: the vessel's prow, when Juno cut her loose,
10.888: the cables breaking, and along swift waves
10.889: pushed her to sea. Yet in that very hour
10.890: Aeneas to the battle vainly called
10.891: the vanished foe, and round his hard-fought path
10.892: stretched many a hero dead. No longer now
10.893: the mocking shadow sought to hide, but soared
10.894: visibly upward and was Iost in cloud,
10.895: while Turnus drifted o'er the waters wide
10.896: before the wind. Bewildered and amazed
10.897: he looked around him; little joy had he
10.898: in his own safety, but upraised his hands
10.899: in prayer to Heaven: “O Sire omnipotent!
10.900: Didst thou condemn me to a shame like this?
10.902: Whence came I here? What panic wafts away
10.903: this Turnus—if 't is he? Shall I behold
10.904: Laurentum's towers once more? But what of those
10.905: my heroes yonder, who took oath to me,
10.906: and whom—O sin and shame!—I have betrayed
10.908: I see them routed, and my ears receive
10.909: their dying groans. What is this thing I do?
10.910: Where will the yawning earth crack wide enough
10.911: beneath my feet? Ye tempests, pity me!
10.912: On rocks and reef—'t is Turnus' faithful prayer,
10.913: let this bark founder; fling it on the shoals
10.914: of wreckful isles, where no Rutulian eye
10.915: can follow me, or Rumor tell my shame.”
10.916: With such wild words his soul tossed to and fro,
10.917: not knowing if to hide his infamy
10.918: with his own sword and madly drive its blade
10.919: home to his heart, or cast him in the sea,
10.920: and, swimming to the rounded shore, renew
10.921: his battle with the Trojan foe. Three times
10.922: each fatal course he tried; but Juno's power
10.923: three times restrained, and with a pitying hand
10.924: the warrior's purpose barred. So on he sped
10.925: o'er yielding waters and propitious tides,
10.926: far as his father Daunus' ancient town.
10.927: At Jove's command Mezentius, breathing rage,
10.928: now takes the field and leads a strong assault
10.929: against victorious Troy. The Tuscan ranks
10.930: meet round him, and press hard on him alone,
10.931: on him alone with vengeance multiplied
10.932: their host of swords they draw. As some tall cliff,
10.933: projecting to the sea, receives the rage
10.934: of winds and waters, and untrembling bears
10.935: vast, frowning enmity of seas and skies,—
10.936: so he. First Dolichaon's son he slew,
10.937: Hebrus; then Latagus and Palmus, though
10.938: they fled amain; he smote with mighty stone
10.939: torn from the mountain, full upon the face
10.940: of Latagus; and Palmus he let lie
10.941: hamstrung and rolling helpless; he bestowed
10.942: the arms on his son Lausus for a prize,
10.943: another proud crest in his helm to wear;
10.944: he laid the Phrygian Euanthus Iow;
10.945: and Mimas, Paris' comrade, just his age,—
10.946: born of Theano's womb to Amycus
10.947: his sire, that night when royal Hecuba,
10.948: teeming with firebrand, gave Paris birth:
10.949: one in the city of his fathers sleeps;
10.950: and one, inglorious, on Laurentian strand.
10.951: As when a wild boar, harried from the hills
10.952: by teeth of dogs (one who for many a year
10.953: was safe in pine-clad Vesulus, or roamed
10.954: the meres of Tiber, feeding in the reeds)
10.955: falls in the toils at last, and stands at bay,
10.956: raging and bristling, and no hunter dares
10.957: defy him or come near, but darts are hurled
10.958: from far away, with cries unperilous:
10.959: not otherwise, though righteous is their wrath
10.960: against Mezentius, not a man so bold
10.961: as face him with drawn sword, but at long range
10.962: they throw their shafts and with loud cries assail;
10.963: he, all unterrified, makes frequent stand,
10.964: gnashing his teeth, and shaking off their spears.
10.965: From ancient Corythus had Acron come,
10.966: a Greek, who left half-sung his wedding-song,
10.967: and was an exile; him Mezentius saw
10.968: among long lines of foes, with flaunting plumes
10.969: and purple garments from his plighted spouse.
10.970: Then as a starving lion when he prowls
10.971: about high pasture-lands, urged on his way
10.972: by maddening hunger (if perchance he see
10.973: a flying she-goat or tall-antlered stag)
10.974: lifts up his shaggy mane, and gaping wide
10.975: his monstrous jaws, springs at the creature's side,
10.977: so through his gathered foes Mezentius
10.978: flew at his prey. He stretched along the ground
10.979: ill-fated Acron, who breathed life away,
10.980: beating the dark dust with his heels, and bathed
10.981: his broken weapons in his blood. Nor deigned
10.983: as he took flight, nor deal a wound unseen
10.984: with far-thrown spear; but ran before his face,
10.985: fronting him man to man, nor would he win
10.986: by sleight or trick, but by a mightier sword.
10.987: Soon on the fallen foe he set his heel,
10.988: and, pushing hard, with heel and spear, cried out:
10.989: “Look ye, my men, where huge Orodes lies,
10.990: himself a dangerous portion of this war!”
10.991: With loyal, Ioud acclaim his peers reply;
10.992: but thus the dying hero: “Victor mine,
10.993: whoe'er thou art, I fall not unavenged!
10.994: Thou shalt but triumph for a fleeting hour.
10.995: Like doom for thee is written. Speedily
10.996: thou shalt this dust inhabit, even as I!”
10.997: Mezentius answered him with wrathful smile:
10.998: “Now die! What comes on me concerns alone
10.999: the Sire of gods and Sovereign of mankind.”
10.1000: So saying, from the wounded breast he plucked
10.1001: his javelin: and on those eyes there fell
10.1003: and in unending night their vision closed.
10.1006: Parthenius and Orses stout and strong;
10.1007: Messapus, good blade cut down Clonius
10.1009: the one from an unbridled war-horse thrown,
10.1010: the other slain dismounted. Then rode forth
10.1011: Agis the Lycian, but bold Valerus,
10.1012: true to his valiant breeding, hurled him down;
10.1013: having slain Thronius, Salius was slain
10.1014: by skilled Nealces, of illustrious name
10.1015: for spear well cast and far-surprising bow.
10.1016: Thus Mars relentless holds in equal scale
10.1018: the victors and the vanquished kill or fall
10.1019: in equal measure; neither knows the way
10.1020: to yield or fly. Th' Olympians Iook down
10.1021: out of Jove's house, and pity as they see
10.1022: the unavailing wrath of either foe,
10.1023: and burdens measureless on mortals laid.
10.1024: Lo! Venus here, Saturnian Juno yon,
10.1025: in anxious watch; while pale Tisiphone
10.1026: moves on infuriate through the battling lines.
10.1027: On strode Mezentius o'er the gory plain,
10.1028: and swollen with rage waved wide-his awful spear.
10.1029: Like tall Orion when on foot he goes
10.1030: trough the deep sea and lifts his shoulders high
10.1031: above the waves; or when he takes his path
10.1032: along the mountain-tops, and has for staff
10.1033: an aged ash-tree, as he fixes firm
10.1034: his feet in earth and hides his brows in cloud;—
10.1035: so Ioomed Mezentius with his ponderous arms.
10.1036: To match him now, Aeneas, Iooking down
10.1037: the long array of war, came forth in arms
10.1038: to challenge and defy. But quailing not,
10.1039: a mass immovable, the other stood
10.1040: waiting his noble foe, and with a glance
10.1041: measured to cast his spear the space between.
10.1042: “May this right hand“, he said, “and this swift spear
10.1043: which here I poise, be favoring gods for me!
10.1044: The spoils from yonder robber's carcase stripped
10.1045: I vow to hang on thee, my Lausus, thou
10.1046: shalt stand for trophy of Aeneas slain.”
10.1047: He said, and hurled from far the roaring spear,
10.1048: which from the shield glanced off, and speeding still
10.1049: smote famed Antores 'twixt the loin and side—
10.1050: antores, friend of Hercules, who came
10.1051: from Argos, and had joined Evander's cause,
10.1052: abiding in Italia. Lo, a wound
10.1053: meant for another pierced him, and he lay,
10.1054: ill-fated! Iooking upward to the light,
10.1055: and dreaming of dear Argos as he died.
10.1056: Then good Aeneas hurled his spear; it passed
10.1057: through hollow orb of triple bronze, and through
10.1058: layers of flax and triple-twisted hides;
10.1059: then in the lower groin it lodged, but left
10.1060: its work undone. Aeneas, not ill-pleased
10.1061: to see the Tuscan wounded, swiftly drew
10.1062: the falchion from his thigh, and hotly pressed
10.1063: his startled foe. But Lausus at the sight
10.1064: groaned loud, so much he loved his father dear,
10.1065: and tears his cheek bedewed. O storied youth!
10.1066: If olden worth may win believing ear,
10.1067: let not my song now fail of thee to sing,
10.1068: thy noble deeds, thy doom of death and pain!
10.1070: fell backward, trailing from the broken shield
10.1071: his foeman's spear. His son leaped wildly forth
10.1072: to join the fray; and where Aeneas' hand
10.1073: lifted to strike, he faced the thrusting sword
10.1074: and gave the hero pause. His comrades raised
10.1075: applauding cries, as shielded by his son
10.1076: the father made retreat; their darts they hurl,
10.1077: and vex with flying spears the distant foe:
10.1078: Aeneas, wrathful, stands beneath his shield.
10.1079: As when the storm-clouds break in pelting hail,
10.1080: the swains and ploughmen from the furrows fly,
10.1081: and every traveller cowers in sure defence
10.1082: of river-bank or lofty shelving crag,
10.1083: while far and wide it pours; and by and by,
10.1084: each, when the sun returns, his task pursues:
10.1085: so great Aeneas, by assault o'erwhelmed,
10.1086: endured the cloud of battle, till its rage
10.1087: thundered no more; then with a warning word
10.1088: to Lausus with upbraiding voice he called:
10.1089: “Why, O death-doomed, rush on to deeds too high
10.1090: for strength like thine. Thou art betrayed, rash boy,
10.1091: by thine own loyal heart!” But none the less
10.1092: the youth made mad defence; while fiercer burned
10.1093: the Trojan's anger; and of Lausus' days
10.1094: the loom of Fate spun forth the last thin thread;
10.1095: for now Aeneas thrust his potent blade
10.1096: deep through the stripling's breast and out of sight;
10.1097: through the light shield it passed—a frail defence
10.1098: to threaten with!—and through the tunic fine
10.1099: his mother's hand had wrought with softest gold:
10.1100: blood filled his bosom, and on path of air
10.1101: down to the shades the mournful soul withdrew,
10.1102: its body quitting. As Anchises' son
10.1103: beheld the agonizing lips and brow
10.1104: so wondrous white in death, he groaned aloud
10.1105: in pity, and reached o'er him his right hand,
10.1106: touched to the heart such likeness to behold
10.1107: of his own filial love. “Unhappy boy!
10.1108: What reward worthy of heroic deeds
10.1109: can I award thee now? Wear still those arms
10.1110: so proudly worn! And I will send thee home
10.1111: (Perhaps thou carest!) to the kindred shades
10.1112: and ashes of thy sires. But let it be
10.1113: some solace in thy pitiable doom
10.1114: that none but great Aeneas wrought thy fall.”
10.1115: Then to the stripling's tardy followers
10.1116: he sternly called, and lifted from the earth
10.1117: with his own hand the fallen foe: dark blood
10.1118: defiled those princely tresses braided fair.
10.1119: Meanwhile Mezentius by the Tiber's wave
10.1120: with water staunched his wound, and propped his weight
10.1121: against a tree; upon its limbs above
10.1122: his brazen helmet hung, and on the sward
10.1123: his ponderous arms lay resting. Round him watched
10.1124: his chosen braves. He, gasping and in pain,
10.1125: clutched at his neck and let his flowing beard
10.1126: loose on his bosom fall; he questions oft
10.1127: of Lausus, and sends many a messenger
10.1128: to bid him back, and bear him the command
10.1129: of his sore-grieving sire. But lo! his peers
10.1130: bore the dead Lausus back upon his shield,
10.1131: and wept to see so strong a hero quelled
10.1132: by stroke so strong. From long way off the sire,
10.1133: with soul prophetic of its woe, perceived
10.1134: what meant their wail and cry. On his gray hairs
10.1135: the dust he flung, and, stretching both his hands
10.1136: to heaven, he cast himself the corpse along.
10.1137: “O son,” he cried, “was life to me so sweet,
10.1138: that I to save myself surrendered o'er
10.1139: my own begotten to a foeman's steel?
10.1140: Saved by these gashes shall thy father be,
10.1141: and living by thy death? O wretched me,
10.1142: how foul an end have I! Now is my wound
10.1143: deep! deep! 't was I, dear son, have stained
10.1144: thy name with infamy—to exile driven
10.1146: by general curse. Would that myself had borne
10.1147: my country's vengeance and my nation's hate!
10.1148: Would my own guilty life my debt had paid—
10.1149: yea, by a thousand deaths! But, see, I live!
10.1150: Not yet from human kind and light of day
10.1151: have I departed. But depart I will.”
10.1152: So saying, he raised him on his crippled thigh,
10.1153: and though by reason of the grievous wound
10.1154: his forces ebbed, yet with unshaken mien
10.1155: he bade them lead his war-horse forth, his pride,
10.1156: his solace, which from every war
10.1157: victorious bore him home. The master then
10.1158: to the brave beast, which seemed to know his pain,
10.1159: spoke thus: “My Rhoebus, we have passed our days
10.1160: long time together, if long time there be
10.1161: for mortal creatures. Either on this day
10.1162: thou shalt his bloody spoils in triumph bear
10.1163: and that Aeneas' head,—and so shalt be
10.1164: avenger of my Lausus' woe; or else,
10.1165: if I be vanquished, thou shalt sink and fall
10.1166: beside me. For, my bravest, thou wouldst spurn
10.1167: a stranger's will, and Teucrian lords to bear.”
10.1168: He spoke and, mounting to his back, disposed
10.1169: his limbs the wonted way and filled both hands
10.1170: with pointed javelins; a helm of brass
10.1171: with shaggy horse-hair crest gleamed o'er his brow.
10.1172: Swift to the front he rode: a mingled flood
10.1173: surged in his heart of sorrow, wrath, and shame;
10.1174: and thrice with loud voice on his foe he called.
10.1175: Aeneas heard and made exulting vow:
10.1176: “Now may the Father of the gods on high,
10.1177: and great Apollo hear! Begin the fray!”
10.1178: He said, and moved forth with a threatening spear.
10.1179: The other cried: “Hast robbed me of my son,
10.1180: and now, implacable, wouldst fright me more?
10.1181: That way, that only, was it in thy power
10.1182: to cast me down. No fear of death I feel.
10.1183: Nor from thy gods themselves would I refrain.
10.1184: Give o'er! For fated and resolved to die
10.1185: I come thy way: but; bring thee as I pass
10.1186: these offerings.” With this he whirled a spear
10.1187: against his foe, and after it drove deep
10.1189: in wide gyration round him. But the shield,
10.1190: the golden boss, broke not. Three times he rode
10.1191: in leftward circles, hurling spear on spear
10.1192: against th' unmoved Aeneas: and three times
10.1193: the Trojan hero in his brazen shield
10.1194: the sheaf of spears upbore. But such slow fight,
10.1195: such plucking of spent shafts from out his shield,
10.1196: the Trojan liked not, vexed and sorely tried
10.1197: in duel so ill-matched. With wrathful soul
10.1198: at length he strode forth, and between the brows
10.1199: of the wild war-horse planted his Iong spear.
10.1200: Up reared the creature, beating at the air
10.1201: with quivering feet, then o'er his fallen lord
10.1202: entangling dropped, and prone above him lay,
10.1203: pinning with ponderous shoulder to the ground.
10.1204: The Trojans and the Latins rouse the skies
10.1205: with clamor Ioud. Aeneas hastening forth
10.1206: unsheathes his sword, and looming o'er him cries:
10.1207: “Where now is fierce Mezentius, and his soul's
10.1208: wild pulse of rage?” The Tuscan in reply
10.1209: with eyes uprolled, and gasping as he gave
10.1210: long looks at heaven, recalled his fading mind:
10.1211: “Why frown at me and fume, O bitterest foe?
10.1212: Why threaten death? To slay me is no sin.
10.1213: Not to take quarter came I to this war,
10.1214: not truce with thee did my lost Lausus crave,
10.1215: yet this one boon I pray,—if mercy be
10.1216: for fallen foes: O, suffer me when dead
10.1217: in covering earth to hide! Full well I know
10.1218: what curses of my people ring me round.
10.1219: Defend me from that rage! I pray to be
10.1220: my son's companion in our common tomb.”
10.1221: He spoke: then offered with unshrinking eye
10.1222: his veined throat to the sword. O'er the bright mail
10.1223: his vital breath gushed forth in streaming gore.

11.1: Up from the sea now soared the dawning day:
11.2: Aeneas, though his sorrow bids him haste
11.3: to burial of the slain, and his sad soul
11.4: is clouded with the sight of death, fulfils,
11.5: for reward to his gods, a conqueror's vow,
11.6: at morning's earliest beam. A mighty oak
11.7: shorn of its limbs he sets upon a hill
11.8: and clothes it o'er with glittering arms, the spoil
11.9: of King Mezentius, and a trophy proud
11.10: to thee, great lord of war. The hero's plumes
11.11: bedewed with blood are there, and splintered spears;
11.12: there hangs the corselet, by the thrusting steel
11.13: twelve times gored through; upon the left he binds
11.14: the brazen shield, and from the neck suspends
11.16: as crowding close his train of captains throng,
11.18: our largest work is done. Bid fear begone
11.19: of what is left to do. Behold the spoils!
11.20: Yon haughty King was firstfruits of our war.
11.21: See this Mezentius my hands have made!
11.22: Now to the Latin town and King we go.
11.23: Arm you in soul! With heart of perfect hope
11.24: prepare the war! So when the gods give sign
11.25: to open battle and lead forth our brave
11.26: out of this stronghold, no bewilderment,
11.27: nor tarrying, nor fearful, faltering mind
11.28: shall slack our march. Meanwhile in earth we lay
11.29: our comrades fallen; for no honor else
11.30: in Acheron have they. Go forth,” said he,
11.31: “bring gifts of honor and of last farewell
11.32: to those high hearts by shedding of whose blood
11.33: our country lives. To sad Evander's town
11.34: bear Pallas first; who, though he did not fail
11.35: of virtue's crown, was seized by doom unblest,
11.36: and to the bitterness of death consigned.”
11.37: Weeping he spoke, and slowly backward drew
11.38: to the tent-door, where by the breathless clay
11.39: of Pallas stood Acoetes, aged man,
11.40: once bearer of Evander's arms, but now
11.41: under less happy omens set to guard
11.42: his darling child. Around him is a throng
11.43: of slaves, with all the Trojan multitude,
11.44: and Ilian women, who the wonted way
11.45: let sorrow's tresses loosely flow. When now
11.46: Aeneas to the lofty doors drew near,
11.47: all these from smitten bosoms raised to heaven
11.48: a mighty moaning, till the King's abode
11.49: was loud with anguish. There Aeneas viewed
11.50: the pillowed head of Pallas cold and pale,
11.51: the smooth young breast that bore the gaping wound
11.52: of that Ausonian spear, and weeping said:
11.53: “Did Fortune's envy, smiling though she came,
11.54: refuse me, hapless boy, that thou shouldst see
11.55: my throne established, and victorious ride
11.56: beside me to thy father's house? Not this
11.57: my parting promise to thy King and sire,
11.58: Evander, when with friendly, fond embrace
11.59: to win imperial power he bade me go;
11.60: yet warned me anxiously I must resist
11.61: bold warriors and a stubborn breed of foes.
11.62: And haply even now he cheats his heart
11.63: with expectation vain, and offers vows,
11.64: heaping with gifts the altars of his gods.
11.65: But we with unavailing honors bring
11.66: this lifeless youth, who owes the gods of heaven
11.67: no more of gift and vow. O ill-starred King!
11.68: Soon shalt thou see thy son's unpitying doom!
11.69: What a home-coming! This is glory's day
11.70: so Iong awaited; this the solemn pledge
11.71: I proudly gave. But fond Evander's eyes
11.72: will find no shameful wounding on the slain,
11.73: nor for a son in coward safety kept
11.74: wilt thou, the sire, crave death. But woe is me!
11.75: How strong a bulwark in Ausonia falls!
11.76: What loss is thine, Iulus!” Thus lamenting,
11.77: he bids them lift the body to the bier,
11.78: and sends a thousand heroes from his host
11.79: to render the last tributes, and to share
11.80: father's tears:—poor solace and too small
11.81: for grief so great, but due that mournful sire.
11.82: Some busy them to build of osiers fine
11.83: the simple litter, twining sapling oaks
11.84: with evergreen, till o'er death's Iofty bed
11.85: the branching shade extends. Upon it lay,
11.86: as if on shepherd's couch, the youthful dead,
11.87: like fairest flower by virgin fingers culled,
11.89: of color still undimmed and leaf unmarred;
11.90: but from the breast of mother-earth no more
11.91: its life doth feed. Then good Aeneas brought
11.92: two broidered robes of scarlet and fine gold,
11.93: which with the gladsome labor of her hands
11.94: Sidonian Dido wrought him long ago,
11.95: the thin-spun gold inweaving. One of these
11.96: the sad prince o'er the youthful body threw
11.97: for parting gift; and with the other veiled
11.98: those tresses from the fire; he heaped on high
11.99: Laurentum's spoils of war, and bade to bring
11.100: much tribute forth: horses and arms he gave,
11.101: seized from the fallen enemy; with hands
11.102: fettered behind them filed a captive train
11.103: doomed to appease the shades, and with the flames
11.104: to mix their flowing blood. He bade his chiefs
11.105: set up the trunks of trees and clothe them well
11.106: with captured arms, inscribing on each one
11.107: some foeman's name. Then came Acoetes forth,
11.108: a wretched, worn old man, who beat his breast
11.109: with tight-clenched hands, and tore his wrinkled face
11.110: with ruthless fingers; oft he cast him down
11.111: full length along the ground. Then lead they forth
11.112: the blood-stained Rutule chariots of war;
11.113: Aethon, the war-horse, of his harness bare,
11.114: walks mournful by; big teardrops wet his cheek.
11.115: Some bear the lance and helm; for all the rest
11.116: victorious Turnus seized. Then filed along
11.117: a mournful Teucrian cohort; next the host
11.118: Etrurian and the men of Arcady
11.119: with trailing arms reversed. Aeneas now,
11.120: when the long company had passed him by,
11.121: spoke thus and groaned aloud: “Ourselves from hence
11.122: are summoned by the same dread doom of war
11.125: I bid thee hail, farewell!” In silence then
11.126: back to the stronghold's Iofty walls he moved.
11.127: Now envoys from the Latin citadel
11.128: came olive-crowned, to plead for clemency:
11.129: would he not yield those bodies of the dead
11.130: sword-scattered o'er the plain, and let them lie
11.131: beneath an earth-built tomb? Who wages war
11.132: upon the vanquished, the unbreathing slain?
11.133: To people once his hosts and kindred called,
11.134: would he not mercy show? To such a prayer,
11.135: deemed not unworthy, good Aeneas gave
11.136: the boon, and this benignant answer made:
11.138: has snared you in so vast a war, that now
11.139: you shun our friendship? Have you here implored
11.140: peace for your dead, by chance of battle fallen?
11.141: Pain would I grant it for the living too.
11.142: I sailed not hither save by Heaven's decree,
11.143: which called me to this land. I wage no war
11.144: with you, the people; 't was your King refused
11.145: our proffered bond of peace, and gave his cause
11.146: to Turnus' arms. More meet and just it were
11.147: had Turnus met this death that makes you mourn.
11.148: If he would end our quarrel sword in hand,
11.149: thrusting us Teucrians forth, 't was honor's way
11.150: to cross his blade with mine; that man to whom
11.151: the gods, or his own valor, had decreed
11.152: the longer life, had lived. But now depart!
11.153: Beneath your lost friends light the funeral fires!”
11.154: So spoke Aeneas; and with wonder mute
11.155: all stood at gaze, each turning to behold
11.156: his neighbor's face. Then Drances, full of years,
11.157: and ever armed with spite and slanderous word
11.158: against young Turnus, made this answering plea:
11.159: “O prince of mighty name, whose feats of arms
11.160: are even mightier! Trojan hero, how
11.161: shall my poor praise exalt thee to the skies?
11.162: Is it thy rectitude or strenuous war
11.163: most bids me wonder? We will bear thy word
11.164: right gladly to the city of our sires;
11.165: and there, if Fortune favor it, contrive
11.166: a compact with the Latin King. Henceforth
11.167: let Turnus find his own allies! Ourselves
11.168: will much rejoice to see thy destined walls,
11.169: and our own shoulders will be proud to bear
11.170: the stone for building Troy.” Such speech he made,
11.171: and all the common voice consented loud.
11.172: So twelve days' truce they swore, and safe from harm
11.174: together o'er the wooded hills. Now rang
11.175: loud steel on ash-tree bole; enormous pines,
11.176: once thrusting starward, to the earth they threw;
11.177: and with industrious wedge asunder clove
11.178: stout oak and odorous cedar, piling high
11.179: harvest of ash-trees on the creaking wain.
11.180: Now Rumor, herald of prodigious woe,
11.181: to King Evander hied, Evander's house
11.182: and city filling, where, but late, her word
11.183: had told in Latium Pallas' victory.
11.184: th' Arcadians thronging to the city-gates
11.185: bear funeral torches, the accustomed way;
11.186: in lines of flame the long street flashes far,
11.187: lighting the fields beyond. To meet them moves
11.188: a Phrygian company, to join with theirs
11.189: its lamentation loud. The Latin wives,
11.190: soon as they saw them entering, aroused
11.191: the whole sad city with shrill songs of woe.
11.192: No hand could stay Evander. Forth he flew
11.193: into the midmost tumult, and fell prone
11.194: on his dead Pallas, on the resting bier;
11.195: he clung to the pale corse with tears, with groans,
11.196: till anguish for a space his lips unsealed:
11.197: “Not this thy promise, Pallas, to thy sire,
11.198: to walk not rashly in the war-god's way.
11.199: I knew too well how honor's morning-star,
11.200: and sweet, foretasted glory tempt and woo
11.201: in a first battle. O first-fruit forlorn
11.202: of youth so fair! O prelude pitiless
11.203: of war approaching! O my vows and prayers,
11.204: which not one god would hear! My blessed wife,
11.205: how happy was the death that spared thee not
11.206: to taste this bitterness! But I, the while,
11.207: by living longer lived to meet my doom,—
11.208: a father sole-surviving. Would I myself
11.209: had perished by the Rutule's cruel spear,
11.210: the Trojan's cause espousing! This breath of life
11.211: how gladly had I given! And O, that now
11.212: yon black solemnity were bearing home
11.213: myself, not Pallas, dead! Yet blame I not,
11.214: O Teucrians, the hallowed pact we made,
11.215: nor hospitable bond and clasp of hands.
11.216: This doom ye bring me was writ long ago,
11.217: for my old age. And though my child is fallen
11.218: untimely, I take comfort that he fell
11.219: where thousands of the Volscians slaughtered lie,
11.220: and into Latium led the Teucrian arms.
11.221: What brighter glory could I crave in death
11.222: for thee, my Pallas, than Aeneas brings,
11.223: and Phrygian princes, and Etrurian lords
11.224: with all Etruria's legions? Lo, they bear
11.225: yon glittering spoils of victims of thy sword!
11.226: Thou, Turnus, too, wert now an effigy
11.227: in giant armor clad, if but his years
11.228: and strength full ripe had been fair match for thine!
11.229: But now my woes detain the Trojan host
11.230: from battle. I beseech ye haste away,
11.231: and bear this faithful message to your King:
11.232: since I but linger out a life I loathe,
11.233: without my Pallas, nothing but thy sword
11.234: can bid me live. Then let thy sword repay
11.235: its debt to sire and son by Turnus slain!
11.236: Such deed alone may with thy honor fit,
11.237: and happier fortunes. But my life to me
11.238: has no joy left to pray for, save to bring
11.239: my son that solace in the shadowy land.”
11.240: Meanwhile o'er sorrowing mortals the bright morn
11.241: had lifted her mild beam, renewing so
11.242: the burden of man's toil. Aeneas now
11.243: built funeral pyres along the winding shore,
11.244: King Tarchon at his side. Each thither brought
11.245: the bodies of his kin, observing well
11.246: all ancient ritual. The fuming fires
11.247: burned from beneath, till highest heaven was hid
11.248: in blackest, overmantling cloud. Three times
11.249: the warriors, sheathed in proud, resplendent steel,
11.250: paced round the kindling pyres; and three times
11.251: fair companies of horsemen circled slow,
11.252: with loud lamenting, round the doleful flame.
11.253: The wail of warriors and the trumpets' blare
11.254: the very welkin rend. Cast on the flames
11.255: are spoils of slaughtered Latins,—helms and blades,
11.256: bridles and chariot-wheels. Yet others bring
11.257: gifts to the dead familiar, their own shields
11.258: and unavailing spears. Around them slain
11.259: great herds of kine give tribute unto death:
11.260: swine, bristly-backed, from many a field are borne,
11.261: and slaughtered sheep bleed o'er the sacred fire.
11.262: So on the shore the wailing multitude
11.263: behold their comrades burning, and keep guard
11.264: o'er the consuming pyres, nor turn away
11.265: till cooling night re-shifts the globe of heaven,
11.267: Likewise the mournful Latins far away
11.268: have built their myriad pyres. Yet of the slain
11.269: not few in graves are laid, and borne with tears
11.270: to neighboring country-side or native town;
11.271: the rest—promiscuous mass of dead unknown—
11.272: to nameless and unhonored ashes burn;
11.273: with multitude of fires the far-spread fields
11.274: blaze forth unweariedly. But when from heaven
11.275: the third morn had dispelled the dark and cold,
11.276: the mournful bands raked forth the mingled bones
11.277: and plenteous ashes from the smouldering pyres,
11.278: then heaped with earth the one sepulchral mound.
11.279: Now from the hearth-stones of the opulent town
11.280: of old Latinus a vast wail burst forth,
11.281: for there was found the chief and bitterest share
11.282: of all the woe. For mothers in their tears,
11.283: lone brides, and stricken souls of sisters fond,
11.284: and boys left fatherless, fling curses Ioud
11.285: on Turnus' troth-plight and the direful war:
11.286: “Let him, let Turnus, with his single sword
11.287: decide the strife,”—they cry,—“and who shall claim
11.288: Lordship of Italy and power supreme.”
11.289: Fierce Drances whets their fury, urging all
11.290: that Turnus singly must the challenge hear,
11.291: and singly wage the war; but others plead
11.292: in Turnus' favor; the Queen's noble name
11.293: protects him, and his high renown in arms
11.294: defends his cause with well-won trophies fair.
11.295: Amid these tumults of the wrathful throng,
11.297: arrive with cloudy forehead from their quest
11.298: in his illustrious town; for naught availed
11.299: their toilsome errand, nor the gifts and gold,
11.300: nor strong entreaty. Other help in war
11.301: the Latins now must find, or humbly sue
11.302: peace from the Trojan. At such tidings dire
11.304: and influence of gods too visible
11.305: sustain Aeneas; so the wrath divine
11.307: give warning clear. Therefore the King convenes
11.308: a general council of his captains brave
11.309: beneath the royal towers. They, gathering,
11.310: throng the approaches thither, where their Iord,
11.311: gray-haired Latinus, takes the central throne,
11.313: He bids the envoys from Aetolia's King
11.314: sent back, to speak and tell the royal words
11.315: in order due. Forthwith on every tongue
11.316: fell silence, while the princely Venulus,
11.317: heeding his Iord's behest, began the parle:
11.318: “My countrymen,” he said, “our eyes have seen
11.319: strongholds of Greeks and Diomed the King.
11.320: We braved all perils to our journey's end
11.321: and clasped that hand whereof the dreadful stroke
11.322: wrought Ilium's fall. The hero built a town,
11.324: near mount Garganus in Apulian land:
11.325: passing that city's portal and the King's,
11.326: we found free audience, held forth thy gifts,
11.327: and told our names and fatherland. We showed
11.328: what condict was enkindled, and what cause
11.329: brought us to Arpi's King. He, hearing all,
11.330: with brow benign made answer to our plea:
11.331: ‘O happy tribes in Saturn's kingdom born,
11.332: Ausonia's ancient stem! What fortune blind
11.333: tempts ye from peace away, and now ensnares
11.334: in wars unknown? Look how we men that dared
11.335: lay Ilium waste (I speak not of what woes
11.336: in battling neath her lofty walls we bore,
11.337: nor of dead warriors sunk in Simois' wave)
11.338: have paid the penalty in many a land
11.339: with chastisement accurst and changeful woe,
11.340: till Priam's self might pity. Let the star
11.341: of Pallas tell its tale of fatal storm,
11.342: off grim Caphereus and Eubcea's crags.
11.343: Driven asunder from one field of war,
11.345: and wise Ulysses saw from Aetna's caves
11.346: the Cyclops gathering. Why name the throne
11.347: of Pyrrhus, or the violated hearth
11.348: whence fled Idomeneus? Or Locri cast
11.349: on Libya's distant shore? For even he,
11.350: Lord of Mycenae by the Greeks obeyed,
11.351: fell murdered on his threshold by the hand
11.352: of that polluted wife, whose paramour
11.353: trapped Asia's conqueror. The envious gods
11.354: withheld me also from returning home
11.355: to see once more the hearth-stone of my sires,
11.356: the wife I yearn for, and my Calydon,
11.357: the beauteous land. For wonders horrible
11.358: pursue me still. My vanished followers
11.359: through upper air take wing, or haunt and rove
11.360: in forms of birds the island waters o'er:
11.361: ah me, what misery my people feel!
11.362: The tall rocks ring with their lament and cry.
11.363: Naught else had I to hope for from that day
11.364: when my infatuate sword on gods I drew,
11.366: the hand of Venus. Urge me not, I pray,
11.367: to conflicts in this wise. No more for me
11.368: of war with Trojans after Ilium's fall!
11.369: I take no joy in evils past, nor wish
11.370: such memory to renew. Go, lay these gifts,
11.371: brought to my honor from your ancient land,
11.372: at great Aeneas' feet. We twain have stood
11.374: in mortal fray. Believe me, I have known
11.375: the stature of him when he lifts his shield,
11.376: and swings the whirlwind of his spear. If Troy
11.377: two more such sons had bred, the Dardan horde
11.378: had stormed at Argos' gates, and Greece to-day
11.379: were for her fallen fortunes grieving sore.
11.380: Our lingering at Ilium's stubborn wall,
11.381: our sluggard conquest halting ten years Iong,
11.382: was his and Hector's work. Heroic pair!
11.383: Each one for valor notable, and each
11.384: famous in enterprise of arms,—but he
11.385: was first in piety. Enclasp with his
11.386: your hands in plighted peace as best ye may:
11.387: but shock of steel on steel ye well may shun.’
11.388: now hast thou heard, good King, a king's reply,
11.389: and how his wisdom sits in this vast war.”
11.390: Soon as the envoys ceased, an answering sound
11.391: of troubled voices through the council flowed
11.392: of various note, as when its rocky bed
11.393: impedes an arrowy stream, and murmurs break
11.394: from the strait-channelled flood; the fringing shores
11.395: repeat the tumult of the clamorous wave.
11.396: But when their hearts and troublous tongues were still,
11.397: the King, invoking first the gods in heaven,
11.398: thus from a Iofty throne his sentence gave:
11.399: “Less evil were our case, if long ago
11.400: ye had provided for your country's weal,
11.401: O Latins, as I urged. It is no time
11.402: to hold dispute, while, compassing our walls,
11.403: the foeman waits. Ill-omened war is ours
11.404: against a race of gods, my countrymen,
11.406: and who, though lost and fallen, clutch the sword.
11.407: If hope ye cherished of Aetolia's power,
11.408: dismiss it! For what hope ye have is found
11.409: in your own bosoms only. But ye know
11.410: how slight it is and small. What ruin wide
11.411: has fallen, is now palpable and clear.
11.412: No blame I cast. What valor's uttermost
11.413: may do was done; our kingdom in this war
11.414: strained its last thews. Now therefore I will tell
11.415: such project as my doubtful mind may frame,
11.416: and briefly, if ye give good heed, unfold:
11.417: an ancient tract have I, close-bordering
11.418: the river Tiber; it runs westward far
11.419: beyond Sicania's bound, and filth it bears
11.421: who furrow its hard hills or feed their flocks
11.422: along the stonier slopes. Let this demesne,
11.423: together with its pine-clad mountain tall,
11.424: be given the Teucrian for our pledge of peace,
11.425: confirmed by free and equitable league,
11.426: and full alliance with our kingly power.
11.427: Let them abide there, if it please them so,
11.428: and build their city's wall. But if their hearts
11.429: for other land or people yearn, and fate
11.430: permits them hence to go, then let us build
11.431: twice ten good galleys of Italian oak,
11.432: or more, if they can man them. All the wood
11.433: lies yonder on the shore. Let them but say
11.434: how numerous and large the ships they crave,
11.435: and we will give the brass, the artisans,
11.436: and ship-supplies. Let us for envoys choose
11.437: a hundred of the Latins noblest born
11.438: to tell our message and arrange the peace,
11.439: bearing mild olive-boughs and weighty gifts
11.440: of ivory and gold, with chair of state
11.441: and purple robe, our emblems as a king.
11.442: But freely let this council speak; give aid
11.443: to our exhausted cause.” Then Drances rose,
11.444: that foe inveterate, whom Turnus' fame
11.445: to stinging hate and envy double-tongued
11.446: ever pricked on. Of liberal wealth was he
11.447: and flowing speech, but slack of hand in war
11.448: at council board accounted no weak voice,
11.449: in quarrels stronger still; of lofty birth
11.450: in the maternal line, but by his sire's
11.451: uncertain and obscure. He, claiming place,
11.452: thus multiplies with words the people's ire:
11.453: “A course most clear, nor needing voice of mine,
11.454: thy council is, good King; for all men see
11.455: the way of public weal, but smother close
11.456: the telling of it. Turnus must concede
11.457: freedom to speak, and his own arrogance
11.459: and fatal conduct—yea, I speak it plain,
11.460: though with his naked steel my death he swear—
11.461: yon host of princes fell, and we behold
11.462: the whole land bowed with grief; while he assails
11.463: the Trojan camp (beating such bold retreats!)
11.464: and troubles Heaven with war. One gift the more,
11.465: among the many to the Trojans given,
11.466: one chiefly, best of kings, thy choice should be.
11.467: Let not wild violence thy will restrain
11.468: from granting, sire, thy virgin daughter's hand
11.469: to son-in-law illustrious, in a match
11.470: worthy of both,—and thus the lasting bond
11.471: of peace establish. But if verily
11.472: our hearts and souls be weak with craven fear,
11.473: let us on Turnus call, and grace implore
11.474: even of him. Let him no more oppose;
11.475: but to his country and his King concede
11.476: their natural right. Why wilt thou o'er and o'er
11.477: fling thy poor countrymen in danger's way,
11.478: O chief and fountain of all Latium's pain?
11.479: War will not save us. Not a voice but sues
11.480: for peace, O Turnus! and, not less than peace,
11.482: I lead in this petition! even I
11.483: whom thou dost feign thy foe—(I waste no words
11.485: take pity on thy kindred; drop thy pride,
11.486: and get thee home defeated. We have seen
11.487: slaughter enough, enough of funeral flames,
11.488: and many a wide field waste and desolate.
11.489: If glory move thee, if thy martial breast
11.490: so swell with strength, and if a royal dower
11.491: be thy dear dream, go, pluck thy courage up,
11.492: and front thy own brave bosom to the foe.
11.493: for, lo, that Turnus on his wedding day
11.494: may win a princess, our cheap, common lives—
11.495: we the mere mob, unwept, unsepulchred—
11.496: must be spilled forth in battle! Thou, I say,
11.497: if there be mettle in thee and some drops
11.498: of thy undaunted sires, Iook yonder where
11.499: the Trojan chieftain waits thee in the field.”
11.500: By such discourse he stirred the burning blood
11.501: of Turnus, who groaned loud and from his heart
11.502: this utterance hurled: “O Drances, thou art rich
11.503: in large words, when the day of battle calls
11.504: for actions. If our senators convene
11.505: thou comest early. But the council hall
11.506: is not for swollen talk, such as thy tongue
11.507: in safety tosses forth; so long as walls
11.508: hold back thy foes, and ere the trenches flow
11.509: with blood of brave men slain. O, rattle on
11.511: Brand me a coward, Drances, when thy sword
11.512: has heaped up Trojan slain, and on the field
11.513: thy shining trophies rise. Now may we twain
11.514: our martial prowess prove. Our foe, forsooth,
11.515: is not so far to seek; around yon wall
11.516: he lies in siege: to front him let us fly!
11.517: Why art thou tarrying? Wilt thou linger here,
11.518: a soldier only in thy windy tongue,
11.519: and thy swift, coward heels? Defeated, I?
11.520: Foul wretch, what tongue that honors truth can tell
11.521: of my defeat, while Tiber overflows
11.522: with Trojan blood? while King Evander's house
11.523: in ruin dies, and his Arcadians lie
11.524: stripped naked on the field? O, not like thee
11.525: did Bitias or the giant Pandarus
11.526: misprize my honor; nor those men of Troy
11.527: whom this good sword to death and dark sent down,
11.528: a thousand in a day,—though I was penned
11.529: a prisoner in the ramparts of my foe.
11.530: War will not save us? Fling that prophecy
11.531: on the doomed Dardan's head, or on thy own,
11.532: thou madman! Aye, with thy vile, craven soul
11.533: disturb the general cause. Extol the power
11.534: of a twice-vanquished people, and decry
11.535: Latinus' rival arms. From this time forth
11.536: let all the Myrmidonian princes cower
11.537: before the might of Troy; let Diomed
11.538: and let Achilles tremble; let the stream
11.539: of Aufidus in panic backward flow
11.540: from Hadria's wave. But hear me when I say
11.541: that though his guilt and cunning feign to feel
11.542: fear of my vengeance, much embittering so
11.543: his taunts and insult—such a life as his
11.544: my sword disdains. O Drances, be at ease!
11.545: In thy vile bosom let thy breath abide!
11.546: But now of thy grave counsel and thy cause,
11.547: O royal sire, I speak. If from this hour
11.548: thou castest hope of armed success away,
11.549: if we be so unfriended that one rout
11.550: o'erwhelms us utterly, if Fortune's feet
11.551: never turn backward, let us, then, for peace
11.552: offer petition, lifting to the foe
11.553: our feeble, suppliant hands. Yet would I pray
11.554: some spark of manhood such as once we knew
11.555: were ours once more! I count him fortunate,
11.556: and of illustrious soul beyond us all,
11.557: who, rather than behold such things, has fallen
11.558: face forward, dead, his teeth upon the dust.
11.559: But if we still have power, and men-at-arms
11.560: unwasted and unscathed, if there survive
11.561: Italian tribes and towns for help in war,
11.562: aye! if the Trojans have but won success
11.563: at bloody cost,—for they dig graves, I ween,
11.564: storm-smitten not less than we,—O, wherefore now
11.565: stand faint and shameful on the battle's edge?
11.566: Why quake our knees before the trumpet call?
11.567: Time and the toil of shifting, changeful days
11.568: restore lost causes; ebbing tides of chance
11.569: deceive us oft, which after at their flood
11.570: do lift us safe to shore. If aid come not
11.571: from Diomed in Arpi, our allies
11.573: auspicious name, and many a chieftain sent
11.574: from many a tribe; not all inglorious
11.575: are Latium's warriors from Laurentian land!
11.576: Hither the noble Volscian stem sends down
11.578: in glittering brass arrayed. But if, forsooth,
11.579: the Trojans call me singly to the fight,
11.580: if this be what ye will, and I so much
11.581: the public weal impair—when from this sword
11.582: has victory seemed to fly away in scorn?
11.583: I should not hopeless tread in honor's way
11.584: whate'er the venture. Dauntless will I go
11.585: though equal match for great Achilles, he,
11.586: and though he clothe him in celestial arms
11.587: in Vulcan's smithy wrought. I, Turnus, now,
11.588: not less than equal with great warriors gone,
11.589: vow to Latinus, father of my bride,
11.590: and to ye all, each drop of blood I owe.
11.591: Me singly doth Aeneas call? I crave
11.592: that challenge. Drances is not called to pay
11.593: the debt of death, if wrath from Heaven impend;
11.594: nor his a brave man's name and fame to share.”
11.595: Thus in their doubtful cause the chieftains strove.
