11.597: moved forward. The ill tidings wildly sped
11.598: from royal hall to hall, and filled the town
11.599: with rumors dark: for now the Trojan host
11.600: o'er the wide plains from Tiber's wave was spread
11.601: in close array of war. The people's soul
11.602: was vexed and shaken, and its martial rage
11.603: rose to the stern compulsion. Now for arms
11.604: their terror calls; the youthful soldiery
11.605: clamor for arms; the sires of riper days
11.606: weep or repress their tears. On every side
11.607: loud shouts and cries of dissonant acclaim
11.608: trouble the air, as when in lofty grove
11.609: legions of birds alight, or by the flood
11.610: of Padus' fishy stream the shrieking swans
11.611: far o'er the vocal marish fling their song.
11.612: Then, seizing the swift moment, Turnus cried:
11.613: “Once more, my countrymen,—ye sit in parle,
11.614: lazily praising peace, while yonder foe
11.615: speeds forth in arms our kingdom to obtain.”
11.616: He spoke no more, but hied him in hot haste,
11.617: and from the housetop called, “Volusus, go!
11.618: Equip the Volscian companies! Lead forth
11.619: my Rutules also! O'er the spreading plain,
11.620: ye brothers Coras and Messapus range
11.621: our host of cavalry! Let others guard
11.622: the city's gates and hold the walls and towers:
11.623: I and my followers elsewhere oppose
11.624: the shock of arms.” Now to and fro they run
11.625: to man the walls. Father Latinus quits—
11.626: the place of council and his large design,
11.627: vexed and bewildered by the hour's distress.
11.628: He blames his own heart that he did not ask
11.629: Trojan Aeneas for his daughter's Iord,
11.630: and gain him for his kingdom's lasting friend.
11.631: They dig them trenches at the gates, or lift
11.632: burden of stakes and stones. The horn's harsh note
11.633: sounds forth its murderous signal for the war;
11.634: striplings and women, in a motley ring,
11.635: defend the ramparts; the decisive hour
11.636: lays tasks on all. Upon the citadel
11.637: a train of matrons, with the doleful Queen,
11.638: toward Pallas' temple moves, and in their hand
11.639: are gifts and offerings. See, at their side
11.640: the maid Lavinia, cause of all these tears,
11.641: drops down her lovely eyes! The incense rolls
11.642: in clouds above the altar; at the doors
11.643: with wailing voice the women make this prayer:
11.645: Break of thyself yon Phrygian robber's spear!
11.646: Hurl him down dying in the dust! Spill forth
11.647: his evil blood beneath our lofty towers!”
11.648: Fierce Turnus girds him, emulous to slay:
11.649: a crimson coat of mail he wears, with scales
11.650: of burnished bronze; beneath his knees are bound
11.651: the golden greaves; upon his naked brow
11.652: no helm he wears; but to his thigh is bound
11.653: a glittering sword. Down from the citadel
11.654: runs he, a golden glory, in his heart
11.656: fore-counts his fallen foes. He seemed as when,
11.657: from pinfold bursting, breaking his strong chain,
11.658: th' untrammelled stallion ranges the wide field,
11.659: or tries him to a herd of feeding mares,
11.660: or to some cooling river-bank he knows,
11.661: most fierce and mettlesome; the streaming mane
11.662: o'er neck and shoulder flies. Across his path
11.663: Camilla with her Volscian escort came,
11.664: and at the city-gate the royal maid
11.665: down from her charger leaped; while all her band
11.666: at her example glided to the ground,
11.667: their horses leaving. Thus the virgin spoke:
11.669: I have no fear; but of myself do vow
11.670: to meet yon squadrons of Aeneadae
11.671: alone, and front me to the gathered charge
11.672: of Tuscan cavalry. Let me alone
11.673: the war's first venture-prove. Take station, thou,
11.674: here at the walls, this rampart to defend.”
11.675: With fixed eyes on the terror-striking maid,
11.677: O virgin bold! What praise, what gratitude
11.678: can words or deeds repay? But since thy soul
11.679: so large of stature shows, I bid thee share
11.680: my burden and my war. Our spies bring news
11.681: that now Aeneas with pernicious mind
11.682: sends light-armed horse before him, to alarm
11.683: the plains below, while through the wilderness
11.684: he climbs the steep hills, and approaches so
11.685: our leaguered town. But I in sheltered grove
11.686: a stratagem prepare, and bid my men
11.687: in ambush at a mountain cross-road lie.
11.688: Meet thou the charge of Tuscan cavalry
11.689: with all thy banners. For auxiliar strength
11.690: take bold Messapus with his Latin troop
11.691: and King Tiburtus' men: but the command
11.692: shall be thy task and care.” He spoke, and urged
11.693: with like instruction for the coming fray
11.694: Messapus and his captains; then advanced
11.695: to meet the foe. There is a winding vale
11.696: for armed deception and insidious war
11.697: well fashioned, and by interlacing leaves
11.698: screened darkly in; a small path thither leads,
11.699: through strait defile-a passage boding ill.
11.700: Above it, on a mountain's lofty brow,
11.701: are points of outlook, level spaces fair,
11.702: and many a safe, invisible retreat
11.703: from whence on either hand to challenge war,
11.704: or, standing on the ridges, to roll down
11.705: huge mountain boulders. Thither Turnus fared,
11.706: and, ranging the familiar tract, chose out
11.707: his cunning ambush in the dangerous grove.
11.708: But now in dwellings of the gods on high,
11.710: a virgin from her consecrated train,
11.711: and thus in sorrow spoke: “O maiden mine!
11.712: Camilla now to cruel conflict flies;
11.713: with weapons like my own she girds her side,
11.714: in vain, though dearest of all nymphs to me.
11.715: Nor is it some new Iove that stirs to-day
11.716: with sudden sweetness in Diana's breast:
11.717: for long ago, when from his kingdom driven,
11.718: for insolent and envied power, her sire
11.719: King Metabus, from old Privernum's wall
11.720: was taking flight amidst opposing foes,
11.721: he bore a little daughter in his arms
11.722: to share his exile; and he called the child
11.724: Camilla. Bearing on his breast the babe,
11.725: he fled to solitary upland groves.
11.726: But hovering round him with keen lances, pressed
11.727: the Volscian soldiery. Across his path,
11.729: o'erflowed its banks—so huge a rain had burst
11.730: but lately from the clouds. There would he fain
11.731: swim over, but the love of that sweet babe
11.732: restrained him, trembling for his burden dear.
11.733: In his perplexed heart suddenly arose
11.734: firm resolve. It chanced the warrior bore
11.735: huge spear in his brawny hand, strong shaft
11.736: of knotted, seasoned oak; to this he lashed
11.737: his little daughter with a withe of bark
11.738: pulled from a cork-tree, and with skilful bonds
11.739: fast bound her to the spear; then, poising it
11.740: high in his right hand, thus he called on Heaven:
11.742: protects this grove, behold, her father now
11.743: gives thee this babe for handmaid! Lo, thy spear
11.744: her infant fingers hold, as from her foes
11.745: she flies a suppliant to thee! Receive,
11.746: O goddess, I implore, what now I cast
11.747: upon the perilous air.’—He spoke, and hurled
11.748: with lifted arm the whirling shaft. The waves
11.749: roared loud, as on the whistling javelin
11.750: hapless Camilla crossed th' impetuous flood.
11.751: But Metabus, his foes in hot pursuit,
11.752: dared plunge him in mid-stream, and, triumphing,
11.753: soon plucked from grass-grown river-bank the spear,
11.754: the child upon it,—now to Trivia vowed,
11.756: could cities hold, nor would his wild heart yield
11.757: its sylvan freedom, but his days were passed
11.758: with shepherds on the solitary hills.
11.759: His daughter too in tangled woods he bred:
11.760: a brood-mare from the milk of her fierce breast
11.761: suckled the child, and to its tender lips
11.762: .Her udders moved; and when the infant feet
11.763: their first firm steps had taken, the small palms
11.764: were armed with a keen javelin; her sire
11.765: a bow and quiver from her shoulder slung.
11.766: Instead of golden combs and flowing pall,
11.767: she wore, from her girl-forehead backward thrown,
11.768: the whole skin of a tigress; with soft hands
11.769: she made her plaything of a whirling spear,
11.770: or, swinging round her head the polished thong
11.771: of her good sling, she fetched from distant sky
11.772: Strymonian cranes or swans of spotless wing.
11.773: From Tuscan towns proud matrons oft in vain
11.774: sought her in marriage for their sons; but she
11.775: to Dian only turned her stainless heart,
11.776: her virgin freedom and her huntress' arms
11.777: with faithful passion serving. Would that now
11.778: this Iove of war had ne'er seduced her mind
11.779: the Teucrians to provoke! So might she be
11.780: one of our wood-nymphs still. But haste, I pray,
11.781: for bitter is her now impending doom.
11.782: Descend, dear nymph, from heaven, and explore
11.783: the country of the Latins, where the fight
11.785: These weapons take, and from this quiver draw
11.786: a vengeful arrow, wherewith he who dares
11.787: to wound her sacred body, though he be
11.788: a Trojan or Italian, shall receive
11.789: bloody and swift reward at my command.
11.790: Then, in a cloud concealed, I will consign
11.793: the virgin to her native land.” Thus spake
11.794: the goddess; but her handmaid, gliding down,
11.795: took her loud pathway on the moving winds,
11.796: and mantled in dark storm her shape divine.
11.797: Meanwhile the Teucrian legions to the wall
11.798: draw near, with Tuscan lords and cavalry
11.799: in numbered troops arrayed. Loud-footed steeds
11.800: prance o'er the field, to manage of the rein
11.801: rebellious, but turned deftly here or there.
11.802: The iron harvest of keen spears spreads far,
11.803: and all the plain burns bright with lifted steel.
11.805: Coras his brother, and th' attending train
11.806: of the fair maid Camilla, form their lines
11.807: in the opposing field. Their poised right hands
11.808: point the long lances forward, and light shafts
11.809: are brandished in the air; the warrior hosts
11.810: on steeds of fire come kindling as they ride.
11.811: One instant, at a spear-throw's space, each line
11.812: its motion stays; then with one sudden cry
11.813: they rush forth, spurring on each frenzied steed.
11.815: pour down like snowflakes, mantling heaven in shade.
11.816: Now with contending spears and straining thews,
11.818: ride forward; with the onset terrible
11.819: loudly their armor rings; their chargers twain
11.820: crash breast to breast, and like a thunderbolt
11.821: Aconteus drops, or like a ponderous stone
11.822: hurled from a catapult; full length he falls,
11.823: surrend'ring to the winds his fleeting soul.
11.824: Now all is panic: holding their light shields
11.825: behind their backs, the Latin horse wheel round,
11.826: retreating to the wall, the Trojan foe
11.827: in close pursuit. Asilas, chieftain proud,
11.828: led on th' assault. Hard by the city gates
11.829: the Latins wheeled once more and pressed the rein
11.830: strong on the yielding neck; the charging foe
11.831: took flight and hurried far with loose-flung rein.
11.832: 'T was like the shock and onset of the sea
11.833: that landward hurls the alternating flood
11.834: and hides high cliffs in foam,—the tawny sands
11.835: upflinging as it rolls; then, suddenly
11.836: whirled backward on the reingulfing waves,
11.837: it quits the ledges, and with ebbing flow
11.838: far from the shore retires. The Tuscans twice
11.839: drive back the flying Rutules to the town;
11.840: and twice repulsed, with shields to rearward thrown,
11.841: glare back at the pursuer; but conjoined
11.842: in the third battle-charge, both armies merge
11.844: of man to man; then follow dying groans,
11.845: armor blood-bathed and corpses, and strong steeds
11.848: to front the warrior's arms—launched forth a spear
11.849: at Remulus' horse, and left the fatal steel
11.850: clinging below its ear; the charger plunged
11.851: madly, and tossed its trembling hoofs in air,
11.852: sustaining not the wound; the rider fell,
11.853: flung headlong to the ground. Catillus slew
11.854: Iollas; and then struck Herminius down,
11.855: great-bodied and great-hearted, who could wield
11.856: a monster weapon, and whose yellow hair
11.857: from naked head to naked shoulder flowed.
11.858: By wounds unterrified he dared oppose
11.859: his huge bulk to the foe: the quivering spear
11.860: pierced to his broad back, and with throes of pain
11.861: bowed the man double and clean clove him through.
11.862: Wide o'er the field th' ensanguined horror flowed,
11.863: where fatal swords were crossed and cut their way
11.864: through many a wound to famous death and fair.
11.865: Swift through the midmost slaughter proudly strides
11.866: the quiver-girt Camilla, with one breast
11.867: thrust naked to the fight, like Amazon.
11.868: Oft from her hand her pliant shafts she rains,
11.870: a doughty battle-axe; her shoulder bears
11.871: Diana's sounding arms and golden bow.
11.872: Sometimes retreating and to flight compelled,
11.873: the maiden with a rearward-pointing bow
11.874: shoots arrows as she flies. Around her move
11.875: her chosen peers, Larina, virgin brave,
11.876: Tarpeia, brandishing an axe of bronze,
11.877: and Tulla, virgins out of Italy
11.878: whom the divine Camilla chose to be
11.879: her glory, each a faithful servitress
11.880: in days of peace or war. The maids of Thrace
11.881: ride thus along Thermodon's frozen flood,
11.882: and fight with blazoned Amazonian arms
11.885: 'mid acclamations shrill, and all her host
11.886: of women clash in air the moon-shaped shield.
11.887: What warrior first, whom last, did thy strong spear,
11.888: fierce virgin, earthward fling? Or what thy tale
11.889: of prostrate foes laid gasping on the ground?
11.890: Eunaeus first, the child of Clytius' Ioins,
11.891: whose bared breast, as he faced his foe, she pierced
11.892: with fir-tree javelin; from his lips outpoured
11.893: the blood-stream as he fell; and as he bit
11.894: the gory dust, he clutched his mortal wound.
11.895: Then Liris, and upon him Pagasus
11.896: she slew: the one clung closer to the reins
11.897: of his stabbed horse, and rolled off on the ground;
11.898: the other, flying to his fallen friend,
11.899: reached out a helpless hand; so both of these
11.900: fell on swift death together. Next in line
11.901: she smote Amastrus, son of Hippotas;
11.902: then, swift-pursuing, pierced with far-flung spear
11.904: and Chromis; every shaft the virgin threw
11.905: laid low its Phrygian warrior. From afar
11.906: rode Ornytus on his Apulian steed,
11.907: bearing a hunter's uncouth arms; for cloak
11.908: he wore upon his shoulders broad a hide
11.909: from some wild bull stripped off; his helmet was
11.910: a wolf's great, gaping mouth, with either jaw
11.911: full of white teeth; the weapon in his hand,
11.912: a farmer's pole. He strode into the throng,
11.913: head taller than them all. But him she seized
11.914: and clove him through (his panic-stricken troop
11.915: gave her advantage), and with wrathful heart
11.916: she taunted thus the fallen: “Didst thou deem
11.917: this was a merry hunting in the wood
11.918: in chase of game? Behold, thy fatal day
11.919: befalls thee at a woman's hand, and thus
11.920: thy boasting answers. No small glory thou
11.921: unto the ghosts of thy dead sires wilt tell,
11.922: that 't was Camilla's javelin struck thee down.”
11.923: The turn of Butes and Orsilochus
11.924: came next, who were the Trojans, hugest twain:
11.925: yet Butes with her javelin-point she clove
11.926: from rearward, 'twixt the hauberk and the helm,
11.927: just where the horseman's neck showed white, and where
11.928: from shoulder leftward slung the light-weight shield.
11.929: From swift Orsilochus she feigned to fly,
11.930: through a wide circle sweeping, craftily
11.931: taking the inside track, pursuing so
11.932: her own pursuer; then she raised herself
11.933: to her full height, and through the warrior's helm
11.934: drove to his very skull with doubling blows
11.935: of her strong battle-axe,—while he implored
11.936: her mercy with loud prayers: his cloven brain
11.937: spilt o'er his face. Next in her pathway came—
11.938: but shrank in startled fear—the warrior son
11.939: of Aunus, haunter of the Apennine,
11.940: not least of the Ligurians ere his doom
11.941: cut short a life of lies. He, knowing well
11.942: no flight could save him from the shock of arms
11.943: nor turn the royal maid's attack, began
11.944: with words of cunning and insidious guile:
11.945: “What glory is it if a girl be bold,
11.946: on sturdy steed depending? Fly me not!
11.947: But, venturing with me on this equal ground,
11.948: gird thee to fight on foot. Soon shalt thou see
11.949: which one of us by windy boast achieves
11.950: a false renown.” He spoke; but she, to pangs
11.951: of keenest fury stung, gave o'er her steed
11.952: in charge of a companion, and opposed
11.953: her foe at equal vantage, falchion drawn,
11.954: on foot, and, though her shield no blazon bore,
11.955: of fear incapable. But the warrior fled,
11.956: thinking his trick victorious, and rode off
11.957: full speed, with reins reversed,—his iron heel
11.958: goading his charger's flight. Camilla cried:
11.959: “Ligurian cheat! In vain thy boastful heart
11.960: puffs thee so large; in vain thou hast essayed
11.961: thy father's slippery ways; nor shall thy trick
11.962: bring thee to guileful Aunus safely home.”
11.963: Herewith on winged feet that virgin bold
11.964: flew past the war-horse, seized the streaming rein,
11.965: and, fronting him, took vengeance on her foe
11.966: in bloody strokes: with not less ease a hawk,
11.967: dark bird of omen, from his mountain crag
11.968: pursues on pinions strong a soaring dove
11.969: to distant cloud, and, clutching with hooked claws,
11.970: holds tight and rips,—while through celestial air
11.971: the torn, ensanguined plumage floats along.
11.972: But now not blindly from Olympian throne
11.973: the Sire of gods and men observant saw
11.974: how sped the day. Then to the conflict dire
11.975: the god thrust Tarchon forth, the Tyrrhene King,
11.976: goading the warrior's rage. So Tarchon rode
11.977: through slaughter wide and legions in retreat,
11.978: and roused the ranks with many a wrathful cry:
11.979: he called each man by name, and toward the foe
11.980: drove back the routed lines. “What terrors now,
11.981: Tuscan cowards, dead to noble rage,
11.982: have seized ye? or what laggard sloth and vile
11.983: unmans your hearts, that now a woman's arm
11.984: pursues ye and this scattered host confounds?
11.985: Why dressed in steel, or to what purpose wear
11.986: your futile swords? Not slackly do ye join
11.987: the ranks of Venus in a midnight war;
11.988: or when fantastic pipes of Bacchus call
11.989: your dancing feet, right venturesome ye fly
11.990: to banquets and the flowing wine—what zeal,
11.991: what ardor then! Or if your flattering priest
11.992: begins the revel, and to Iofty groves
11.993: fat flesh of victims bids ye haste away!”
11.994: So saying, his steed he spurred, and scorning death
11.995: dashed into the mid-fray, where, frenzy-driven,
11.996: he sought out Venulus, and, grappling him
11.997: with one hand, from the saddle snatched his foe,
11.998: and, clasping strongly to his giant breast,
11.999: exultant bore away. The shouting rose
11.1000: to heaven, and all the Latins gazed his way,
11.1001: as o'er the plain the fiery Tarchon flew
11.1002: bearing the full-armed man; then, breaking off
11.1003: the point of his own spear, he pried a way
11.1004: through the seam'd armor for the mortal wound;
11.1005: the other, struggling, thrust back from his throat
11.1006: the griping hand, full force to force opposing.
11.1007: As when a golden eagle high in air
11.1008: knits to a victim—snake his clinging feet
11.1009: and deeply-thrusting claws; but, coiling back,
11.1010: the wounded serpent roughens his stiff scales
11.1011: and stretches high his hissing head; whereat
11.1012: the eagle with hooked beak the more doth rend
11.1013: her writhing foe, and with swift stroke of wing
11.1014: lashes the air: so Tarchon, from the ranks
11.1015: of Tibur's sons, triumphant snatched his prey.
11.1016: The Tuscans rallied now, well pleased to view
11.1017: their king's example and successful war.
11.1018: Then Arruns, marked for doom, made circling line
11.1019: around Camilla's path, his crafty spear
11.1020: seeking its lucky chance. Where'er the maid
11.1021: sped furious to the battle, Arruns there
11.1022: in silence dogged her footsteps and pursued;
11.1023: or where triumphant from her fallen foes
11.1024: she backward drew, the warrior stealthily
11.1025: turned his swift reins that way: from every side
11.1026: he circled her, and scanned his vantage here
11.1027: or vantage there, his skilful javelin
11.1028: stubbornly shaking. But it soon befell
11.1029: that Chloreus, once a priest of Cybele,
11.1030: shone forth in far-resplendent Phrygian arms,
11.1031: and urged a foaming steed, which wore a robe
11.1032: o'erwrought with feathery scales of bronze and gold;
11.1033: while he, in purples of fine foreign stain,
11.1034: bore light Gortynian shafts and Lycian bow;
11.1035: his bow was gold; a golden casque he wore
11.1036: upon his priestly brow; the saffron cloak,
11.1037: all folds of rustling cambric, was enclasped
11.1038: in glittering gold; his skirts and tunics gay
11.1039: were broidered, and the oriental garb
11.1040: swathed his whole leg. Him when the maiden spied,
11.1041: (Perchance she fain on temple walls would hang
11.1042: the Trojan prize, or in such captured gold
11.1043: her own fair shape array), she gave mad chase,
11.1044: and reckless through the ranks her prey pursued,
11.1046: Then from his ambush Arruns seized at last
11.1047: the fatal moment and let speed his shaft,
11.1048: thus uttering his vow to heavenly powers:
11.1049: “Chief of the gods, Apollo, who dost guard
11.1050: Soracte's hallowed steep, whom we revere
11.1051: first of thy worshippers, for thee is fed
11.1052: the heap of burning pine; for thee we pass
11.1053: through the mid-blaze in sacred zeal secure,
11.1054: and deep in glowing embers plant our feet.
11.1055: O Sire Omnipotent, may this my spear
11.1056: our foul disgrace put by. I do not ask
11.1057: for plunder, spoils, or trophies in my name,
11.1058: when yonder virgin falls; let honor's crown
11.1059: be mine for other deeds. But if my stroke
11.1060: that curse and plague destroy, may I unpraised
11.1061: safe to the cities of my sires return.”
11.1062: Apollo heard and granted half the prayer,
11.1063: but half upon the passing breeze he threw:
11.1064: granting his votary he should confound
11.1065: Camilla by swift death; but 't was denied
11.1066: the mountain-fatherland once more to see,
11.1067: or safe return,—that prayer th' impetuous winds
11.1068: swept stormfully away. Soon as the spear
11.1069: whizzed from his hand, straight-speeding on the air,
11.1070: the Volscians all turned eager thought and eyes
11.1071: toward their Queen. She only did not heed
11.1072: that windy roar, nor weapon dropped from heaven,
11.1073: till in her bare, protruded breast the spear
11.1074: drank, deeply driven, of her virgin blood.
11.1076: around her, and uplift their sinking Queen.
11.1077: But Arruns, panic-stricken more than all,
11.1078: makes off, half terror and half joy, nor dares
11.1079: hazard his lance again, nor dares oppose
11.1080: a virgin's arms. As creeps back to the hills
11.1081: in pathless covert ere his foes pursue,
11.1082: from shepherd slain or mighty bull laid low,
11.1083: some wolf, who, now of his bold trespass ware,
11.1084: curls close against his paunch a quivering tail
11.1085: and to the forest tries: so Arruns speeds
11.1086: from sight of men in terror, glad to fly,
11.1087: and hides him in the crowd. But his keen spear
11.1088: dying Camilla from her bosom drew,
11.1089: though the fixed barb of deeply-wounding steel
11.1090: clung to the rib. She sank to earth undone,
11.1091: her cold eyes closed in death, and from her cheeks
11.1092: the roses fled. With failing breath she called
11.1093: on Acca—who of all her maiden peers
11.1094: was chiefly dear and shared her heart's whole pain—
11.1095: and thus she spoke: “O Acca, sister mine,
11.1096: I have been strong till now. The cruel wound
11.1097: consumes me, and my world is growing dark.
11.1098: Haste thee to Turnus! Tell my dying words!
11.1099: 'T is he must bear the battle and hold back
11.1100: the Trojan from our city wall. Farewell!”
11.1101: So saying, her fingers from the bridle-rein
11.1102: unclasped, and helpless to the earth she fell;
11.1103: then, colder grown, she loosed her more and more
11.1104: out of the body's coil; she gave to death
11.1105: her neck, her drooping head, and ceased to heed
11.1106: her war-array. So fled her spirit forth
11.1107: with wrath and moaning to the world below.
11.1108: Then clamor infinite uprose and smote
11.1109: the golden stars, as round Camilla slain
11.1110: the battle newly raged. To swifter charge
11.1111: the gathered Trojans ran, with Tuscan lords
11.1112: and King Evander's troops of Arcady.
11.1113: Fair Opis, keeping guard for Trivia
11.1114: in patient sentry on a lofty hill, beheld
11.1115: unterrified the conflict's rage. Yet when,
11.1116: amid the frenzied shouts of soldiery,
11.1117: she saw from far Camilla pay the doom
11.1118: of piteous death, with deep-drawn voice of sight
11.1119: she thus complained: “O virgin, woe is me!
11.1120: Too much, too much, this agony of thine,
11.1121: to expiate that thou didst lift thy spear
11.1122: for wounding Troy. It was no shield in war,
11.1123: nor any vantage to have kept thy vow
11.1124: to chaste Diana in the thorny wild.
11.1125: Our maiden arrows at thy shoulder slung
11.1126: availed thee not! Yet will our Queen divine
11.1127: not leave unhonored this thy dying day,
11.1128: nor shall thy people let thy death remain
11.1129: a thing forgot, nor thy bright name appear
11.1130: a glory unavenged. Whoe'er he be
11.1131: that marred thy body with the mortal wound
11.1132: shall die as he deserves.” Beneath that hill
11.1133: an earth-built mound uprose, the tomb
11.1134: of King Dercennus, a Laurentine old,
11.1135: by sombre ilex shaded: thither hied
11.1136: the fair nymph at full speed, and from the mound
11.1137: looked round for Arruns. When his shape she saw
11.1139: “Whither so fast?” she cried. “This way, thy path!
11.1140: This fatal way approach, and here receive
11.1141: thy reward for Camilla! Thou shalt fall,
11.1142: vile though thou art, by Dian's shaft divine.”
11.1143: She said; and one swift-coursing arrow took
11.1144: from golden quiver, like a maid of Thrace,
11.1145: and stretched it on her bow with hostile aim,
11.1146: withdrawing far, till both the tips of horn
11.1147: together bent, and, both hands poising well,
11.1148: the left outreached to touch the barb of steel,
11.1149: the right to her soft breast the bowstring drew:
11.1150: the hissing of the shaft, the sounding air,
11.1151: Arruns one moment heard, as to his flesh
11.1152: the iron point clung fast. But his last groan
11.1153: his comrades heeded not, and let him lie,
11.1154: scorned and forgotten, on the dusty field,
11.1155: while Opis soared to bright Olympian air.
11.1156: Camilla's light-armed troop, its virgin chief
11.1157: now fallen, were the first to fly; in flight
11.1158: the panic-stricken Rutule host is seen
11.1159: and Acer bold; his captains in dismay
11.1160: with shattered legions from the peril fly,
11.1161: and goad their horses to the city wall.
11.1162: Not one sustains the Trojan charge, or stands
11.1163: in arms against the swift approach of death.
11.1164: Their bows unstrung from drooping shoulder fall,
11.1165: and clatter of hoof-beats shakes the crumbling ground.
11.1166: On to the city in a blinding cloud
11.1167: the dust uprolls. From watch-towers Iooking forth,
11.1168: the women smite their breasts and raise to heaven
11.1169: shrill shouts of fear. Those fliers who first passed
11.1170: the open gates were followed by the foe,
11.1171: routed and overwhelmed. They could not fly
11.1172: a miserable death, but were struck down
11.1173: in their own ancient city, or expired
11.1174: before the peaceful shrines of hearth and home.
11.1175: Then some one barred the gates. They dared not now
11.1176: give their own people entrance, and were deaf
11.1177: to all entreaty. Woeful deaths ensued,
11.1178: both of the armed defenders of the gate,
11.1179: and of the foe in arms. The desperate band,
11.1180: barred from the city in the face and eyes
11.1181: of their own weeping parents, either dropped
11.1183: into the moat below; or, frantic, blind,
11.1184: battered with beams against the stubborn door
11.1185: and columns strong. Above in conflict wild
11.1186: even the women (who for faithful love
11.1187: of home and country schooled them to be brave
11.1188: Camilla's way) rained weapons from the walls,
11.1189: and used oak-staves and truncheons shaped in flame,
11.1190: as if, well-armed in steel, each bosom bold
11.1191: would fain in such defence be first to die.
11.1192: Meanwhile th' unpitying messenger had flown
11.1193: to Turnus in the wood; the warrior heard
11.1194: from Acca of the wide confusion spread,
11.1195: the Volscian troop destroyed, Camilla slain,
11.1196: the furious foe increasing, and, with Mars
11.1197: to help him, grasping all, till in that hour
11.1198: far as the city-gates the panic reigned.
11.1199: Then he in desperate rage (Jove's cruel power
11.1200: decreed it) from the ambushed hills withdrew
11.1201: and pathless wild. He scarce had passed beyond
11.1202: to the bare plain, when forth Aeneas marched
11.1203: along the wide ravine, climbed up the ridge,
11.1204: and from the dark, deceiving grove stood clear.
11.1205: Then swiftly each with following ranks of war
11.1206: moved to the city-wall, nor wide the space
11.1207: that measured 'twixt the twain. Aeneas saw
11.1208: the plain with dust o'erclouded, and the lines
11.1209: of the Laurentian host extending far;
11.1210: Turnus, as clearly, saw the war array
11.1211: of dread Aeneas, and his ear perceived
11.1212: loud tramp of mail-clad men and snorting steeds.
11.1213: Soon had they sped to dreadful shock of arms,
11.1214: hazard of war to try; but Phoebus now,
11.1215: glowing rose-red, had dipped his wearied wheel
11.1216: deep in Iberian seas, and brought back night
11.1217: above the fading day. So near the town
11.1218: both pitch their camps and make their ramparts strong.

12.1: When Turnus marks how much the Latins quail
12.2: in adverse war, how on himself they call
12.3: to keep his pledge, and with indignant eyes
12.4: gaze all his way, fierce rage implacable
12.5: swells his high heart. As when on Libyan plain
12.6: a lion, gashed along his tawny breast
12.7: by the huntsman's grievous thrust, awakens him
12.8: unto his last grim fight, and gloriously
12.9: shaking the great thews of his maned neck,
12.10: shrinks not, but crushes the despoiler's spear
12.11: with blood-sprent, roaring mouth,—not less than so
12.12: burns the wild soul of Turnus and his ire.
12.13: Thus to the King he spoke with stormful brow:
12.14: “The war lags not for Turnus' sake. No cause
12.15: constrains the Teucrian cowards and their King
12.16: to eat their words and what they pledged refuse.
12.17: On his own terms I come. Bring forward, sire,
12.18: the sacrifice, and seal the pact I swear:
12.19: either to deepest hell this hand shall fling
12.21: may sit at ease and see!—and my sole sword
12.22: efface the general shame; or let him claim
12.23: the conquest, and Lavinia be his bride.”
12.24: To him Latinus with unruffled mind
12.25: thus made reply: “O youth surpassing brave!
12.26: The more thy sanguinary valor burns
12.27: beyond its wont, the more with toilsome care
12.28: I ponder with just fear what chance may fall,
12.29: weighing it well. Thy father Daunus' throne,
12.30: and many a city by thy sword subdued,
12.31: are still thy own. Latinus also boasts
12.32: much golden treasure and a liberal hand.
12.33: Other unwedded maids of noble stem
12.34: in Latium and Laurentine land are found.
12.35: Permit me, then, to tell thee without guile
12.36: things hard to utter; let them deeply fill
12.37: thy listening soul. My sacred duty 'twas
12.38: to plight my daughter's hand to nonesoe'er
12.39: of all her earlier wooers—so declared
12.40: the gods and oracles; but overcome
12.41: by love of thee, by thy dear, kindred blood,
12.42: and by the sad eyes of my mournful Queen,
12.43: I shattered every bond; I snatched away
12.44: the plighted maiden from her destined lord,
12.45: and took up impious arms. What evil case
12.46: upon that deed ensued, what hapless wars,
12.47: thou knowest, since thyself dost chiefly bear
12.48: the cruel burden. In wide-ranging fight
12.49: twice-conquered, our own city scarce upholds
12.50: the hope of Italy. Yon Tiber's wave
12.51: still runs warm with my people's blood; the plains
12.52: far round us glisten with their bleaching bones.
12.53: Why tell it o'er and o'er? What maddening dream
12.54: perverts my mind? If after Turnus slain
12.55: I must for friendship of the Trojan sue,
12.56: were it not better to suspend the fray
12.57: while Turnus lives? For what will be the word
12.58: of thy Rutulian kindred—yea, of all
12.59: Italia, if to death I give thee o'er—
12.60: (Which Heaven avert!) because thou fain wouldst win
12.61: my daughter and be sworn my friend and son?
12.62: Bethink thee what a dubious work is war;
12.63: have pity on thy father's reverend years,
12.64: who even now thy absence daily mourns
12.65: in Ardea, his native land and thine.”
12.66: But to this pleading Turnus' frenzied soul
12.67: yields not at all, but rather blazes forth
12.68: more wildly, and his fever fiercer burns
12.69: beneath the healer's hand. In answer he,
12.70: soon as his passion gathered voice, began:
12.71: “This keen solicitude for love of me,
12.72: I pray, good sire, for love of me put by!
12.73: And let me traffic in the just exchange
12.74: of death for glory. This right hand, O King,
12.75: can scatter shafts not few, nor do I wield
12.76: untempered steel. Whene'er I make a wound
12.77: blood follows. For my foeman when we meet
12.78: will find no goddess-mother near, with hand
12.79: to hide him in her woman's skirt of cloud,
12.80: herself in dim, deluding shade concealed.”
12.81: But now the Queen, whose whole heart shrank in fear
12.82: from these new terms of duel, wept aloud,
12.83: and like one dying clasped her fiery son:
12.84: “O Turnus, by these tears-if in thy heart
12.86: who art of our distressful, dark old age
12.87: the only hope and peace, the kingly name
12.88: and glory of Latinus rests in thee;
12.89: thou art the mighty prop whereon is stayed
12.90: our falling house. One favor I implore:
12.91: give o'er this fight with Trojans. In such strife
12.92: thy destined doom is destined to be mine
12.93: by the same fatal stroke. For in that hour
12.94: this hated life shall cease, nor will I look
12.95: with slave's eyes on Aeneas as my son.”
12.96: Lavinia heard her mother's voice, and tears
12.97: o'erflowed her scarlet cheek, where blushes spread
12.98: like flame along her warm, young face and brow:
12.99: as when the Indian ivory must wear
12.100: ensanguined crimson stain, or lilies pale
12.101: mingled with roses seem to blush, such hues
12.102: her virgin features bore; and love's desire
12.103: disturbed his breast, as, gazing on the maid,
12.104: his martial passion fiercer flamed; whereon
12.105: in brief speech he addressed the Queen: “No tears!
12.106: No evil omen, mother, I implore!
12.107: Make me no sad farewells, as I depart
12.108: to the grim war-god's game! Can Turnus' hand
12.110: Idmon, my herald, to the Phrygian King,
12.111: and tell him this—a word not framed to please:
12.112: soon as Aurora from her crimson car
12.113: flushes to-morrow's sky, let him no more
12.114: against the Rutule lead the Teucrian line;
12.115: let Teucrian swords and Rutule take repose,
12.116: while with our own spilt blood we twain will make
12.117: an end of war; on yonder mortal field
12.118: let each man woo Lavinia for his bride.”
12.119: So saying, he hied him to his lordly halls,
12.120: summoned his steeds, and with pleased eye surveyed
12.121: their action proud: them Orithyia, bride
12.122: of Boreas, to Sire Pilumnus gave,
12.123: which in their whiteness did surpass the snow
12.124: in speed the wind. The nimble charioteers
12.125: stood by and smote with hollowed hand and palm
12.126: the sounding chests, or combed the necks and manes.
12.127: But he upon his kingly shoulders clasped
12.128: his corselet, thick o'erlaid with blazoned gold
12.129: and silvery orichalch; he fitted him
12.130: with falchion, shield, and helm of purple plume,
12.131: that falchion which the Lord of Fire had made
12.132: for Daunus, tempering in the Stygian wave
12.133: when white it glowed; next grasped he the good spear
12.134: which leaned its weight against a column tall
12.135: in the mid-court, Auruncan Actor's spoil,
12.136: and waved it wide in air with mighty cry:
12.137: “O spear, that ne'er did fail me when I called,
12.138: the hour is come! Once mighty Actor's hand,
12.139: but now the hand of Turnus is thy lord.
12.140: Grant me to strike that carcase to the ground,
12.141: and with strong hand the corselet rip and rend
12.142: from off that Phrygian eunuch: let the dust
12.143: befoul those tresses, tricked to curl so fine
12.144: with singeing steel and sleeked with odorous oil.”
12.145: Such frenzy goads him: his impassioned brow
12.146: is all on flame, the wild eyes flash with fire.
12.147: Thus, bellowing loud before the fearful fray,
12.148: some huge bull proves the fury of his horns,
12.149: pushing against a tree-trunk; his swift thrusts
12.150: would tear the winds in pieces; while his hoofs
12.151: toss up the turf and sand, rehearsing war.
12.152: That self-same day with aspect terrible
12.153: Aeneas girt him in the wondrous arms
12.154: his mother gave; made sharp his martial steel,
12.155: and roused his heart to ire; though glad was he
12.156: to seal such truce and end the general war.
12.157: Then he spoke comfort to his friends; and soothed
12.159: but on Latinus bade his heralds lay
12.160: unyielding terms and laws of peace impose.
12.161: Soon as the breaking dawn its glory threw
12.162: along the hills, and from the sea's profound
12.163: leaped forth the horses of the sun-god's car,
12.164: from lifted nostrils breathing light and fire,
12.165: then Teucrian and Rutulian measured out
12.166: a place for duel, underneath the walls
12.167: of the proud city. In the midst were set
12.168: altars of turf and hearth-stones burning bright
12.169: in honor of their common gods. Some brought
12.170: pure waters and the hallowed flame, their thighs
12.171: in priestly skirt arrayed, and reverend brows
12.172: with vervain bound. Th' Ausonians, spear in hand,
12.173: out from the city's crowded portals moved
12.174: in ordered column: next the Trojans all,
12.175: with Tuscan host in various martial guise,
12.176: equipped with arms of steel, as if they heard
12.177: stern summons to the fight. Their captains, too,
12.178: emerging from the multitude, in pride
12.179: of gold and purple, hurried to and fro:
12.180: Mnestheus of royal stem, Asilas brave;
12.181: and Neptune's offspring, tamer of the steed,
12.182: Messapus. Either host, at signal given,
12.183: to its own ground retiring, fixed in earth
12.184: the long shafts of the spears and stacked the shields.
12.185: Then eagerly to tower and rampart fly
12.186: the women, the infirm old men, the throng
12.187: of the unarmed, and sit them there at gaze,
12.188: or on the columned gates expectant stand.
12.189: But Juno, peering from that summit proud
12.190: which is to-day the Alban (though that time
12.191: nor name nor fame the hallowed mountain knew),
12.192: surveyed the plain below and fair array
12.193: of Trojan and Laurentine, by the walls
12.195: with Turnus' sister she began converse,
12.196: goddess with goddess; for that nymph divine
12.197: o'er Alba's calm lakes and loud rivers reigns;
12.198: Jove, the high monarch of th' ethereal sky,
12.199: gave her such glory when he stole away
12.200: her virgin zone. “O nymph“, she said, “who art
12.201: the pride of flowing streams, and much beloved
12.202: of our own heart! thou knowest thou alone
12.203: hast been my favorite of those Latin maids
12.204: that to proud Jove's unthankful bed have climbed;
12.205: and willingly I found thee place and share
12.206: in our Olympian realm. So blame not me,
12.207: but hear, Juturna, what sore grief is thine:
12.208: while chance and destiny conceded aught
12.209: of strength to Latium's cause, I shielded well
12.210: both Turnus and thy city's wall; but now
12.211: I see our youthful champion make his war
12.212: with fates adverse. The Parcae's day of doom
12.214: to Iook upon such fight, such fatal league.
12.215: If for thy brother's life thou couldst be bold
12.216: to venture some swift blow, go, strike it now!
12.217: 'T is fit and fair! Some issue fortunate
12.218: may tread on sorrow's heel.” She scarce had said,
12.219: when rained the quick tears from Juturna's eyes.
12.220: Three times and yet again her desperate hand
12.221: smote on her comely breast. But Juno cried,
12.222: “No tears to-day! But haste thee, haste and find
12.223: what way, if way there be, from clutch of death
12.224: to tear thy brother free; arouse the war;
12.225: their plighted peace destroy. I grant thee leave
12.226: such boldness to essay.” With this command
12.227: she left the nymph dismayed and grieving sore.
12.228: Meanwhile the kings ride forth: Latinus first,
12.229: looming tall-statured from his four-horse car;
12.230: twelve rays of gold encircle his bright brow,
12.231: sign of the sun-god, his progenitor;
12.232: next Turnus, driving snow-white steeds, is seen,—
12.233: two bread-tipped javelins in his hand he bears;
12.234: Aeneas, of Rome's blood the source and sire,
12.235: with star-bright shield and panoply divine,
12.236: far-shining comes; Ascanius by his side—
12.237: of Roman greatness the next hope is he.
12.238: To camp they rode, where, garbed in blameless white,
12.239: with youngling swine and two-year sheep unshorn,
12.240: the priest before the flaming altars drove
12.241: his flock and offering: to the rising sun
12.242: all eyes are lifted, as with careful hand
12.243: the salted meal is scattered, while with knives
12.244: they mark each victim's brow, outpouring wine
12.245: from shallow bowls, the sacrifice to bless.
12.246: Then good Aeneas, his sword drawn, put forth
12.247: this votive prayer: “O Sun in heaven; and thou,
12.248: Italia, for whom such toils I bear,
12.249: be witness of my orison. On thee,
12.250: Father omnipotent, I call; on thee,
12.251: his Queen Saturnia,—now may she be
12.252: more gracious to my prayer! O glorious Mars,
12.254: all wars begin and end, on thee I call;
12.255: hail, all ye river-gods and haunted springs;
12.256: hail, whatsoever gods have seat of awe
12.257: in yonder distant sky, and ye whose power
12.258: is in the keeping of the deep, blue sea:
12.259: if victory to Ausonian Turnus fall,
12.260: then let my vanquished people take its way
12.261: unto Evander's city! From these plains
12.262: Iulus shall retire—so stands the bond;
12.263: nor shall the Trojans with rebellious sword
12.264: bring after-trouble on this land and King.
12.265: But if on arms of ours success shall shine,
12.266: as I doubt not it shall (may gods on high
12.267: their will confirm!), I purpose not to chain
12.269: nor seek I kingly power. Let equal laws
12.271: the two unconquered nations; both shall share
12.272: my worshipped gods. Latinus, as my sire,
12.273: shall keep his sword, and as my sire receive
12.275: shall build my stronghold, but our citadel
12.277: Aeneas thus: then with uplifted eyes
12.278: Latinus swore, his right hand raised to heaven:
12.279: “I too, Aeneas, take the sacred vow.
12.280: By earth and sea and stars in heaven I swear,
12.281: by fair Latona's radiant children twain,
12.282: and two-browed Janus; by the shadowy powers
12.283: of Hades and th' inexorable shrines
12.284: of the Infernal King; and may Jove hear,
12.285: who by his lightnings hallows what is sworn!
12.286: I touch these altars, and my lips invoke
12.287: the sacred altar-fires that 'twixt us burn:
12.288: we men of Italy will make this peace
12.289: inviolate, and its bond forever keep,
12.290: let come what will; there is no power can change
12.291: my purpose, not if ocean's waves o'erwhelm
12.292: the world in billowy deluge and obscure
12.293: the bounds of heaven and hell. We shall remain
12.294: immutable as my smooth sceptre is“
12.295: (By chance a sceptre in his hand he bore),
12.296: “which wears no more light leaf or branching shade;
12.297: for long since in the grove 't was plucked away
12.298: from parent stem, and yielded to sharp steel
12.299: its leaves and limbs; erewhile 't was but a tree,
12.300: till the wise craftsman with fair sheath of bronze
12.301: encircled it and laid it in the hands
12.302: of Latium's royal sires.” With words like these
12.303: they swore the bond, in the beholding eyes
12.304: of gathered princes. Then they slit the throats
12.305: of hallowed victims o'er the altar's blaze,
12.306: drew forth the quivering vitals, and with flesh
12.307: on loaded chargers heaped the sacrifice.
12.308: But to Rutulian eyes th' approaching joust
12.309: seemed all ill-matched; and shifting hopes and fears
12.310: disturbed their hearts the closer they surveyed
12.311: th' unequal risks: still worse it was to see
12.312: how Turnus, silent and with downcast eyes,
12.313: dejectedly drew near the place of prayer,
12.314: worn, pale, and wasted in his youthful bloom.
12.315: The nymph Juturna, with a sister's fear,
12.316: noted the growing murmur, and perceived
12.317: how all the people's will did shift and change;
12.318: she went from rank to rank, feigning the shape
12.319: of Camers, scion of illustrious line,
12.320: with heritage of valor, and himself
12.321: dauntless in war; unceasingly she ran
12.322: from rank to rank, spreading with skilful tongue
12.323: opinions manifold, and thus she spoke:
12.324: “Will ye not blush, Rutulians, so to stake
12.325: one life for many heroes? Are we not
12.326: their match in might and numbers? O, behold
12.327: those Trojan sons of Heaven making league
12.328: with exiled Arcady; see Tuscan hordes
12.329: storming at Turnus. Yet we scarce could find
12.330: one foe apiece, forsooth, if we should dare
12.331: fight them with half our warriors. Of a truth
12.332: your champion brave shall to those gods ascend
12.333: before whose altars his great heart he vows;
12.334: and lips of men while yet on earth he stays
12.335: will spread his glory far. Ourselves, instead,
12.336: must crouch to haughty masters, and resign
12.337: this fatherland upon whose fruitful fields
12.338: we dwell at ease.” So speaking, she inflamed
12.339: the warriors' minds, and through the legions ran
12.341: and even Latium wavered. Those who late
12.342: prayed but for rest and safety, clamored loud
12.343: for arms, desired annulment of the league,
12.345: Whereon Juturna tried a mightier stroke,
12.346: a sign from heaven, which more than all beside
12.347: confused the Latins and deceived their hearts
12.348: with prodigy. For through the flaming skies
12.349: Jove's golden eagle swooped, and scattered far
12.350: a clamorous tribe of river-haunting birds;
12.351: then, swiftly to the waters falling, seized
12.352: one noble swan, which with keen, curving claws
12.353: he ruthless bore away: th' Italians all
12.354: watched eagerly, while the loud-screaming flock
12.355: wheeled upward (wondrous sight!), with host of wings
12.356: shadowed the sky, and in a legion-cloud
12.357: chased through the air the foe; till, overborne
12.358: by heavier odds, the eagle from his claws
12.359: flung back his victim to the waves, and fled
12.360: to the dim, distant heaven. The Rutules then
12.361: hailed the good omen with consenting cry,
12.362: and grasped the sword and shield. Tolumnius
12.363: the augur spake first: “Lo, the sign I sought
12.364: with many a prayer! I welcome and obey
12.365: the powers divine. Take me for captain, me!
12.366: And draw your swords, ye wretches, whom th' assault
12.367: of yonder foreign scoundrel puts in fear
12.368: like feeble birds, and with his violence
12.369: lays waste your shore. He too shall fly away,
12.370: spreading his ships' wings on the distant seas.
12.371: Close up your ranks—one soul in all our breasts!
12.372: Defend in open war your stolen King.”
12.373: So saying, he hurled upon th' opposing foe
12.374: his javelin, running forward. The strong shaft
12.375: of corner whistled shrill, and clove the air
12.377: and all th' onlookers at the spectacle
12.378: leaped up amazed, and every heart beat high.
12.379: The spear sped flying to the foeman's line,
12.380: where stood nine goodly brethren, pledges all
12.381: of one true Tuscan mother to her lord,
12.382: Gylippus of Arcadia; it struck full
12.383: on one of these at his gold-belted waist,
12.384: and where the clasp clung, pierced the rib clean through.
12.385: And stretched the fair youth in his glittering arms
12.386: full length and lifeless on the yellow sand.
12.387: His brothers then, bold band to wrath aroused
12.388: by sorrow, seize the sword or snatch the spear
12.389: and blindly charge. Opposing them, the host
12.391: the Trojans like a torrent pour, enforced
12.392: by Tuscans and the gay-accoutred clans
12.393: of Arcady. One passion moved in all
12.394: to try the judgment of the sword. They tore
12.395: the altars down: a very storm of spears
12.396: rose angrily to heaven, in iron rain
12.397: down-pouring: while the priests bore far away
12.398: the sacrificial bowls and sacred fires.
12.399: Even Latinus fled; his stricken gods
12.400: far from his violated oath he bore.
12.401: Some leaped to horse or chariot and rode
12.402: with naked swords in air. Messapus, wild
12.403: to break the truce, assailed the Tuscan King,
12.404: Aulestes, dressed in kingly blazon fair,
12.405: with fearful shock of steeds; the Tuscan dropped
12.406: helplessly backward, striking as he fell
12.407: his head and shoulders on the altar-stone
12.408: that lay behind him. But Messapus flew,
12.409: infuriate, a javelin in his hand,
12.410: and, towering o'er the suppliant, smote him strong
12.411: with the great beam-like spear, and loudly cried:
12.412: “Down with him! Ah! no common victim he
12.413: to give the mighty gods!” Italia's men
12.414: despoiled the dead man ere his limbs were cold.
12.415: Then Corynaeus snatched a burning brand
12.416: out of the altar, and as Ebysus
12.417: came toward him for to strike, he hurled the flame
12.418: full in his face: the big beard quickly blazed
12.419: with smell of singeing; while the warrior bold
12.420: strode over him, and seized with firm left hand
12.421: his quailing foe's Iong hair; then with one knee
12.422: he pushed and strained, compelled him to the `ground—
12.423: and struck straight at his heart with naked steel.
12.424: The shepherd Alsus in the foremost line
12.425: came leaping through the spears; when o'er him towered
12.426: huge Podalirius with a flashing sword
12.427: in close pursuit; the mighty battle-axe
12.428: clove him with swinging stroke from brow to chin,
12.429: and spilt along his mail the streaming gore:
12.430: so stern repose and iron slumber fell
12.431: upon that shepherd's eyes, and sealed their gaze
12.432: in endless night. But good Aeneas now
12.433: stretched forth his unarmed hand, and all unhelmed
12.434: thus Ioudly to his people called: “What means
12.435: this frantic stir, this quarrel rashly bold?
12.436: Recall your martial rage! The pledge is given
12.437: and all its terms agreed. 'T is only I
12.438: do lawful battle here. So let me forth,
12.439: and tremble not. My own hand shall confirm
12.440: the solemn treaty. For these rites consign
12.441: Turnus to none but me.” Yet while he spoke,
12.442: behold, a winged arrow, hissing loud,
12.443: the hero pierced; but what bold hand impelled
12.444: its whirling speed, none knew; nor if it were
12.445: chance or some power divine that brought this fame
12.446: upon Rutulia; for the glorious deed
12.447: was covered o'er with silence: none would boast
12.448: an arrow guilty of Aeneas' wound.
12.449: When Turnus saw Aeneas from the line
12.450: retreating, and the captains in dismay,
12.451: with sudden hope he burned: he called for steeds,
12.452: for arms, and, leaping to his chariot,
12.453: rode insolently forth, the reins in hand.
12.454: Many strong heroes he dispatched to die,
12.455: as on he flew, and many stretched half-dead,
12.456: or from his chariot striking, or from far
12.457: raining his javelins on the recreant foe.
12.458: As Mars, forth-speeding by the wintry stream
12.459: of Hebrus, smites his sanguinary shield
12.460: and whips the swift steeds to the front of war,
12.461: who, flying past the winds of eve and morn,
12.462: scour the wide champaign; the bounds of Thrace
12.463: beneath their hoof-beats thunder; the dark shapes
12.464: of Terror, Wrath, and Treachery move on
12.465: in escort of the god: in such grim guise
12.466: bold Turnus lashed into the fiercest fray
12.467: his streaming steeds, that pitiful to see
12.468: trod down the slaughtered foe; each flying hoof
12.469: scattered a bloody dew; their path was laid
12.470: in mingled blood and sand. To death he flung
12.472: two smitten in close fight and one from far:
12.473: also from far he smote with fatal spear
12.475: whom Imbrasus himself in Lycia bred,
12.476: and honored them with arms of equal skill
12.477: when grappling with a foe, or o'er the field
12.478: speeding a war-horse faster than the wind.
12.479: Elsewhere Eumedes through a throng of foes
12.480: to battle rode, the high-born Dolon's child,
12.481: famous in war, who bore his grandsire's name,
12.482: but seemed in might and courage like his sire:
12.483: that prince, who reconnoitring crept so near
12.484: the Argive camp, he dared to claim for spoil
12.485: the chariot of Achilles; but that day
12.486: great Diomed for such audacious deed
12.487: paid wages otherwise,—and he no more
12.488: dreamed to possess the steeds of Peleus' son.
12.489: When Turnus recognized in open field
12.490: this warrior, though far, he aimed and flung
12.491: his javelin through the spacious air; then stayed
12.492: his coursers twain, and, leaping from his car,
12.493: found the wretch helpless fallen; so planted he
12.494: his foot upon his neck, and from his hand
12.495: wrested the sword and thrust it glittering
12.496: deep in the throat, thus taunting as he slew:
12.497: “There's land for thee, thou Trojan! Measure there
12.498: th' Hesperian provinces thy sword would find.
12.499: Such reward will I give to all who dare
12.500: draw steel on me; such cities they shall build.”
12.501: To bear him company his spear laid low
12.503: Chloreus and Dares, and Thymoetes thrown
12.504: sheer off the shoulders of his balking steed.
12.505: As when from Thrace the north wind thunders down
12.506: the vast Aegean, flinging the swift flood
12.507: against the shore, and where his blasts assail
12.508: the cloudy cohorts vanish out of heaven:
12.509: so before Turnus, where his path he clove,
12.510: the lines fell back, the wheeling legions fled.
12.511: The warrior's own wild impulse swept him on,
12.512: and every wind that o'er his chariot blew
12.513: shook out his plume in air. But such advance
12.514: so bold, so furious, Phegeus could not brook,
12.515: but, fronting the swift chariot's path, he seized
12.516: the foam-flecked bridles of its coursers wild,
12.517: while from the yoke his body trailed and swung;
12.518: the broad lance found his naked side, and tore
12.519: his double corselet, pricking lightly through
12.520: the outer flesh; but he with lifted shield
12.521: still fought his foe and thrust with falchion bare;
12.522: but the fierce pace of whirling wheel and pole
12.523: flung him down prone, and stretched him on the plain.
12.524: Then Turnus, aiming with relentless sword
12.525: between the corselet's edge and helmet's rim
12.526: struck off his whole head, leaving on the sands
12.527: the mutilated corpse. While thus afield
12.528: victorious Turnus dealt out death and doom,
12.529: Mnestheus, Achates true, and by their side
12.530: Ascanius, have carried to the camp
12.531: Aeneas, gashed and bleeding, whose long lance
12.532: sustained his limping step. With fruitless rage
12.533: he struggled with the spear-head's splintered barb,
12.534: and bade them help him by the swiftest way
12.535: to carve the wound out with a sword, to rip
12.536: the clinging weapon forth, and send him back
12.537: to meet the battle. Quickly to his side
12.538: came Iapyx, dear favorite and friend
12.539: of Phoebus, upon whom the god bestowed
12.540: his own wise craft and power, Iove-impelled.
12.541: The gifts of augury were given, and song,
12.542: with arrows of swift wing: he when his sire
12.543: was carried forth to die, deferred the doom
12.544: for many a day, by herbs of virtue known
12.545: to leechcraft; and without reward or praise
12.546: his silent art he plied. Aeneas stood,
12.547: bitterly grieving, propped upon his spear;
12.548: a throng of warriors were near him, and
12.550: gathered his garments up as leeches do,
12.551: and with skilled hand and Phoebus' herbs of power
12.552: bustled in vain; in vain his surgery
12.553: pried at the shaft, and with a forceps strong
12.554: seized on the buried barb. But Fortune gave
12.555: no remedy, nor did Apollo aid
12.556: his votary. So more and more grim fear
12.557: stalks o'er the field of war, and nearer hies
12.558: the fatal hour; the very heavens are dust;
12.559: the horsemen charge, and in the midmost camp
12.560: a rain of javelins pours. The dismal cry
12.561: of men in fierce fight, and of men who fall
12.562: beneath relentless Mars, rends all the air.
12.563: Then Venus, by her offspring's guiltless woe
12.564: sore moved, did cull from Cretan Ida's crest
12.565: some dittany, with downy leaf and stem
12.566: and flowers of purple bloom—a simple known
12.567: to mountain goats, when to their haunches clings
12.568: an arrow gone astray. This Venus brought,
12.569: mantling her shape in cloud; and this she steeped
12.570: in bowls of glass, infusing secretly
12.571: ambrosia's healing essence and sweet drops
12.572: of fragrant panacea. Such a balm
12.573: aged Iapyx poured upon the wound,
12.574: though unaware; and sudden from the flesh
12.575: all pain departed and the blood was staunched,
12.576: while from the gash the arrow uncompelled
12.577: followed the hand and dropped: his wonted strength
12.578: flowed freshly through the hero's frame. “Make haste!
12.579: Bring forth his arms! Why tarry any more?”
12.580: Iapyx shouted, being first to fire
12.581: their courage 'gainst the foe. “This thing is done
12.582: not of man's knowledge, nor by sovereign skill;
12.583: nor has my hand, Aeneas, set thee free.
12.584: Some mighty god thy vigor gives again
12.585: for mighty deeds.” Aeneas now put on,
12.586: all fever for the fight, his golden greaves,
12.587: and, brooking not delay, waved wide his spear.
12.588: Soon as the corselet and the shield were bound
12.589: on back and side, he clasped Ascanius
12.590: to his mailed breast, and through his helmet grim
12.591: tenderly kissed his son. “My boy", he cried,
12.592: “What valor is and patient, genuine toil
12.593: learn thou of me; let others guide thy feet
12.594: to prosperous fortune. Let this hand and sword
12.595: defend thee through the war and lead thee on
12.596: to high rewards. Thou also play the man!
12.597: And when thy riper vigor soon shall bloom,
12.598: forget not in thy heart to ponder well
12.599: the story of our line. Heed honor's call,
12.600: like Sire Aeneas and Hector thy close kin.”
12.601: After such farewell word, he from the gates
12.602: in mighty stature strode, and swung on high
12.603: his giant spear. With him in serried line
12.604: Antheus and Mnestheus moved, and all the host
12.605: from the forsaken fortress poured. The plain
12.606: was darkened with their dust; the startled earth
12.607: shook where their footing fell. From distant hill
12.608: Turnus beheld them coming, and the eyes
12.609: of all Ausonia saw: a chill of fear
12.610: shot through each soldier's marrow; in their van
12.611: Juturna knew full well the dreadful sound,
12.612: and fled before it, shuddering. But he
12.613: hurried his murky cohorts o'er the plain.
12.614: As when a tempest from the riven sky
12.615: drives landward o'er mid-ocean, and from far
12.616: the hearts of husbandmen, foreboding woe,
12.617: quake ruefully,—for this will come and rend
12.618: their trees asunder, kill the harvests all,
12.619: and sow destruction broadcast; in its path
12.620: fly roaring winds, swift heralds of the storm:
12.621: such dire approach the Trojan chieftain showed
12.622: before his gathered foes. In close array
12.623: they wedge their ranks about him. With a sword
12.626: Achates shears the head; from Ufens, Gyas;
12.627: Tolumnius the augur falls, the same
12.628: who flung the first spear to the foeman's line.
12.629: Uprose to heaven the cries. In panic now
12.630: the Rutules in retreating clouds of dust
12.631: scattered across the plain. Aeneas scorned
12.632: either the recreant or resisting foe
12.633: to slaughter, or the men who shoot from far:
12.634: for through the war-cloud he but seeks the arms
12.635: of Turnus, and to single combat calls.
12.637: distraught with terror, strikes down from his place
12.639: forward among the reins and off the pole.
12.640: Him leaving on the field, her own hand grasped
12.641: the loosely waving reins, while she took on
12.642: Metiscus' shape, his voice, and blazoned arms.
12.643: As when through some rich master's spacious halls
12.644: speeds the black swallow on her lightsome wing,
12.645: exploring the high roof, or harvesting
12.646: some scanty morsel for her twittering brood,
12.649: among the hostile ranks, and wings her way
12.650: behind the swift steeds of the whirling car.
12.651: At divers points she lets the people see
12.652: her brother's glory, but not yet allows
12.653: the final tug of war; her pathless flight
12.654: keeps far away. Aeneas too must take
12.655: a course circuitous, and follows close
12.656: his foeman's track; Ioud o'er the scattered lines
12.657: he shouts his challenge. But whene'er his eyes
12.658: discern the foe, and fain he would confront
12.660: the chariot round and flies. What can he do?
12.661: Aeneas' wrath storms vainly to and fro,
12.662: and wavering purposes his heart divide.
12.663: Against him lightly leaped Messapus forth,
12.664: bearing two pliant javelins tipped with steel;
12.665: and, whirling one in air, he aimed it well,
12.666: with stroke unfailing. Great Aeneas paused
12.667: in cover of his shield and crouched low down
12.668: upon his haunches. But the driven spear
12.669: battered his helmet's peak and plucked away
12.670: the margin of his plume. Then burst his rage:
12.671: his cunning foes had forced him; so at last,
12.672: while steeds and chariot in the distance fly,
12.673: he plunged him in the fray, and called on Jove
12.674: the altars of that broken oath to see.
12.675: Now by the war-god's favor he began
12.676: grim, never-pitying slaughter, and flung free
12.679: such horror can make known? What song declare
12.680: the bloodshed manifold, the princes slain,
12.681: or flying o'er the field from Turnus' blade,
12.682: or from the Trojan King? Did Jove ordain
12.683: so vast a shock of arms should interpose
12.686: staying the Trojan charge—and with swift blow
12.687: struck at him sidewise, where the way of death
12.688: is quickest, cleaving ribs and rounded side
12.689: with reeking sword. Turnus met Amycus,
12.690: unhorsed him, though himself afoot, and slew
12.691: Diores, his fair brother (one was pierced
12.692: fronting the spear, the other felled to earth
12.693: by strike of sword), and both their severed heads
12.694: he hung all dripping to his chariot's rim.
12.695: But Talon, Tanais, and Cethegus brave,
12.696: three in one onset, unto death went down
12.697: at great Aeneas' hand; and he dispatched
12.699: fair Peridia's child. Then Turnus slew
12.700: two Lycian brothers unto Phoebus dear,
12.702: who hated war (though vainly) when he plied
12.703: his native fisher-craft in Lerna's streams,
12.704: where from his mean abode he ne'er went forth
12.705: to wait at great men's doors, but with his sire
12.706: reaped the scant harvest of a rented glebe.
12.707: as from two sides two conflagrations sweep
12.708: dry woodlands or full copse of crackling bay,
12.709: or as, swift-leaping from the mountain-vales,
12.710: two flooded, foaming rivers seaward roar,
12.711: each on its path of death, not less uproused,
12.712: speed Turnus and Aeneas o'er the field;
12.713: now storms their martial rage; now fiercely swells
12.715: each hero's full strength to the slaughter moves.
12.716: Behold Murranus, boasting his high birth
12.717: from far-descended sires of storied name,
12.718: the line of Latium's kings! Aeneas now
12.719: with mountain-boulder lays him low in dust,
12.720: smitten with whirlwind of the monster stone;
12.721: and o'er him fallen under yoke and rein
12.722: roll his own chariot wheels, while with swift tread
12.723: the mad hoofs of his horses stamp him down,
12.724: not knowing him their lord. But Turnus found
12.725: proud Hyllus fronting him with frantic rage,
12.726: and at his golden helmet launched the shaft
12.727: that pierced it; in his cloven brain it clung.
12.728: Nor could thy sword, O Cretheus, save thee then
12.729: from Turnus, though of bravest Greeks the peer;
12.730: nor did Cupencus' gods their priest defend
12.731: against Aeneas, but his breast he gave
12.732: unto the hostile blade; his brazen shield
12.733: delayed no whit his miserable doom.
12.735: spread thy huge body dying on the ground;
12.736: yea, dying, thou whom Greeks in serried arms
12.737: subdued not, nor Achilles' hand that hurled
12.738: the throne of Priam down: here didst thou touch
12.739: thy goal of death; one stately house was thine
12.740: on Ida's mountain, at Lyrnessus, one;
12.741: Laurentum's hallowed earth was but thy grave.
12.742: Now the whole host contends; all Latium meets
12.743: all Ilium; Mnestheus and Serestus bold;
12.745: Asilas; Tuscans in a phalanx proud;
12.747: each warrior lifts him to his height supreme
12.748: of might and skill; no sloth nor lingering now,
12.749: but in one far-spread conflict all contend.
12.751: now stirred the purpose to make sudden way
12.752: against the city-wall, in swift advance
12.753: of all his line, confounding Latium so
12.754: with slaughter and surprise. His roving glance,
12.755: seeking for Turnus through the scattered lines
12.756: this way and that, beholds in distant view
12.757: the city yet unscathed and calmly free
12.758: from the wide-raging fight. Then on his soul
12.759: rushed the swift vision of a mightier war.
12.761: his chosen chiefs, he summons to his side,
12.762: and stands upon a hillock, whither throng
12.763: the Teucrian legions, each man holding fast
12.764: his shield and spear. He, towering high,
12.765: thus from the rampart to his people calls:
12.766: “Perform my bidding swiftly: Jove's own hand
12.767: sustains our power. Be ye not slack, because
12.768: the thing I do is sudden. For this day
12.769: I will pluck out th' offending root of war,—
12.770: yon city where Latinus reigns. Unless
12.771: it bear our yoke and heed a conqueror's will,
12.772: will lay low in dust its blazing towers.
12.773: Must I wait Turnus' pleasure, till he deign
12.774: to meet my stroke, and have a mind once more,
12.775: though vanquished, to show fight? My countrymen,
12.776: see yonder stronghold of their impious war!
12.777: Bring flames; avenge the broken oath with fire!”
12.778: Scarce had he said, when with consenting souls,
12.779: they speed them to the walls in dense array,
12.780: forming a wedge. Ladders now leap in air,
12.781: and sudden-blazing fires. In various war
12.782: some troops run charging at the city-gates,
12.783: and slay the guards; some fling the whirling spear
12.784: and darken heaven with arrows. In their van,
12.785: his right hand lifted to the wails and towers,
12.786: Aeneas, calling on the gods to hear,
12.787: loudly upbraids Latinus that once more
12.788: conflict is thrust upon him; that once more
12.789: Italians are his foes and violate
12.790: their second pledge of peace. So blazes forth
12.792: some would give o'er the city and fling wide
12.793: its portals to the Trojan, or drag forth
12.794: the King himself to parley; others fly
12.795: to arms, and at the rampart make a stand.
12.796: 'T is thus some shepherd from a caverned crag
12.797: stirs up the nested bees with plenteous fume
12.798: of bitter smoke; they, posting to and fro,
12.799: fly desperate round the waxen citadel,
12.800: and whet their buzzing fury; through their halls
12.801: the stench and blackness rolls; within the caves
12.802: noise and confusion ring; the fatal cloud
12.803: pours forth incessant on the vacant air.
12.804: But now a new adversity befell
12.805: the weary Latins, which with common woe
12.806: shook the whole city to its heart. The Queen,
12.807: when at her hearth she saw the close assault
12.808: of enemies, the walls beset, and fire
12.809: spreading from roof to roof, but no defence
12.810: from the Rutulian arms, nor front of war
12.811: with Turnus leading,—she, poor soul, believed
12.812: her youthful champion in the conflict slain;
12.813: and, mad with sudden sorrow, shrieked aloud
12.814: against herself, the guilty chief and cause
12.815: of all this ill; and, babbling her wild woe
12.816: in endless words, she rent her purple pall,
12.817: and with her own hand from the rafter swung
12.818: a noose for her foul death. The tidings dire
12.819: among the moaning wives of Latium spread,
12.820: and young Lavinia's frantic fingers tore
12.821: her rose-red cheek and hyacinthine hair.
12.822: Then all her company of women shrieked
12.823: in anguish, and the wailing echoed far
12.824: along the royal seat; from whence the tale
12.825: of sorrow through the peopled city flew;
12.826: hearts sank; Latinus rent his robes, appalled
12.827: to see his consort's doom, his falling throne;
12.828: and heaped foul dust upon his hoary hair.
12.829: Meanwhile the warrior Turnus far afield
12.830: pursued a scattered few; but less his speed,
12.831: for less and less his worn steeds worked his will;
12.832: and now wind-wafted to his straining ear
12.833: a nameless horror came, a dull, wild roar,
12.834: the city's tumult and distressful cry.
12.835: “Alack,” he cried, “what stirs in yonder walls
12.836: such anguish? Or why rings from side to side
12.837: such wailing through the city?” Asking so,
12.838: he tightened frantic grasp upon the rein.
12.839: To him his sister, counterfeiting still
12.840: the charioteer Metiscus, while she swayed
12.841: rein, steeds, and chariot, this answer made:
12.842: “Hither, my Turnus, let our arms pursue
12.843: the sons of Troy. Here lies the nearest way
12.844: to speedy triumph. There be other swords
12.845: to keep yon city safe. Aeneas now
12.846: storms against Italy in active war;
12.847: we also on this Trojan host may hurl
12.848: grim havoc. Nor shalt thou the strife give o'er
12.849: in glory second, nor in tale of slain.”
12.851: I knew thee what thou wert, when guilefully
12.852: thou didst confound their treaty, and enlist
12.853: thy whole heart in this war. No Ionger now
12.854: thy craft divine deceives me. But what god
12.855: compelled thee, from Olympus fallen so far,
12.856: to bear these cruel burdens? Wouldst thou see
12.857: thy wretched brother slaughtered? For what else
12.858: is in my power? What flattering hazard still
12.859: holds forth deliverance? My own eyes have seen
12.860: Murranus (more than any now on earth
12.861: my chosen friend) who, calling on my name,
12.862: died like a hero by a hero's sword.
12.864: to Iook upon my shame; the Teucrians
12.865: divide his arms for spoil and keep his bones.
12.866: Shall I stand tamely, till my hearth and home
12.867: are levelled with the ground? For this would be
12.868: the only blow not fallen. Shall my sword
12.869: not give the lie to Drances' insolence?
12.870: Shall I take flight and let my country see
12.871: her Turnus renegade? Is death a thing
12.872: so much to weep for? O propitious dead,
12.873: O spirits of the dark, receive and bless
12.874: me whom yon gods of light have cast away!
12.875: Sacred and guiltless shall my soul descend
12.876: to join your company; I have not been
12.877: unworthy offspring of my kingly sires.”
12.878: Scarce had he said, when through the foeman's line
12.879: Saces dashed forth upon a foaming steed,
12.880: his face gashed by an arrow. He cried loud
12.881: on Turnus' name: “O Turnus, but in thee
12.882: our last hope lies. Have pity on the woe
12.883: of all thy friends and kin! Aeneas hurls
12.884: his thunderbolt of war, and menaces
12.885: to crush the strongholds of all Italy,
12.886: and lay them low; already where we dwell
12.887: his firebrands are raining. Unto thee
12.888: the Latins Iook, and for thy valor call.
12.889: The King sits dumb and helpless, even he,
12.890: in doubt which son-in-law, which cause to choose.
12.891: Yea, and the Queen, thy truest friend, is fallen
12.892: by her own hand; gone mad with grief and fear,
12.893: she fled the light of day. At yonder gates
12.895: the brunt of battle; round us closely draw
12.896: the serried ranks; their naked blades of steel
12.897: are thick as ripening corn; wilt thou the while
12.898: speed in thy chariot o'er this empty plain?”
12.899: Dazed and bewildered by such host of ills,
12.900: Turnus stood dumb; in his pent bosom stirred
12.901: shame, frenzy, sorrow, a despairing love
12.902: goaded to fury, and a warrior's pride
12.905: of reason to his blinded soul returned,
12.906: he strained his flaming eyeballs to behold
12.907: the distant wall, and from his chariot gazed
12.908: in wonder at the lordly citadel.
12.909: For, lo, a pointed peak of flame uprolled
12.910: from tier to tier, and surging skyward seized
12.911: a tower—the very tower his own proud hands
12.912: had built of firm-set beams and wheeled in place,
12.913: and slung its Iofty bridges high in air.
12.914: “Fate is too strong, my sister! Seek no more
12.915: to stay the stroke. But let me hence pursue
12.916: that path where Heaven and cruel Fortune call.
12.917: Aeneas I must meet; and I must bear
12.918: the bitterness of death, whate'er it be.
12.919: O sister, thou shalt look upon my shame
12.920: no longer. But first grant a madman's will!”
12.921: He spoke; and leaping from his chariot, sped
12.922: through foes and foemen's spears, not seeing now
12.923: his sister's sorrow, as in swift career
12.924: he burst from line to line. Thus headlong falls
12.925: a mountain-boulder by a whirlwind flung
12.926: from lofty peak, or loosened by much rain,
12.927: or by insidious lapse of seasons gone;
12.928: the huge, resistless crag goes plunging down
12.929: by leaps and bounds, o'erwhelming as it flies
12.930: tall forests, Bocks and herds, and mortal men:
12.931: so through the scattered legions Turnus ran
12.932: straight to the city walls, where all the ground
12.933: was drenched with blood, and every passing air
12.934: shrieked with the noise of spears. His lifted hand
12.935: made sign of silence as he loudly called:
12.937: your spears withhold! The issue of the fray
12.938: is all my own. I only can repair
12.939: our broken truce by judgment of the sword.”
12.940: Back fell the hostile lines, and cleared the field.
12.941: But Sire Aeneas, hearing Turnus' name,
12.942: down the steep rampart from the citadel
12.943: unlingering tried, all lesser task laid by,
12.944: with joy exultant and dread-thundering arms.
12.945: Like Athos' crest he loomed, or soaring top
12.946: of Eryx, when the nodding oaks resound,
12.947: or sovereign Apennine that lifts in air
12.948: his forehead of triumphant snow. All eyes
12.950: were fixed his way; and all who kept a guard
12.951: on lofty rampart, or in siege below
12.952: were battering the foundations, now laid by
12.953: their implements and arms. Latinus too
12.954: stood awestruck to behold such champions, born
12.955: in lands far-sundered, met upon one field
12.956: for one decisive stroke of sword with sword.
12.957: Swift striding forth where spread the vacant plain,
12.958: they hurled their spears from far; then in close fight
12.959: the brazen shields rang. Beneath their tread
12.960: Earth groaned aloud, as with redoubling blows
12.961: their falchions fell; nor could a mortal eye
12.962: 'twixt chance and courage the dread work divide.
12.963: As o'er Taburnus' top, or spacious hills
12.964: of Sila, in relentless shock of war,
12.965: two bulls rush brow to brow, while terror-pale
12.966: the herdsmen fly; the herd is hushed with fear;
12.967: the heifers dumbly marvel which shall be
12.968: true monarch of the grove, whom all the kine
12.969: obedient follow; but the rival twain,
12.971: thrust with opposing horns, and bathe their necks
12.972: in streams of blood; the forest far and wide
12.973: repeats their bellowing rage: not otherwise
12.974: Trojan Aeneas and King Daunus' son
12.975: clashed shield on shield, till all the vaulted sky
12.976: felt the tremendous sound. The hand of Jove
12.977: held scales in equipoise, and threw thereon
12.978: th' unequal fortunes of the heroes twain:
12.979: one to vast labors doomed and one to die.
12.980: Soon Turnus, reckless of the risk, leaped forth,
12.981: upreached his whole height to his lifted sword,
12.982: and struck: the Trojans and the Latins pale
12.983: cried mightily, and all eyes turned one way
12.984: expectant. But the weak, perfidious sword
12.985: broke off, and as the blow descended, failed
12.986: its furious master, whose sole succor now
12.987: was flight; and swifter than the wind he flew.
12.988: But, lo! a hilt of form and fashion strange
12.989: lay in his helpless hand. For in his haste,
12.990: when to the battle-field his team he drove,
12.991: his father's sword forgotten (such the tale),
12.992: he snatched Metiscus' weapon. This endured
12.993: to strike at Trojan backs, as he pursued,
12.994: but when on Vulcan's armory divine
12.995: its earthly metal smote, the brittle blade
12.996: broke off like ice, and o'er the yellow sands
12.997: in flashing fragments scattered. Turnus now
12.998: takes mad flight o'er the distant plain, and winds
12.999: in wavering gyration round and round;
12.1000: for Troy's close ring confines him, and one way
