12.1001: a wide swamp lies, one way a frowning wall.
12.1002: But lo! Aeneas—though the arrow's wound
12.1003: still slackens him and oft his knees refuse
12.1005: his quailing foe, and dogs him stride for stride.
12.1006: As when a stag-hound drives the baffled roe
12.1007: to torrent's edge (or where the flaunting snare
12.1009: and with incessant barking swift pursues;
12.1010: while through the snared copse or embankment high
12.1011: the frightened creature by a thousand ways
12.1012: doubles and turns; but that keen Umbrian hound
12.1013: with wide jaws, undesisting, grasps his prey,
12.1014: or, thinking that he grasps it, snaps his teeth
12.1015: cracking together, and deludes his rage,
12.1016: devouring empty air: then peal on peal
12.1017: the cry of hunters bursts; the lake and shore

12.1019: such was the flight of Turnus, who reviled
12.1020: the Rutules as he fled, and loudly sued
12.1021: of each by name to fetch his own lost sword.
12.1022: Aeneas vowed destruction and swift death
12.1023: to all who dared come near, and terrified
12.1024: their trembling souls with menace that his power
12.1025: would raze their city to the ground. Straightway,
12.1026: though wounded, he gave chase, and five times round
12.1027: in circles ran; then winding left and right
12.1028: coursed the swift circles o'er. For, lo! the prize
12.1029: is no light laurel or a youthful game:
12.1030: for Turnus' doom and death their race is run.
12.1031: But haply in that place a sacred tree,
12.1032: a bitter-leaved wild-olive, once had grown,
12.1033: to Faunus dear, and venerated oft
12.1034: by mariners safe-rescued from the waves,
12.1035: who nailed their gifts thereon, or hung in air
12.1036: their votive garments to Laurentum's god.
12.1037: But, heeding not, the Teucrians had shorn
12.1038: the stem away, to clear the field for war.
12.1039: 'T was here Aeneas' lance stuck fast; its speed
12.1040: had driven it firmly inward, and it clave
12.1041: to the hard, clinging root. Anchises' son
12.1042: bent o'er it, and would wrench his weapon free,
12.1043: and follow with a far-flung javelin
12.1044: the swift out-speeding foe. But Turnus then,
12.1045: bewildered and in terror, cried aloud:
12.1046: “O Faunus, pity me and heed my prayer!
12.1047: Hold fast his weapon, O benignant Earth!
12.1048: If ere these hands have rendered offering due,
12.1049: where yon polluting Teucrians fight and slay.”
12.1050: He spoke; invoking succor of the god,
12.1051: with no Iost prayer. For tugging valiantly
12.1052: and laboring long against the stubborn stem,
12.1053: Aeneas with his whole strength could but fail
12.1054: to Ioose the clasping tree. While fiercely thus
12.1055: he strove and strained, Juturna once again,
12.1057: ran to her brother's aid, restoring him
12.1058: his own true sword. But Venus, wroth to see
12.1059: what license to the dauntless nymph was given,
12.1060: herself came near, and plucked from that deep root
12.1061: the javelin forth. So both with lofty mien
12.1062: strode forth new-armed, new-hearted: one made bold
12.1063: by his good sword, the other, spear in hand,
12.1064: uptowered in wrath, and with confronting brows
12.1065: they set them to the war-god's breathless game.
12.1067: to Juno speaks, as from an amber cloud
12.1068: the strife she views: “My Queen, what end shall be?
12.1069: What yet remains? Thou seest Aeneas' name
12.1070: numbered with tutelary gods of power;
12.1071: and well thou know'st what station in the sky
12.1072: his starward destiny intends. What scheme
12.1073: vexes thy bosom still? What stubborn hope,
12.1074: fostered in cloud and cold? O, was it well
12.1075: to desecrate a god with mortal wound;
12.1076: or well (what were a nymph unhelped by thee?)
12.1077: to give back Turnus his lost sword, and lend
12.1078: strength unavailing to the fallen brave?
12.1079: Give o'er, and to our supplication yield;
12.1080: let not such grief thy voiceless heart devour;
12.1081: nor from thy sweet lips let thy mournful care
12.1082: so oft assail my mind. For now is come
12.1083: the last decisive day. Thy power availed
12.1084: to vex the Trojans upon land and sea,
12.1085: to wake abominable war, bring shame
12.1086: upon a royal house, and mix the songs
12.1087: of marriage and the grave: but further act
12.1088: I thee refuse.” Such was the word of Jove.
12.1089: Thus Saturn's daughter answered, drooping low
12.1090: her brows divine: “Because, great Jove, I knew
12.1091: thy pleasure, I from yonder earth retired
12.1092: and Turnus' cause, tho, with unwilling mind.
12.1093: Else shouldst thou not behold me at this hour
12.1094: Upon my solitary throne of air
12.1095: enduring fair and foul; I should be found
12.1096: flame-girded on the battle's deadly verge,
12.1097: tempting the Teucrians to a hated war.
12.1098: Yea, 't was my motion thrust Juturna forth
12.1099: to help her hapless brother. I approved—
12.1100: to save his life—that she should be too bold;
12.1101: but bade no whirl of spear nor bending bow:
12.1102: I swear it by th' inexorable fount
12.1103: whence flow the Stygian rivers, the sole seat
12.1104: where gods of light bow down in awful prayer.
12.1105: I yield me now; heart-sick I quit the war.
12.1106: But ask one boon, which in the book of fate
12.1107: is not denied; for Latium's good I sue,
12.1108: and high prerogatives of men that be
12.1109: thy kith and kin: when happy wedlock vows
12.1110: (aye, be it so!) shall join them by strong laws
12.1111: of chartered peace, let not the Latins Iose
12.1112: their ancient, native name. Bid them not pass
12.1113: for Trojans, nor be hailed as Teucer's sons;
12.1114: no alien speech, no alien garb impose.
12.1115: Let it be Latium ever; let the lords
12.1116: of Alba unto distant ages reign;
12.1117: let the strong, master blood of Rome receive
12.1118: the manhood and the might of Italy.
12.1119: Troy perished: let its name and glory die!”
12.1120: The Author of mankind and all that is,
12.1121: smiling benignant, answered thus her plea:
12.1122: “Jove's sister true, and Saturn's second child,
12.1123: what seas of anger vex thy heart divine!
12.1124: But come, relinquish thy rash, fruitless rage:
12.1125: I give thee this desire, and yield to thee
12.1127: shall keep the speech and customs of their sires;
12.1128: the name remains as now; the Teucrian race,
12.1129: abiding in the land, shall but infuse
12.1130: the mixture of its blood. I will bestow
12.1131: a league of worship, and to Latins give
12.1132: one language only. From the mingled breed
12.1133: a people shall come forth whom thou shalt see
12.1134: surpass all mortal men and even outvie
12.1135: the faithfulness of gods; for none that live
12.1136: shall render to thy name an equal praise.”
12.1137: So Juno bowed consent, and let her will
12.1138: be changed, as with much comfort in her breast

12.1140: After these things Jove gave his kingly mind
12.1141: to further action, that he might forthwith
12.1142: cut off Juturna from her brother's cause.
12.1143: Two plagues there be, called Furies, which were spawned
12.1144: at one birth from the womb of wrathful Night
12.1145: with dread Megaera, phantom out of hell;
12.1146: and of their mother's gift, each Fury wears
12.1148: These at Jove's throne attend, and watch the doors

12.1150: for wretched mortals, when the King of gods
12.1151: hurls pestilence and death, or terrifies
12.1152: offending nations with the scourge of war.
12.1153: 'T was one of these which Jove sent speeding down
12.1154: from his ethereal seat, and bade her cross
12.1155: the pathway of Juturna for a sign.
12.1156: Her wings she spread, and earthward seemed to ride
12.1157: upon a whirling storm. As when some shaft,
12.1158: with Parthian poison tipped or Cretan gall,
12.1159: a barb of death, shoots cloudward from the bow,
12.1160: and hissing through the dark hastes forth unseen:
12.1161: so earthward flew that daughter of the night.
12.1162: Soon as she spied the Teucrians in array
12.1163: and Turnus' lines, she shrivelled to the shape
12.1164: of that small bird which on lone tombs and towers
12.1165: sits perching through the midnight, and prolongs
12.1166: in shadow and deep gloom her troubling cry.
12.1167: In such disguise the Fury, screaming shrill,
12.1168: flitted in Turnus' face, and with her wings
12.1169: smote on his hollow shield. A strange affright
12.1170: palsied his every limb; each several hair
12.1171: lifted with horror, and his gasping voice
12.1172: died on his lips. But when Juturna knew
12.1173: from far the shrieking fiend's infernal wing,
12.1174: she loosed her tresses, and their beauty tore,
12.1175: to tell a sister's woe; with clenching hands
12.1176: she marred her cheeks and beat her naked breast.
12.1177: “What remedy or help, my Turnus, now
12.1178: is in a sister's power? What way remains
12.1179: for stubborn me? Or with what further guile
12.1180: thy life prolong? What can my strength oppose
12.1181: to this foul thing? I quit the strife at last.
12.1182: Withdraw thy terror from my fearful eyes,
12.1183: thou bird accurst! The tumult of thy wings
12.1184: I know full well, and thy death-boding call.
12.1185: The harsh decrees of that large-minded Jove
12.1186: I plainly see. Is this the price he pays
12.1187: for my lost maidenhood? Why flatter me
12.1189: my property of death? What boon it were
12.1190: to end this grief this hour, and hie away
12.1191: to be my brother's helpmeet in his grave!
12.1192: I, an immortal? O, what dear delight
12.1193: is mine, sweet brother, living without thee?
12.1194: O, where will earth yawn deep enough and wide
12.1195: to hide a goddess with the ghosts below?”
12.1196: She spoke; and veiled in glistening mantle gray
12.1197: her mournful brow; then in her stream divine
12.1198: the nymph sank sighing to its utmost cave.
12.1199: Aeneas now is near; and waving wide
12.1200: a spear like some tall tree, he called aloud
12.1201: with unrelenting heart: “What stays thee now?
12.1202: Or wherefore, Turnus, backward fly? Our work
12.1203: is not a foot-race, but the wrathful strife
12.1204: of man with man. Aye, hasten to put on
12.1205: tricks and disguises; gather all thou hast
12.1206: of skill or courage; wish thou wert a bird
12.1207: to fly to starry heaven, or hide thy head
12.1208: safe in the hollow ground!” The other then
12.1209: shook his head, saying: “It is not thy words,
12.1210: not thy hot words, affright me, savage man!
12.1211: Only the gods I fear, and hostile Jove.”
12.1212: Silent he stood, and glancing round him saw
12.1213: a huge rock Iying by, huge rock and old,
12.1214: a landmark justly sundering field from field,
12.1215: which scarce six strong men's shoulders might upraise,
12.1216: such men as mother-Earth brings forth to-day:
12.1217: this grasped he with impetuous hand and hurled,
12.1218: stretched at full height and roused to all his speed,
12.1219: against his foe. Yet scarcely could he feel
12.1220: it was himself that ran, himself that moved
12.1221: with lifted hand to fling the monster stone;
12.1222: for his knees trembled, and his languid blood
12.1223: ran shuddering cold; nor could the stone he threw,
12.1224: tumbling in empty air, attain its goal
12.1225: nor strike the destined blow. But as in dreams,
12.1226: when helpless slumber binds the darkened eyes,
12.1227: we seem with fond desire to tread in vain
12.1228: along a lengthening road, yet faint and fall
12.1229: when straining to the utmost, and the tongue
12.1230: is palsied, and the body's wonted power
12.1231: obeys not, and we have no speech or cry:
12.1233: his valiant spirit moved, the direful Fiend
12.1234: stopped in the act his will. Swift-changing thoughts
12.1235: rush o'er his soul; on the Rutulian host,
12.1236: then at the town he glares, shrinks back in fear,
12.1237: and trembles at th' impending lance; nor sees
12.1238: what path to fly, what way confront the foe:—
12.1240: Above his faltering terror gleams in air
12.1241: Aeneas' fatal spear; whose eye perceived
12.1242: the moment of success, and all whose strength
12.1243: struck forth: the vast and ponderous rock outflung

12.1262: and me, or, if thou wilt, my lifeless clay,

12.1264: my conqueror! Ausonia's eyes have seen
12.1265: me suppliant, me fallen. Thou hast made

12.1269: but his bare sword restraining; for such words
12.1270: moved on him more and more: when suddenly,
12.1271: over the mighty shoulder slung, he saw
12.1272: that fatal baldric studded with bright gold
12.1273: which youthful Pallas wore, what time he fell
12.1274: vanquished by Turnus' stroke, whose shoulders now
12.1275: carried such trophy of a foeman slain.
12.1276: Aeneas' eyes took sure and slow survey
12.1277: of spoils that were the proof and memory
12.1278: of cruel sorrow; then with kindling rage
12.1279: and terrifying look, he cried, “Wouldst thou,
12.1280: clad in a prize stripped off my chosen friend,
12.1281: escape this hand? In this thy mortal wound
12.1282: 't is Pallas has a victim; Pallas takes
12.1283: the lawful forfeit of thy guilty blood!”
12.1284: He said, and buried deep his furious blade
12.1285: in the opposer's heart. The failing limbs
12.1286: sank cold and helpless; and the vital breath
12.1287: with moan of wrath to darkness fled away.
